PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Douglas McClelland) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia,
Believing that men and women are equal but different,
Convinced that Australia can provide equal opportunity for all citizens without foreign treaties,
Concerned that ratifying the UN Discrimination Convention would give a Communist-dominated international committee to power to judge Australia's laws,
Humbly petition that your honourable House will not support the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women and we will always thus petition.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Convenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in Article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation and your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to R.A.A.F. Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned with the cut in funding to the Brisbane Airport, concerned that this cut means loss of jobs, concerned that this cut could seriously affect the economy of Queensland:
Humbly petition the Senate to request the Australian Government to:
1. Reverse its decision to cut funding to the Brisbane Airport.
2. Abide by the guarantee given by the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Airport would receive priority funding.
3. Assure the citizens of Queensland that the Brisbane Airport as the domestic and economic gateway to this State will be fully completed by 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the metric system and request the Government to restore the imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The concerns which people around the world have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Governments of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Reserves
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That as Mr R. J. L. Hawke has publicly stated:
(1) 'The Defence Force Reserves are the backbone of our nation's defence',
(2) The Defence Force Reserves are a highly economical and viable means of training men and women to serve Australia in times of emergency,
(3) The Reserves are composed of volunteers dedicated to Australia.

Furthermore, we the undersigned recognise that members of the reserves are required to maintain levels of efficiency at least equivalent to those of the permanent forces, and that members of reserves spend much of their own time and money towards reserve training obligations.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government recognise the role played by the reserves in serving Australia, that reserve pays and allowances are already far below the levels for equivalent work in the general workforce, and that therefore the proposed introduction of taxation to the meagre pays earned by members of the defence force reserves is a poor way of saying thank you.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
MIGRATION AMENDMENT BILL 1983

On 4 May 1983, when the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs announced the Government's criminal deportation policy in the House, he said that the Government would be introducing legislation to amend the Migration Act to remove the discrimination which exists against non-Commonwealth citizens in their liability for deportation as a result of crimes committed in Australia. He said discrimination is also found in other legislation within his portfolio and this is clearly inconsistent with the Australian Labor Government's policy of removing all forms of discrimination, wherever it may exist, in the Australian community.

The main purpose of the Migration Amendment Bill 1983 is to reform the Migration Act to remove the discrimination between aliens and other immigrants contained in the criminal deportation provisions. Permanent resident aliens- persons not United Kingdom, Irish or 'Commonwealth' citizens-are treated differently from other immigrants in these provisions: in particular, in the period for which they are liable to deportation as criminals-aliens remain always liable, other immigrants cannot be deported after 5 years from entry; and in the types of crimes for which they may be ordered deported. This discrimination is totally unacceptable to the Government. Accordingly, this Bill is being introduced to put all non-Australian citizens on the same footing in the Migration Act 1958.

The Migration Act was passed in 1958, almost 25 years ago. It has been amended on a number of occasions but has never been the subject of a complete review in the light of developments since 1958. The Act provides the machinery through which government immigration policies are implemented. During the past 25 years immigration policies have changed radically in response to changing community attitudes and interests, economic and employment conditions, conditions in other countries and the increasingly multicultural nature of our society. The number of movements into and out of Australia has increased significantly and the method of travel is now predominantly by aircraft.

It is the intention of the Government to review not only the Migration Act but also other legislation in the Immigration and Ethnic Affairs portfolio, including the Australian Citizenship Act 1948, to reflect the changes I have mentioned and to ensure that these Acts provide for the equal treatment of all non-citizens, whilst at the same time ensuring that appropriate controls are maintained. The amendments included in this Bill should therefore be regarded as the first steps towards achieving this end. They will remove obvious discrimination and correct other deficiencies of immediate concern-for example, the power to deport prostitutes or persons admitted to mental hospitals or public charitable institutions. Further amendments to the Migration Act, which is obviously in need of reform, will depend upon the outcome of the review. That review will take into account the views of the Human Rights Commission, which is examining the Migration Act.

The amendments introduced by this Bill will form a package under which consistent, firm, just and humane decisions can be made on the sensitive matter of the deportation of non-citizens convicted of serious crimes in Australia. The proposed legislative provisions relating to criminal deportation cannot be considered in isolation from the policy. The legislation does not define the basis on which decisions are to be taken; that is the purpose of the policy. Experience has shown that it is not feasible, nor proper, to define by legislation precisely who must be deported from Australia. Discretion must continue to be vested in the Minister to consider each case on its merits. The exercise of discretion under the Act must continue to be guided by statements of Government policy.

The Government must be able to protect the Australian community from non- citizens whose serious crimes show that they are a threat to the community. The Government must retain the legislative power to remove criminals and undesirables who have chosen not to commit themselves fully to Australia or who, through their own criminal actions, do not qualify for membership of the Australian community. The legislative power given by the Migration Act must, however, apply equally to all non-Australian citizens and not, as it now does, discriminate between 'aliens' and 'immigrants' both in respect of the types of crimes committed and the period during which they are committed.

Apart from removing the distinction and discrimination between non-Commonwealth and other overseas-born residents who are not Australian citizens, the Bill also limits liability for deportation, generally speaking, to those non-citizens who commit offences during the first 10 years of permanent residence and introduces a more exact measure of the seriousness of the crime, that being an actual penalty of imprisonment for 12 months or more.

The introduction of a statutory liability period of 10 years authorised residence fulfils a pre-election commitment by the Government that non-citizens should be free from the threat of deportation after a certain period. Currently persons who are citizens of non-Commonwealth countries remain always liable to deportation unless they become Australian citizens. This is unacceptable. In administering a large-scale immigration program the Government and the community must be prepared to accept some 'bad with the good'. The overwhelming majority of non-citizens who settle in this country are law-abiding members of the community and have a right to expect, after 10 years of lawful residence, that they will not be expelled. Honourable senators will note, when I turn to the details of the proposed amendments, that time actually spent in prison will not be regarded as authorized permanent residence. The objective of this exemption is to ensure that a non-citizen with a repetitive, and sometimes worsening, criminal record, if not deported on the basis of earlier convictions, will remain subject to deportation for a longer period.

Honourable senators will also note that the proposed section 12 includes a reference to the death penalty. This reference will be deleted from the Act when the death penalty has been abolished in all States. I particularly refer to Western Australia.

I must emphasise that the purpose of deporting a criminal is to protect the safety and welfare of the Australian community. Deportation is not imposed as a punishment and must not in any sense be regarded as punishment. It is for the courts to determine the sentences imposed for crimes committed and for the appropriate State authorities, or the Governor-General in the case of Federal offenders, to decide when the person is to be released from prison. While deportation may produce hardship, it is not done as a punishment. The Minister's responsibility is to weigh that hardship to the offender, and others whose interests would be affected by deportation, against harm to the community which might result from the person's continued presence in this country. Under this Government deportation is not automatic. A deportation order is made only after a full investigation of the case and a careful consideration of factors, including the legitimate rights of individuals, as outlined in the Government's criminal deportation policy statement.
Consistent with the Government's concern to protect civil liberties the scope of Ministerial discretion to deport a person under section 14 is to be seriously reduced.

Honourable senators will recall that existing section 14 of the Act discriminates between an alien and an immigrant and gives wide discretionary power to deport non-Australian citizens on the basis of their conduct. The Bill removes that discrimination and restricts the bases for deportation under section 14 to a non-citizen's conduct constituting a threat to the security of Australia or to his conviction of certain specific offences. This set of proposed amendments is designed to ensure the equal treatment of all non- citizens and the maintenance of appropriate controls on behalf of the general community in Australia.

When the amendments come into effect non-citizens will not be subject to deportation on the basis of their conduct after 10 years of permanent residence in Australia. The introduction of this statutory liability period of 10 years is consistent with the Government's pre-election commitment and the Government's recognition that the overwhelming majority of non-citizens who have settled in Australia and have contributed to the development of this country have a right to expect, after 10 years of lawful residence, that they will not be expelled.

One should not confuse amendments to section 14 of the Act on security grounds with amendments to existing sections 12 and 13 on the basis of criminal deportation. The protection of those who are within the scope of proposed new section 14 (1)-that is to say, temporary residents or permanent residents of less than 10 years standing-will be maintained if and when their conduct brings them within the much narrower scope of this proposed new sub-section. The Minister may not order their deportation unless a commissioner who is or has been a judge of a Federal Court or of the Supreme Court of a State or Territory, or a barrister or solicitor of the High Court of Australia or of a Supreme Court of a State or Territory of not less than five years standing, and who is appointed by the Governor-General has reviewed their case and has reported to the Minister within the framework of section 14.
I now turn to the details of the Bill.

Clause 4 of the Bill is an interpretation clause. It omits the definitions of ' alien', 'immigrant' and 'protected person' and inserts a definition of 'non- citizen' to mean a person who is not an Australian citizen. This definition is central to the operation of the Migration Act 1958, as it will be amended, because it puts all non-Australian citizens on the same footing. The clause also empowers the Minister to make valid decisions when at present only 'officers' and 'authorised officers' as defined in the Act may take such decisions.

Clause 6 seeks, amongst other things, to substitute neutral words in sub- section 6 (7) of the Act for words which are perceived by members of the community as discriminatory on the ground of sex. This amendment of a purely technical nature is in accordance with the Government's approach to sex discrimination.

Clause 8 contains the repeal of sub-section 7 (4) which at present allows overstayers to cease to be deportable five years after the expiry of their entry permit simply because they succeed in evading detection during that period of time. The effect of this repeal is to render future overstayers and those who, because of the operation of sub-section 7 (4), have ceased to be prohibited immigrants, liable to deportation from Australia. The repeal of sub-section 7 (4 ) will enhance the Government's control of its migration program which is overburdened by this 'backdoor' migration of overstayers who more often than not also work illegally. The amendment would not affect the status of former prohibited immigrants whose permanent residence has been regularised. Of course the repeal of sub-section 7 (4) would not result in massive and indiscriminate deportation of this class of non-citizens. Ministerial discretion to let them stay remains in certain circumstances. Each case will be considered on the basis of its merits.

A new section dealing with criminal deportation is to be inserted into the principal Act by clause 10. The new section 12 will render liable to deportation any non-citizen who has, within 10 years of being granted permanent residence, committed a crime for which he has been sentenced to death-the reference to the death penalty will be removed when all the States take if off their statute books-or to imprisonment for life or for a period of no less than one year. The period of 10 years shall be determined on the basis of legal presence or the aggregate of periods of legal presence in Australia, of the person as a permanent resident. It shall, however, exclude a period for which the person was confined in a prison as a result of conviction for any offence. For the purpose of this 10-year period, a period of presence in Australia of the person as an Australian citizen shall be included, to avoid an unintended adverse effect against a non-citizen who, during the length of his legal presence in Australia, acquired Australian citizenship and subsequently lost it, either by choice or by operation of law. The proposed section has no application with respect to prohibited non-citizens. It deals only with deportation of legal permanent residents who are non-citizens and who have committed crimes and have been sentenced as specified.

Clause 11 amends section 14 by omitting sub-sections (1) and (2). The clause inserts new sub-sections which remove the discrimination between the treatment of aliens and immigrants and confine and specify the basis upon which deportation may be ordered irrespective of the limitations applying to criminal deportations under section 12.
Clause 11 inserts new sub-section 14 (1) relating to deportation of non- citizens on the basis of their conduct which constitutes or has constituted a threat to the security of Australia.
The new sub-section provides a statutory immunity to permanent residents of not less than ten years in Australia.

Existing section 14 of the Act allows the Minister to order the deportation of an alien or an immigrant, with less than five years' residence, from Australia on the Minister's perception of that conduct. It is a very wide power available to the Minister. There is no attempt to define aspects of such conduct. It is a totally obnoxious section. It also allows the Minister to deport on the basis of very generalised security definitions. There is a process of review by a Commissioner appointed by the Governor-General with the Minister retaining the final power of decision.

The Migration Amendment Bill has narrowed this section to security grounds alone. It also defines the sections of the Crimes Act under which conviction becomes a trigger for a Ministerial decision to deport.
The Bill does not alter the right to request within thirty days a review by a Commissioner, or otherwise disturb this appeal system.

The Government has decided to further restrict the basis for ordering deportation under section 14 (1) on security grounds by providing immunity after a permanent resident has resided in Australia for an aggregate period of ten years, less time spent in prison, that is, exactly the same situation will apply to consideration of deportation on security grounds under section 14 (1) as applies to the criminal deportation procedure.

So we have moved from an extraordinarily wide, unfettered discretion under which the Minister has unbridled power to order deportation based upon a person' s alleged conduct, to a situation where the Minister may order deportation purely on security grounds with immunity after ten years, unless actually convicted under the Crimes Act 1914, and with an appeal provision still in place .
Clause 13 inserts certain proposed amendments to section 16 of the Act to render, in addition to existing grounds, a non-citizen to be deemed a prohibited non-citizen:

(i) where at the time of, or prior to, his entry into Australia, he makes or made, or causes or caused to be made, to the Minister or to an officer, in respect of that entry, a statement that is false or misleading in a material particular;

(ii) where at the time of, or prior to, the grant of a visa or a return endorsement to him, he makes or made, or causes or caused to be made, to the Minister or to an officer, in respect of the grant of that visa or return endorsement, a statement that is false or misleading in a material particular.

This clause also inserts a proposed amendment into section 16 to render a non- citizen a deemed prohibited non-citizen when, in seeking a further entry permit after his arrival, he produced or caused to be produced certain false, forged documents or made or caused to be made a false or misleading statement.
Clause 15 inserts a new sub-section into section 20 to provide that a deportation order will not become invalid through any delay in the execution of the order.

Clause 23 amends section 36A to extend the time within which a notice must be served on a carrier after a person is taken into custody under the section requiring the carrier to remove the person from Australia. Extension of the period of time for service of the notice from 24 hours to 48 hours will remove the current difficulties experienced in complying with the restrictive time requirement.

Clause 33 contains amendments to section 55 consequential upon the removal of the definition of 'alien'. Clause 36 amends various sections as set out in the Schedule. The amendments substitute, for references to 'immigrants' and ' prohibited immigrants', 'non-citizens' and 'prohibited non-citizens' respectively, and include other minor amendments of a technical nature.

Clause 37 is a transitional provision which renders a person who was a prohibited immigrant, or a deemed prohibited immigrant, before the commencement of this amending Act, to be a prohibited non-citizen or a deemed prohibited non- citizen, as the case may be. The clause also provides that an entry permit, visa , return endorsement or any other instrument that was in force under the principal Act immediately before the commencement of this amending Act, shall have effect as though it were in force under the provisions of the principal Act as so amended. The clause also preserves the validity of a deportation order which was made under the principal Act prior to the commencement of the amending Act and which was not revoked before the commencement of the amending Act.

The Government sees the Migration Amendment Bill 1983 as an important step in the reform of the Migration Act, for which the Government has a mandate following the last election. I commend the Bill to honourable senators.
MIGRATION (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1983

The purpose of this Bill is to amend a number of Commonwealth Acts consequential upon the Migration Amendment Bill 1983. The latter Bill, which removes the distinction between aliens and immigrants from the Migration Act 1958, will necessitate amendments to other legislation, in particular where terms are defined by reference to meanings within that Act.
I now turn to the details of the Bill.

Part II of the Bill effects amendments to section 25 of the Australian Citizenship Act 1948 which are consequential to the removal of references to ' prohibited immigrant' from the Migration Act 1958. Clause 4 inserts a new sub- section 25 (7) to provide that a person who entered Australia before the commencement of the Migration Amendment Act 1983 and who at the time of entry, was a prohibited immigrant or the holder of a temporary entry permit, shall not become an Australian citizen under the section. The clause also inserts a new sub-section 25 (7A) to provide that a person who enters Australia after the commencement of the Migration Amendment Act 1983 and who at the time of entry, is a prohibited non-citizen or the holder of a temporary entry permit, shall not become an Australian citizen under the section.
Part III effects a consequential amendment to the Civil Aviation (Offenders on International Aircraft) Act 1970.
Part IV effects a consequential amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
Part V amends the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946 so as to be consistent with the amendments contained in the Migration Amendment Bill 1983.
Part VI effects consequential amendments to the Navigation Act 1912.
Part VII effects a consequential amendment to the Navigation Amendment Act 1980 .

Part VIII effects consequential amendments to the Overseas Students Charge Act 1979. Clause 27 provides that a person shall be taken not to be an overseas student if the person ceases to be an immigrant within the meaning of the Migration Act 1958 as in force immediately before the commencement of the Migration Amendment Act 1983.
Part IX effects consequential amendments to the Quarantine Act 1908.
Part X effects a consequential amendment to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill will modify from 1 October 1983 the terms on which an income tax rebate is available to home buyers during the first five years of occupation of a sole or principal residence in Australia.
The change was announced in the 19 May economic statement, as part of an overall package of housing measures.
In particular, it was announced then that there would be a new cash subsidy scheme which would provide assistance to first home buyers, on an income tested basis, from 1 October 1983.

The schemes of assistance for home buyers introduced by the previous government had been neither efficient nor effective in targeting assistance to those in most need and in providing a stimulus to the housing industry.
One of those schemes, which provided a tax rebate on the portion of interest payments that exceeded 10 per cent per annum on loans of up to $60,000, was terminated with effect from 1 July 1983.

The other tax rebate scheme, which applies only to first home buyers, is to be modified by this Bill so that, subject to a transitional measure, there will be no new entrants to the scheme after 30 September 1983.

After that date prospective first home buyers will come within the new first home owners assistance scheme, which will have the effect of making home ownership an attainable goal of many more Australian families.

Home buyers who first occupy their sole or principal residence by 30 September 1983 will remain entitled to a tax rebate on home loan interest payments during the first five years of ownership, subject to an income test.
Under the income test, benefits will be available in full to taxpayers whose family income in the 1982-83 income year does not exceed $24,300.
Where a taxpayer's family income in that year exceeds $24,300 the rebate will be shaded out progressively, finally cutting out at $27,900.
In applying the income test, family income will be taken to be the combined taxable income of the taxpayer and, where relevant, of the person who is the taxpayer's spouse on 1 October 1983.
For the 1983-84 income year, of course, only the rebate entitlement for the period after 30 September 1983 will be income tested.

Although, as a general rule, there will be no new entrants to the rebate scheme after 30 September 1983, taxpayers who contract to acquire or build or commence to build by that date will be brought within the scheme even though they occupy the home after 30 September.

This transitional measure to extend entry into the scheme will protect those first home buyers who will not be eligible for assistance under the proposed first home owners assistance scheme that I referred to earlier.
Without this extension of the rebate some lower income first home buyers would not be entitled to the benefits of either scheme.

In applying the income test in these cases, family income will be the combined taxable income of the taxpayer and, where relevant, of the person who is the taxpayer's spouse when the home is first occupied.
A memorandum explaining the technical features of the Bill is being made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Button) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of the Bill is to make provision for the financing of the prospective 1983-84 Budget deficit.

The Budget deficit in prospect for 1983-84 gives rise to a deficit in the consolidated revenue fund of about the same magnitude and thus creates a need to seek authority to finance certain expenditures from borrowings to the extent that amounts appropriate by the Parliament for expenditure from the consolidated revenue fund will exceed moneys legally available to that fund.

Legally, expenditure from the consolidated revenue fund cannot exceed the moneys available to that fund. Thus, successive governments have, for many years , introduced legislation in the form of a Loan Bill to authorise payments from the loan fund to meet defence and certain non-defence expenditures.

In the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that the prospective Budget deficit for this financial year is estimated to be some $8.4 billion. The shortfall in the consolidated revenue fund is estimated to be of the same order.
Under existing standing authorities some $2 billion of expenditure can be charged to loan fund. This leaves a shortfall of some $6.4 billion for which separate funding authority is required.
This Bill therefore seeks authority to borrow moneys for defence and other purposes to enable certain other expenditures to be met from the loan fund rather than from the consolidated revenue fund.
I should make it clear, however, that the Bill does not authorise defence or other expenditures additional to those otherwise authorised by Parliament.

The Bill does not include any specific limit on the amount of borrowings that may be undertaken. The actual limit, in the case of defence expenditure, however , is the amount for which appropriation is sought for defence purposes in the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1983-84-some $5 billion-and any subsequent moneys for defence purposes that may be approved in subsequent Appropriation Acts. The effective limit is likely to be significantly less than these amounts as defence expenditures cannot be charged to loan fund until the legislation is enacted.

The legal limit for borrowings for non-defence purposes is determined by the level of borrowing authority approved by the loan council. Together, it is estimated that these limits will be sufficient to enable the financing of the Budget deficit.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Collard) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW REFORM ORDINANCE AND CUSTOMS REGULATIONS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Postponement of Notices of Motion
Motion (by Senator Lewis)-by leave-agreed to:

That Business of the Senate, Notices of Motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in the name of Senator Coates for the next day of sitting and relating to the disallowance of the Law Reform (Miscellaneous Provisions) (Amendment) Ordinance 1982 and certain Customs (Cinematograph Films) Regulations (Amendment), be postponed till five sitting days after today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Health Insurance Commission Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 88, and made under the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, be disallowed.

In the next few weeks the Parliament will be considering some legislation to establish Labor's health care program. There are indications that that program may attract support from the Parliament, though we have objections to it in principle which we will make known at an appropriate time. Today's debate is not about that legislation. It is about the processes and procedures which are being used to start to implement Labor's program even before there is a legislative basis for it. It is to test in Parliament the action which has been taken by the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), using his power to make regulations. That power enables him to proceed in advance of any parliamentary consideration. Regulations enable Ministers to proceed with the business of government, but Parliament can set aside such decisions when it disapproves of them or when the action is deemed to be inappropriate. Disallowance of regulations such as we are proposing now is a well-established procedure in this Senate and there have been disallowances of government regulations that I can remember every year I have been present in the Senate.

The regulation in this case was put down on 29 June by the Minister for Health. It was a regulation seeking to establish Medibank-the Health Insurance Commission-as the sole state-backed monopoly to take over the functions of Medicare from the voluntary health funds. The regulation seeks to establish a monopoly for the purposes of the Medicare program. It is an argument about the methods and the consequences of that action that is before us today. It is not of itself an argument about Medicare or the Medicare program. That is a debate we will take up at some other time. While the Australian Labor Party claims that it has a mandate to introduce Medicare, we do not believe that that mandate, however widely expressed, gives it the right at one stroke to do a number of unsatisfactory things: First, to threaten the viability of many private health funds; second, to wipe out thousands of jobs of those employed in the private health funds.

One of the most unsatisfactory features of the regulation is that it has put in train the loss of jobs of many people at a time when the Government is talking about the importance of preserving jobs. It is a regulation which moves towards making less available the convenience of one-stop shopping for the majority of people who want to take out additional private insurance. It incurs unnecessary establishment costs, perhaps of the order of $40m. At a time when the Government is talking about economic stringency it is unnecessary that this money be spent- taxpayers' money-in duplicating the facilities already available within the voluntary funds. It will involve additional ongoing expenses if Medibank is given the monopoly of the operation of Labor's new health insurance system.

The argument is about whether or not the Health Insurance Commission should have a monopoly in this matter. The regulation about which we are talking sought to give effect to that intention. The Minister for Health has over recent weeks, I am afraid, engaged in some bluff, some standover tactics, saying that if this regulation were disallowed the whole Medicare program might be threatened. Let us put that to one side-that is nonsense. Medicare is to be proceeded with by the Government whether or not this regulation is disallowed. This is a matter for the Senate and the introduction of the program will not be affected. It was foolish of the Minister to try to pretend that our consideration of this regulation would in some way put in question the threshold issue of whether the Labor Party intended to proceed with its Medicare proposals. Of course it will proceed. This issue is quite separate and can be looked at on its merits.

The Opposition is concerned about the regulation for a number of reasons. The most alarming aspect of the implementation proposal for the Australian public seems to be that the Government appears intent upon eliminating a satisfactory competitive private industry with the willingness and the ability necessary to administer Medicare and to replace it with a single expensive monopoly with all the potential that monopolies have for long term cost and for service inefficiencies. The private funds have already demonstrated their ability to operate cost effectively, and more cost effectively than has Medibank Private. I draw the attention of honourable senators who may have looked at the reports of the Health Insurance Commission over a number of years to the fact that in some States the Health Insurance Commission through its Medibank operations was effectively bankrupt. It was operating at a loss in all States across Australia except Victoria. It has not shown any capacity to operate effectively in a commercial sense over a number of years. It does not have a proven track record. The private health funds have. They are in place, their employees are in place, their outlets are in place. If it is service to the public we are looking to, it just does not make sense for the Government to want to move to create a monopoly and to give that monopoly to a fund which, if it had been a private fund, would have had to close its doors because of its poor commerical performance.

The Government, if it had accepted all the offers of the private health funds, could have ensured the implementation of its Medicare program without disruption , without extra expenditure and waste, without significant unemployment and without forcing the public to use just the one government-operated fund. It could have done so with the competitive and service elements important to efficient operation. It may be that the Government has decided to give the private funds a post office role, and I will come back in a moment to what the Government's later plans may have been. But if the Government wants to implement what is contained in this regulation, its proposal does not make sense for a number of reasons. It does not make sense for economic reasons because the implementation costs of duplicating the funds' existing facilities to do the same job by using a vastly expanded Medibank Private will be $40m. Nearly all this significant expense is unnecessary, nearly all of it represents duplication and it can be described only as totally wasteful, particularly in light of the financial restraint and the penalties that the Labor Government has imposed on other sections of the community. Why spend this money if it does not have to be spent? No argument can be advanced that a single bureaucratic monopoly, with all its ongoing operational costs and Public Service conditions, would be less costly or more efficient than a competitive private insurance market.

Another reason why it is not sensible to go down the track the Government has proposed relates to employment and jobs. At a time of high unemployment the Government's proposals to spend $80m unnecessarily will be accompanied by a net loss of at least 2,000 jobs in the health insurance industry. At the same time the Minister can give no firm guarantee as to the employment status of a further 5,000 people who will be sacked. Let us take that a little further. It is true that the Health Insurance Commission will need to take on some extra employees. The Government may say that the people who are laid off from the private funds can be taken on by Medibank, but what is not clear is the mechanics of how this will happen. The Health Insurance Commission will require staff well before the commencement of Medicare on 1 February, yet the private funds will need all their present staff to continue their operations up to that date. The staff will be taken on by Medicare before the staff will be laid off by the private funds. The disemployment will be considerable. It is unnecessary and it will be hurtful . To be kind to the Government, it has displayed amazing ineptitude and insensitivity in going down this track at a time when it has asserted that jobs are an important issue for the Australian people.

The Minister has been unconvincing in his arguments in support of the Health Insurance Commission as the sole operator in implementing Medicare. He asks us to believe that economies of scale will be achieved by the single monopoly. He says that there will be economies of scale compared with the operation of the competitive private funds. He says that that entitles the Health Insurance Commission to sole agency rights. It has never been shown that government monopolies operate as efficiently or more efficiently than the private sector. I remind honourable senators of some of the well-known features of monopolies-be they private monopolies or State monopolies. They are characterised by low morale. They are characterised by an accident proneness. When they make mistakes those mistakes tend to be enormous mistakes because the monopoly tends to make a single response to any change in its environment. When that mistake is made it tends to be a colossal blunder. Monopolies are characterised by high costs and inflating costs. They are characterised by great vulnerability to industrial action. They are characterised by an insensitivity to individual needs and wants . Of course, the power of monopolies is something from which ordinary citizens suffer, be they monopolies of capital, labour or of government. They all have these unsatisfactory features.

Just as puzzling but nevertheless fallacious is the Minister's assertion that Medibank's experience qualifies it for the sole agency. I would have thought that Medibank's experience in the market was one thing which would have led us to believe that it was not qualified to take on the job which it was given by the regulation which the Minister brought down. It was bankrupt in some States and it was operating unsuccessfully in other States. Only in one State was it making money-Victoria. The Minister made the statement that the Health Insurance Commission was selected because it operates an Australia-wide fund and it is generally recognised that its method of cash payments is superior and that it has a network of 278 branches throughout Australia. The Minister's ignorance is outstanding. Private health funds in each State have a far greater network of branches. They have over 1,000 branches, to be exact. If it is the convenience of the public we are thinking about, it makes no sense to say that it is an advantage for a fund with 278 branches to take over from funds which have 1,000 branches. Between them the private health funds also have Australia-wide coverage. They have the advantage of local experience. They have reciprocal claims agreements throughout Australia and they have the most efficient cash payment system in existence in health insurance.

I now pick up the point of medical fraud as it relates to this issue. There is another matter which has not been understood or taken on by the Government in seeking to give to Medibank Private a monopoly over its Medicare program. If it does this it will make the detection of medical fraud significantly more difficult. We have information that it would create a discontinuity of patient treatment information, which is essential to the application of the fraud and overservicing, or FOD, system. Apparently there is no way of relating the patient information that is stored in the funds' records to the patient information that will be stored in the new Medicare computer file. The old information will have its particular patient identification numbering system as used within the private funds. The new Medicare system will have its new Medicare family numbers. During the changeover period there will be no way in which to relate the fraud and overservicing experience of the private funds to that of Medicare. By giving Medicare a monopoly and taking the matter out of the hands of the private funds, this Australian Labour Party Government will be making it harder to detect fraud and overservicing. Unless doctor servicing patterns can be related to particular patients, the fraud and overservicing system will have no data base on which to launch action in particular cases. It is necessary to relate particular patients and their experience to the activities of particular doctors. Breaking up the record system, duplicating computers and using different numbers will make this more difficult. If the Australian Labour Party wanted to make it simple for those few people who practice fraud and overservicing to prosper this would be one way to do it. It will make it almost impossible to counter fraud. It will take anything up to 12 months for the necessary computer data to be assembled. By the time it would be possible to match data we would hope that doctors would have adjusted their servicing levels in an appropriate way, but of course those who practice overservicing or fraud may have adjusted to a new plateau in some other way. They may escape detection simply because of what this Labour Government is doing .

That leaves only the question why we wish to proceed with this disallowance motion today. First, I understand that legislation has been introduced in another place and that included in it is an attempt to repeal the particular regulation concerned. Let me point out that legislation introduced is not legislation passed. The problem is that the time allowed for disallowance is limited. We have a certain number of sitting days in which to effect it. If we do not proceed to effect it within that time our right to do so will have gone forever. A government which introduces legislation can take its time and decide the speed at which the legislation is to go through the Parliament. It can in fact amend the legislation. There is no guarantee that a provision contained in a Bill that was introduced last night in the House of Representatives will be in the legislation that is finally passed. It is entirely possible that if we give up the opportunity to disallow now the Government could alter its mind and go down a different path. Now is the time to consider the regulation in the Senate on its merits and to disallow it. Let the legislation follow and be dealt with on its merits. If this Australian Labour Party Government intends to include in its legislation a provision repealing the regulation, surely that removes any reason at all for members of that Party not wishing to support this disallowance motion today. If the Government is moving in its legislation to repeal the regulation, why should they not support us today in our motion for disallowance? The Australian Labour Party has indicated that the regulation is to go.

If it is to go next week one may well ask: Why not support that happening today . I say to the Australian Democrats: 'If we know that it is to be a part of the Governments program to disallow this regulation next week, what reason is there not to support disallowance today?' What reason in logic is there for not supporting disallowance? I remind the Senate of two statements issued in recent times. The first is a joint statement issued on 13 July by my colleague the honourable member for Mackellar, Jim Carlton, who is the shadow Minister for Health; Senator Janine Haines, spokesperson on health for the Australian Democrats; and Senator Brian Harradine.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot blackmail them that way. They realise time has passed and things have changed.

—I am grateful to the honourable senator for that Jesuitical interjection. The statement which appeared on 13 July committed the people who were party to it to moving to disallow this particular regulation. The Press release argued persuasively why the regulation was inappropriate. It indicated why it was appropriate to move to disallow this particular piece of subordinate legislation. This statement issued by the Australian Democrats, Senator Harradine and the Liberal Party of Australia is on the public record for anyone to see. I am moving today to give effect to what was promised by the people who were party to that document. The other matter to which I draw the Senate's attention is the August 1983 issue of a journal called Medical Practice.
—I have read that.

—I am glad Senator Haines has read this journal. I would say the honourable senator received very honourable comment in the article to which I will refer. The article is entitled 'Beginning of the End for Freedom of Choice?'. A small part of it says:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Haines spoke out strongly against some of the implementation features of Medicare, saying she was not and never had been a person to turn her back on a fight.
The article then quotes Senator Haines as follows:
Medibank Private will get the sole agency rights to administer Medicare only after I have tried everything possible to prevent it-everything, that is, short of voting against the levy bill.

That is entirely consistent with the Press statement of 13 July and I would say to honourable senators that we have a case where what is proposed in the regulation is undesirable, has been recognised by the Liberals as being undesirable and has been acknowledged as being undesirable by the Australian Democrats. We have a situation where the Government has now indicated that it will repeal the regulation next week. Senator Chipp seems to be distressed. I am doing no more than quoting people's own words. We have a situation where the Australian Democrats have given a public commitment to oppose the regulation, because Senator Haines at a meeting-I say it again-said:
Medibank Private will get the sole agency rights to administer Medicare only after I have tried everything possible to prevent it . . .

Today we have the first of those things that can be done, that is, a move to disallow this regulation. I for one am not prepared to forgo the rights of the Senate to move against subordinate legislation simply because a government has said that when legislation gets here sometime it will contain some provision to do the same thing. If that is the case, if the Government is happy to see the regulation disallowed later on, then why not disallow it sooner. For that reason I invite honourable senators to join the Liberal Party in disallowing this regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was rather intrigued to hear Senator Peter Baume's speech since it sounded remarkably like the one he referred to as being reported in the medical journal, which was one I delivered to the New South Wales branch of the Australian Medical Association, I think on 17 July this year. A certain sense of deja vu overcame me whilst listening to Senator Baume. I was also intrigued to hear his comments about disemployment being hurtful since I would suggest that part of the reason why so many Liberal senators and members are now disemployed is because of the previous Government's attitude to a universal basic health insurance scheme. It may interest Senator Baume to hear the contents of a telex I sent today to those people with whom I have spent the last three months negotiating changes to the Government's proposed scheme. I was under the impression that today we were simply going to debate the disallowance of the Health Insurance Commission regulations. Senator Baume has brought in other matters so I will follow suit. When the Government introduced this scheme it said that it would introduce a one per cent levy on taxable income and that it would make Medibank Private the sole agent, thereby eliminating any role for the other private health insurance funds, which would decimate, if not actually destroy, employment in that area. The Liberals seemed to sit back for some months and take this quietly. I do not know whether it was because they had not got their act together, whether they were not particularly concerned, or whether they were going to vote against the whole lot and were not interested in helping anybody along the way. I have spent the last three months negotiating with the Government, at times with some acrimony but generally with courtesy on both sides, and finally some considerable amount of co-operation. As a result quite a number of concessions that will assist the funds, their employees and their contributors have been achieved. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) brought down the legislation last night. This morning I sent a telex to the AMA, the health insurance funds, the private hospital organisations, all of those people with whom I have been closely involved in the last few months. The telex reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Omnibus Medicare legislation appears to contain all concessions wrung from Government in past three months. Only surprise is clause 71 (2) which repeals the June 29 Health Insurance Commission Regulation. This makes Senate disallowance unnecessary.

Further negotiations with Government in the past few days indicate that they will also allow the funds to forward Medicare forms to HIC for those contributors who have additional insurance. This will ensure minimum inconvenience to contributors, making them unlikely to transfer their custom to Medibank Private, and thus will stabilise employment.
In addition, the Government may be prepared to agree to limited gap insurance for people with some chronic illnesses such as asthma.
I will elaborate on that in a moment. At 9.40 this morning I had a meeting with the Minister, and have now settled on a proposal in that area. The telex continues:

The achievement of all the above concessions has occured despite the lack of cooperation of the Liberal Party. Their inflammatory remarks and totally intransigent attitude mean I have been unable to persuade my colleagues or the Government to agree to any other concessions e.g. full agency rights for the funds, full gap insurance or opposition to the diagnostic services clause. The latter must now be taken up at State Government level.

The AMA, VHIAA, Private Hospitals Association and other concerned groups are all to be commended for their reasoned and reasonable approach to the legislation. Thank you for your assistance and advice over the past hectic months. Had the Liberal Opposition chosen to follow this lead, I believe an even better Bill would have resulted. Sadly this did not occur.

I point out to Senator Baume that, in honouring the Press release which I put out jointly with the honourable member for Mackellar, Mr Carlton, and Senator Harradine, I will support the disallowance motion. As I indicated in this telex, for very good reasons I have been unable to convince my colleagues to join me in that. I respect their attitude. Last night the Government moved to repeal this regulation.

The Government has included in the legislation a series of concessions which include deregulating the funds, but not Medibank Private, which will allow the private health insurance funds in this country to extend their services beyond health insurance. It will allow them to offer a wide range of additional and ancillary health insurance including chiropractic insurance, private hospital insurance and a wide range of alternative health care insurance. Limits have been placed on Medibank Private's role in this area and in others in its accounting procedures and in its sharing with Medicare the 86 other outlets. It will also not be able to piggy-back with Medicare on any advertising. The Government has included ease of mergers in the legislation; it has allowed for regional funds; it has amended the reserve requirements for the funds. As I indicated in the telex to those people with whom I have been negotiating, the Government has now agreed to a post box arrangement or a de facto agency arrangement whereby people will be able to drop off their Medicare forms at the agency-the Hospitals Benefits Association Ltd, or Mutual Health, for example- through which they choose to take out their additional and ancillary insurance. That insurance fund will then forward those Medicare claim forms to the HIC which will process them and send them directly to the contributors.

Over the past few years when the previous Liberal Government tinkered pathologically with the previous Labor Government's health insurance system, the Labor Opposition, with some reason, frequently got hysterical over the fact that people were being constantly chopped and changed in their routine and were being confused and inhibited in the way they conducted their medical insurance. I would have thought, therefore, that it would have been in the interests of all parties to make sure that the next implementation of basic universal health insurance via a levy scheme, a system which is part of the Australian Democrats' policy and which is part of the Australian Labor Party's policy, should be introduced as smoothly as possible with as little inconvenience to the public, the consumer, as is legislatively possible. I point out that, in getting these concessions, I have worked exceedingly hard. I believe we have achieved a very great deal not only to assist those people employed in the funds but also to ensure the long term role for the private health insurance industry and the minimal amount of public inconvenience.

This morning, Dr Blewett informed me that our negotiations for providing a limited form of gap insurance had borne fruit. Yesterday, I put to him the suggestion that the group of people most likely to be seriously inconvenienced by a prohibition against gap insurance which is now included in the legislation would be those people who suffer from certain chronic illnesses, in particular, families which have one or more children who suffer from asthma. That condition, like a number of other conditions, including diabetes, Parkinson's disease and so on, requires spasmodic, frequent trips to doctors or to hospitals. This can leave parents, particularly those in low and low-middle income families considerably out of pocket. I suggested to him, therefore, that he come up with a list of accepted chronic illnesses and people, families included, suffering from those illnesses who would be permitted to take out gap insurance. This morning Dr Blewett informed me that it is not possible in the time left to the Government to provide that sort of list to the private health insurance funds. However, the Government has said that it is prepared to carry for everybody in this country that 15 per cent gap over and above an initial cost of around $120 to $150 a year. We are still negotiating on what that cut off level will be. But the Government is prepared to say that contributors-ordinary Australians and their families-will be expected to pay no more than around $120 to $150 a year in excess medical payments; that is, the 15 per cent that remains over and above the Medicare cover at 85 per cent, but that Medicare will fund this. I believe that this is an important step forward.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do they administer it?
—Very easily-in fact, I understand, much more easily than going through a private insurance agency.
—Could you explain it?

—Will I explain the administration of it? No, I spent 15 minutes with the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) this morning in between a Senate select committee meeting, a party meeting and here. Basically, this is all I can give to the honourable senator. When a doctor does not bulk bill and people are expected to pay the additional 15 per cent up to the 100 per cent of the recommended fee-I am not talking about where doctors exceed that; I am talking only about the 15 per cent left--
—The gap insurance?

—Yes, the gap between the 85 per cent and the 100 per cent. People will be expected to pay no more than a fixed amount per person per year before the Government is prepared to pay that gap. I think this will assist a great number of families.
—How much will it cost?
—The cost to the Government is somewhere in the range, I understand, of $8m to $10m.
—You have agreed to it.
—The administration of it is not my problem; it is the Government 's problem. If it says that it can do it, I believe it.
—Are you going to oppose it?
—I am just dying to know what the cost of administration will be .
—Order! Senator Haines has the call.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. For the last three months I have engaged in extensive negotiations with the Government, the health funds, the Australian Medical Association and the private hospital people in order to come up with some legislation which not only matches Labor and Australian Democrats policy but also assists these people. I believe the list of eight or 10 concessions that we have obtained, which either are or will be incorporated in the legislation, is testimony to what can be achieved by co-operative consensus. It is a shame that other members of the Opposition do not take part in any of this. The legislation contains these concessions. After the Government accepts my amendments next week, it will contain the remaining concessions with regard to the de facto agency arrangement and the Government sponsored gap insurance. I hope that from 1 February we will see a national universal basic health insurance scheme operate to the advantage of all Australians and minus the nitpicking and inflammatory statements that have come from the Liberal Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard Senator Haines tell us what a wonderful negotiating job she did. However, she only got a little way with it. I gather that the Australian Democrats, even though they were not satisfied with their negotiating and did not accomplish all they set out to accomplish, will still vote for an imperfect Bill. That is how it has come across to me in this place today. If the funds had been able to join with Medicare they would have been able to provide a system without disruption, without excessive expenditure, without waste, without the significant unemployment that will result from this and without forcing on the people one fund instead of giving them a right to choose and, at the same time, retaining a competitive service, which element is so important to on-going efficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: If we ask ourselves why, given all that the private funds could have done, the Government came forward with this proposal of wanting Medibank Private to take over the administration of Medicare, we have only to look at the policy of the Australian Labor Party, which is to socialise as much as it can. It is a socialist government and it intends to socialise the funds. This is its method of doing that. The Government set up a task force, an administrative advisory committee, to advise it on the implementation of medicare. If we look at the members of that committee there will be no doubt as to why they came up with the decision they did because the Government included on this committee three Medibank Private assistant general managers, an ex-Medibank Private general manager and an ex-Medibank Private chairman. No representatives from the private health funds were included. If the Government wants certain advice then it is very simple for it to set up a committee of people whose opinions it knows will give it that advice. It is just a ludicrous situation for the Government to hide behind the committee it has set up. The Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) said in his statement:

It is generally recognised that the Health Insurance Commission's way of dealing with cash payments is superior . . . with its nation wide network of branches already established the Health Insurance Commission, in operating Medicare, will provide convenient and efficient services for Australians and their families.

Who generally recognises that the Health Insurance Commission deals in a superior way with cash payments? Was it the committee which was made up of Medibank Private managers, the ex-chairman, et cetera? It is certainly not recognised by the Australian community. The Government has not even sought that. It sought advice only from the committee it set up consisting of Medibank Private general managers, the ex-chairman, et cetera. It did not put any members of the private funds on that committee. What was it frightened of by not including them? Was it frightened of the fact that the private health funds could prove that they had a more efficient management? Was the Government frightened that they may remind Medibank Private that our Government had to get Medibank out of a terrible financial mess that it was in by giving it an addtional $11m?

TALK.START.PARA: —Twenty-one million dollars.

—No. Altogether it was $21m. We started off with $11m and had to get Medibank out of financial trouble by giving it another $10m. Was the Government concerned that if it put some of the representatives from the private health funds on that committee to advise it they might come up with this sort of information? I quote the management costs as a percentage of contribution income -that is, the management costs of the funds compared with the income from their contributions. In 1978 the figure for Medibank Private was 14 per cent and the figure for the voluntary health organisations was 9.7 per cent. In 1979 Medibank Private's was 12 per cent and the voluntary health funds' percentage was 10.3 per cent. In 1980 Medibank Private's was 17 per cent-this is its costs as a percentage of its contribution rate-and the private industry's was 11 per cent. In 1981 Medibank Private's was 16.4 per cent and the voluntary health funds' figure was 11.7 per cent. Last year, in 1982, Medibank Private was still well ahead with 11.7 per cent and the voluntary health funds figure was 10.1 per cent . We are told by the Minister that Medibank Private is economically able to do this. What absolute rubbish.

SPEECH.PARA: I go on to management costs as a percentage of total claims benefits paid out, because this is also an indication of who runs the most cost-effective industry. In 1978 the figure for Medibank Private was 13.8 per cent and that for the voluntary health industry was 9.4 per cent. In 1979 Medibank Private was 13.7 per cent while the voluntary health funds' was 9.4 per cent. In 1980 Medibank Private's was 13.4 per cent and the private funds' was 9.8 per cent. In 1981 Medibank Private's was 13.5 per cent and the private funds' was 10.1 per cent. In 1982 Medibank Private's was 10.1 per cent and the private funds' was 9.5 per cent. It is ludicrous for the Minister to say that Medibank Private will be more economically viable and more cost effective than the private funds. That is blatant misrepresentation. It is not a truthful statement. I believe the only reason for him putting forward those comments is that he wants to say to the Australian people: 'Bigger is beautiful, therefore we will socialise the funds. We will get rid of them'.

In this statement he said that over 60 funds presently handle medical benefit payments and this has resulted in expensive levels of service to the Australian public. As I have just demonstrated, that is 100 per cent wrong. He talked about 60 funds. There are 62 funds. Only 40 of those are open to the public. The others are private, closed or company-run funds. Again he is dealing in half truths. He makes it sound as though there are over 60 funds open to the public, and that is not true. He uses half truths in his statements. I am appalled at the Minister's misrepresentation. There are only five major funds and they deal with almost 60 per cent of the population. Medibank Private covers 24 per cent. So 84 per cent of the population is covered by just six funds, yet the Minister says there is a great conglomeration of funds and that this makes the system expensive for the people of Australia. That is not true. Through interjection earlier, Senator Crowley compounded the situation by saying there are 70 funds. She should know that is completely inaccurate. There are 62 funds. It is a pity that the Opposition cannot put its case forward to the people in a truthful manner so that they can understand what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is an admission, is it? You said: 'The Opposition'.

—I am sorry, the Government. The Labor Party should be in opposition. Mr Deputy President, as Senator Peter Baume has said, there is a duplication of existing facilities. Indeed, the cost to the Australian taxpayer is $80m. Nearly all of this is completely wasteful. It will now cost a taxpayer an additional $20m for ongoing services. That is $10m in additional costs that need not have occurred. It will indeed only create additional costs to the people of Australia. The Minister has said in the past that it will be less costly for the average Australian. The average Australian will pay more. The average Australian will be paying his one per cent and he will also have to pay a contribution if he insures privately with the private hospitals and this of course has not been indicated by the Minister at all.
—Rubbish.
—It has never been indicated by the Minister at all because he said very clearly that it would be less expensive for the average Australian.
—It will be.

—Senator Crowley has already proved today that she has not spoken the truth when she mentions the 70 funds, so I would cast out any further interjection she may make. As has already been stated by Senator Peter Baume we have found in the past that any government monopoly always has to be subsidised in the end. Government monopolies are not capable of running on their own finances. They end up being subsidised. As I said earlier, we already have proof that Medibank Private was one of those instrumentalities because our Government had to pull it out of the situation it got into with an additional $11m subsidy. I will leave the rest of debate on this legislation until it reaches the Senate. I support Senator Peter Baume's motion for disallowance of this regulation and only hope that the Australian Democrats will do as they have previously indicated and support it. Senator Haines has already indicated that she wishes to support this motion for disallowance. Her colleagues have not supported her on this but I presume, as the Democrats say that they can vote the way they want to vote, that Senator Haines will be joining the Liberals in their vote on this motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears from the debate thus far and the indications that have been given that the motion for disallowance will not succeed. Nevertheless, I feel that it is necessary for the Senate to make a stand when it comes to regulations of this kind, particularly regulations that are framed and gazetted during the parliamentary recess. This regulation was to make additional functions for the Health Insurance Commission and in particular it stated:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes. . . of the Act the following functions are prescribed, that is to say, to plan and establish the organization required to administer a health insurance scheme to provide benefits in respect of medical, optometrical, dental and pathology services to all Australian residents.

That of course was pre-empting the debate on the Government's proposed health insurance legislation which was brought into Parliament only yesterday. I take a dim view of a government, any government, attempting to pre-empt proper debate on a substantial measure such as this. What the Government did, by regulation, was to place the Health Insurance Commission into a position in which it entered into arrangements in relation to computers and other facilities to do what it has not been authorised to do by the Parliament of this nation. Regulations were gazetted without, or prior to, consultations or agreements taking place with the unions involved and as I understand it up until this moment agreement has not been reached between the unions concerned and the Government or the Health Insurance Commission.

There is another Health Insurance Commission regulation, No. 152 of 1983, the explanatory notes which are not clear and which I believe the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances will be considering. The reason that I am supporting the disallowance is simply to ensure that the Senate makes a stand , as it is entitled to do, against the attempts made by the Executive Government to stampede proposed legislation and to create a situation which is a fait accompli. I believe that the Senate does have the right and responsibility of audit and control over such Executive decisions and this is one occasion on which we should exercise that audit and control. I support the motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that most of this debate should in fact be held the week after next or whenever the legislation for the introduction of Medicare comes into the Parliament. But unfortunately, at least on the part of the Liberal Party, this debate, which is allegedly just about the disallowance of a regulation, has been extended to incorporate all its objections to Medicare, and in particular its objections to the Health Insurance Commission having the sole right to deal under the Medicare legislation as it is predicted it will. I put it to the Senate that there is the world of difference between the attitude of Senator Harradine and the attitude of Senator Haines who object to the regulation basically because they disagree that the regulation should have been a mechanism used by the Government. They object, although the Government does not agree, to the fact that the Government used this regulation in order to do those things necessary to commence the planning of Medicare, rather than agree with the objections raised by Senator Peter Baume and Senator Walters, who in fact indulged in their usual tirade against the Health Insurance Commission. I think it is worth while looking at the record of the Liberal and National parties in the matter of health insurance in recent years and I think it is worth while, on examining that record, to look at their motives for this disallowance. I must point out that the Government opposes the disallowance of this regulation, first of all because we believe that it was a reasonable and rational way to proceed in this matter and, secondly, because the disallowance is unnecessary and irrelevant in light of the fact that the legislation is before the Parliament.
—Why not just agree and save the debate?

—Because to disallow the regulation at this stage would of course cause considerable inconvenience, albeit for a short time, to the smooth introduction of Medicare. As I said, the Liberal and National parties' record in this matter is a history of blind opposition. In fact, in one of the first votes on the introduction of a health insurance program in this chamber in 1975, I vividly remember Senator Peter Baume, as a result of an exchange that he and I had, saying that the medical profession, whose view he was then putting, would co-operate with anybody, anybody at all, except the Australian Labor Party.
