That is clearly the view of the Liberal Party and the National Party at the moment, not only about the health insurance provisions but also about such things as assets tests, superannuation and everything else. For instance, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) today announced that in government the Opposition would repeal all legislation concerning superannuation and pensions as announced in May and in the recent Budget, even though the legislation is not even before the Parliament. Although the legislation has not been passed it would be repealed, sight unseen, by the Opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind honourable senators that in 1975 in this place the then Opposition, led by Senator Peter Baume at the time-he more or less led the debate on those occasions, even though he had just arrived here-opposed the introduction of a levy to fund Medibank. That Bill was one of the excuses used to cause a double dissolution in 1975. In early 1976 the same people, now in government, introduced that Bill to put down the levy themselves. They completely turned around on that issue. The sorry history of the Liberal and National parties, represented here today by Senator Walters and Senator Peter Baume, has been one of blind obstruction at any opportunity. This motion is typical of that obstruction. The disallowance of this regulation serves no useful purpose, except for those who have Senator Harradine's view and believe that the Senate should exert its powers in this situation to avoid government by the Executive. Senator Peter Baume and Senator Walters gave nothing but a tirade against the Health Insurance Commission and in favour of the voluntary health funds, a cause absolutely consistent with the blind obstructionism in which they have indulged since 1974 and 1975.

It is worth while to look at the record in this area, not only of the Liberal and National parties in opposition but also of the voluntary health funds. In 1975 all private health funds were given the opportunity to act as agents for Medibank and no major fund took up that offer. The Voluntary Health Insurance Association of Australia now says that the reason for that was that 'it believed that the Medibank claims assessing system would be hastily installed, resulting in problems and confusion'. It believed that the funds, being the contact point, would be blamed. The funds now concede that that did not happen. They now concede that Medibank was introduced without major public inconvenience. They concede that they made a mistake. What they are saying is that Medibank is efficient and that under the Medicare system it will be efficient, and they want to be in on it. In those days they did not want a bar of it; now they do. Senator Walters and Senator Baume, knowing very well of the financial and physical support given to them in successive election campaigns by the voluntary health funds, support them as they have done consistently over the years. Senator Baume's arguments are so poor that he has to indulge in a sectarian exchange with Senator Tate. That is pathetic and particularly pathetic coming from Senator Peter Baume.

In 1978 the Liberal Government decided that the Health Insurance Commission could function solely as another private fund. Both Senator Baume and Senator Walters were in this place at that time. Did they care to show any concern then about the effect of that change on Medibank? Did they have much concern about the loss of jobs? The removal of the public function of Medibank, the Health Insurance Commission, left the Commission with 3,000 surplus staff and a computer system owned by the Department of Health which was not appropriate for its future needs. Within 14 months the Health Insurance Commission had developed an on-line processing system that any independent evaluation would agree is at least the equivalent of the best in Australia.

Let us look at the facts. The Health Insurance Commission has had to cope in that time with the gradual rundown of surplus staff numbers after the 1978 changes. Therefore, its staff levels have been unnecessarily high as have its staff costs. That it has been coping, and coping efficiently, is reflected in the fact that its management expenses fell from the 1980-81 figure of 13.5 per cent of income contribution quoted by Senator Walters to 11.3 per cent in 1981- 82 to the 10.1 per cent shown in the Health Insurance Commission report tabled in this Parliament recently. At the same time the management expenses of the other major funds rose from 10.6 per cent in 1980-81 to 10.9 per cent in 1981-82 . The figures are now about the same. While Medibank expenses have been going down, those of the other health funds have been going up.

In her usual manner Senator Walters talked about the $21m that her Government contributed to the Health Insurance Commission. She omitted to say that this year the Commission has already repaid $10m. Over that time the much lauded and praiseworthy funds about which she talked, at various stages and particularly after the early changes, have been carried in part by Medibank carrying some of their debts because of their refusal to accept them. I ask Senator Walters to go back to Tasmania and tell those people who are out of pocket to the extent of $1 ,000 or more, the doctors, the hospitals and the patients who are in strife as a result of the collapse of the Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund, how efficient that fund was and how well protected were its members.

TALK.START.PARA: —She is not listening.

—Senator Walters listens only when she thinks that she is getting the best of the argument. The Liberal and National parties are concerned about what they call the monopoly control of the Health Insurance Commission in the area of Medicare. No one in this community can have been under any illusion about the intentions of the Australian Labor Party in Government. No one can suggest that the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, in his ceaseless endeavours to explain not only to the electorate but also to the doctors, the health insurance funds, the private hospitals, everyone involved in the provision of health care in this country, did not at all times make it clear that the Australian Labor Party in Government would give the Health Insurance Commission the so-called monopoly about which Senator Baume and Senator Walters seem so concerned. In negotiations not only with Senator Haines but also with the voluntary health funds and others in the community he has gone out of his way to ensure that people understood and that modifications could be made to the system which would protect the jobs and the rights of various people involved in the industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We have two sad and sorry representatives of the Liberal Party attacking Dr Blewett and the Health Insurance Commission, which is headed by a leading Australian businessman, a man involved in private enterprise, for largely imaginary defects. They say that the duty of their Party in Opposition is to obstruct at every point along the line. That is an approach typical of an Opposition which has no ideas and which must cover up its own sorry record in this area. When I sat on the other side of the Parliament from 1976 until early this year I was the spokesman for our Party on health in this place. Year after year amendments to the Health Insurance Act were brought in, as were amendments to the National Health Act. Year after year it was claimed that those changes would introduce the brave new world of health insurance in this country, that everything would be satisfactory. It got so silly that newspaper cartoonists used to portray the Minister for Health of the day saying: 'I feel another health insurance system coming on'. It became so silly that I used to get up in this place at the end of each piece of health legislation and finish my speech by saying: 'I will see you all again here next year because this cannot work, it will not work and we will have another series of amendments to the legislation'. More often than not we had amendments twice a year.

Compare that with the situation now. Dr Blewett and the Australian Labor Party have for years spelt out adequately and clearly what we would do in the area of health insurance. This was spelt out to the electorate and to everyone involved so that no one was in any doubt about what would happen. Compare that with the action of Mr Fraser who said: 'Medibank will remain' and then proceeded to destroy it year after year through various incompetent Ministers for Health. As a result of that, if ever a party in this place had a clear mandate to do anything, it is the Australian Labor Party which has a mandate to introduce the Medicare system. There can be no question about that and there can be no question about what the people said in March this year. For that reason we believe that just for once the Opposition should not indulge in the sort of nonsense and hypocrisy it went on with in 1975. It should look at the proposals which have been accepted by the Australian people. It should take the attitude adopted by Senator Haines and say: 'Well, there are things we do not like and which we believe should be modified' and spend an inordinate amount of time consulting with the Minister involved. Perhaps then we would end up with a better and more reasonable system. But to take every excuse, including the disallowance of a regulation, to obstruct the introduction of a fair and equitable health insurance system in this country is, I believe, a travesty of what an opposition should do.

For members of the Opposition to act as they did in 1975-they claim they are not doing that but are trying to disallow this regulation in order to uphold the rights of the Senate-and then proceed to can the Health Insurance Commission, the Minister for Health and everybody else for anything up to 20 or 25 minutes is to confirm Disraeli's description of conservative governments as organised hypocrisy. In this case it is the Opposition and it is disorganised hypocrisy. Therefore I ask the Senate not to accept Senator Baume's motion to disallow the regulation, to accept the fact that the legislation is before the House of Representatives and will shortly be before the Senate and to accept the fact that once that legislation is passed the regulation will become irrelevant anyhow.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 6 September 1983.
Clause 20 (Dissolution of marriage).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not propose to canvass all of the issues that have been canvassed both within the Parliament and outside concerning the need to sustain the institution of marriage. The amendment I have moved, amendment No. 18, is an attempt to give young marriages an opportunity to work. At present young marriages can be dissolved on the ground of separation for 12 months. In my view that is inadequate in any marriage and that will be the subject of a further amendment. It is particularly inadequate in relation to young marriages. As I have indicated previously, the term 'young marriage' includes-marriages involving a person who has been through the divorce court and has remarried. As I mentioned last night, I do not accept viewpoints of lawyers in England who, for one reason or another, have made certain recommendations in this field. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) compared not like with like but like with unlike. I do not accept that.

SPEECH.PARA: I and other persons who are attempting to ensure that reasonable amendments are passed by this Parliament to give genuine legislative support to the institution of marriage find ourselves in a defensive position. The onus of proof should be on the other side because the quite arbitrary decision to define irretrievable breakdown in marriage as 12 months separation is something that was imposed upon the people of Australia by a one-vote majority. No scientific backup or case was put forward for that; it was a quite arbitrary decision. So far as I am concerned the onus of proof is on the other side. The proof is mounting that that quite arbitrary decision was disastrous for marriages in Australia and, therefore, disastrous for the community as a whole. As I said, I do not propose to recanvass all of the issues. I simply hope that in this instance, in this attempt to protect young marriages from breaking up and to establish in the legislation a principle which will enable the people who enter into the contract of marriage time to allow the marriage to work, the Senate will support my amendment and include it in the legislation.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: -I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Page 14, clause 20, leave out the clause, insert the following new clause:
Dissolution of marriage
''20. Section 48 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:
'48. (1) An application under this Act by a party to a marriage for a decree of dissolution of the marriage shall be based on the fact that the marriage has broken down irretrievably.

'(2) In a proceeding instituted by such an application, the fact that the marriage has broken down irretrievably shall be held to have been established if , and only if, it is proved to the reasonable satisfaction of the Court that-
(a) the other party to the marriage has behaved in such a way that the applicant cannot reasonably be expected to live with that party;
(b) since the marriage the other party to the marriage has committed continuing adultery;
(c) the other party to the marriage has wilfully deserted the applicant and left the applicant so deserted for a period of 2 years or more; or

(d) the parties to the marriage have separated and thereafter have lived separately and apart for a continuous period of not less than 2 years immediately preceding the date of the application and there is no reasonable likelihood of cohabitation being resumed, provided that the Court is satisfied that, in all the circumstances, it is not harsh and oppressive to either party or contrary to public policy to grant the relief sought.'.''.
My attitude to marriage is that marriage is a covenant, a commitment for life. Indeed, that is encompassed in the Family Law Act at section 43, which states:

The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

Of course, a large number of people within the community perceive that commitment as being a commitment not only between man and woman but also in the sight of God. But we live in an imperfect world and, as legislators, we must understand that there are varying attitudes. We all have a responsibility to ensure that the common good of the country is maintained. The common good of the country cannot be maintained whilst ever we see the slide that we are seeing now in divorce figures and the consequences of divorce-the legal and economic consequences and the consequences for children.

The position is that in 1982 because of the Family Law Act and the easy divorce provision of that Act-despite the high sounding principles in section 43-there were 44,088 divorces. That is the last year for which figures are available. The children affected by those divorces-that is, children under 18 years of age- numbered more than 53,000. I remind the Senate that the breakdown rate for second marriages has now reached 50 per cent or almost twice the rate for first marriages. That sort of situation causes grave concern to us as legislators. It certainly is causing grave concern amongst the people who elect us. In addition, there is a great deal of anxiety and anguish within the community, a feeling of frustration and a sense of injustice because of the operations of the Family Law Court of Australia. Each member of parliament frequently receives letters expressing this sense of injustice.

We have to come back to the basics-that promises made by the parties to the marriage celebration are solemn, serious and imply mutual good for the parties. Those promises include an undertaking that they will care for each other and so on. If people want a different, impermanent relationship which is inconsistent with the concept of marriage-even that indicated in section 43 of the Act, which refers to the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life-and do not want to undertake such promises, they can of course have a de facto relationship. I certainly do not condone that but it is available to them. If people are not prepared to make the contractual commitments implied by the marriage vows they can enter, as some have, into a sexual relationship which under the law as it now exists does not have the same protection and understanding.

The need is to strengthen marriage, not to so weaken it that there will be no perceived difference in the community outlook and under the law between marriage and de facto sexual cohabitation. I refer honourable senators to the requirement under section 46 of the Marriage Act in relation to what the celebrants of a marriage must say. The Family Law Act provides that the only proof needed of marriage breakdown is that there shall have been a separation for 12 months. The legislation makes it immaterial that one party does not agree, or positively disagrees, that the marriage has broken down. Many of the complaints that have been made come from persons who are in this category. The concept of mutuality and joint promises, the commitment to the optimum ideal of marriage as a voluntary union between a man and a woman for life, to the exclusion of all others, is not upheld by section 48 of the Act. That is why I seek to have that section repealed and replaced by the provision that I have mentioned.

The divorce provisions of the Act are in contradiction to the definition of marriage set out in section 43, which I have described. Section 48 teaches powerfully that marriage, despite the promises made at its inception, can be ended at the will of either party, regardless of the keeping or breaking of those promises, and that either party can apply for and obtain negation of those promises after living apart for 12 months. The party actively breaking promises can apply for divorce. The method of divorce encompassed in the Act changes the perception of the nature of marriage to that of an arrangement terminable at will. The 12 months separation period is too short. While the 12 months separation ground exists and is presented in some quarters as an attractive and easy solution of matrimonial difficulties it will be used although, as I have often said, the problems do not go away. I repeat, remarriage has a 50 per cent failure rate. It is not in the interests of marriage or the family, about which the Act professes great concern, to make the legal dissolution of marriage so easy. Since the inception of the Act it has become increasingly obvious that persons who, under the sanction type legislation of the Matrimonial Causes Act, for example, would never have left their families are doing so in ever increasing numbers. I refer to prominent members of the medical and legal professions, politicians and others who the community might well expect to provide an example of integrity. People are familiar with the concept of sanctions and it is unrealistic to expect the principle to be upheld without individuals knowing and understanding the consequences of their actions.

These concepts are clearly expressed in rules of law relating to a whole host of other matters such as breaking contracts in civil law, offences associated with the abuse of the privilege of driving a motor vehicle-even down to spitting on trains, failing to contain dangerous or nuisance matters on one's property, overhanging trees, careless management of vehicles used for public transport and in most cases where behaviour damages or tends to damage one's neighbours. How can this concept be removed by the legislative pen from marriage and divorce without a negative result to the family, to children and to society? Since the inception of the Act, hundreds of thousands of children have been affected by divorce. The number of such children under the age of 18 years has now reached 400,000. The consensus has been that all children suffer in psyche and stability as a result of divorce. One can divorce a spouse but never one's children. Bearing in mind the nature and purpose of the rules of our society and the importance of stable home life to the welfare of all, I believe there ought to be other ways of proving irretrievable breakdown of marriage than simply that there has been a separation for 12 months.

The previous divorce law, the Matrimonial Causes Act, provided for dissolution of marriage upon proof of one of several objective tests of whether the marriage had broken down. These objective tests were dubbed 'fault' when, in reality, they were tests of behaviour of the parties within the marriage covenant as to whether or not an essential breach of the marriage bond had been committed. If marriage is to be the basis of families and the long term commitment required for the bringing up of children it is reasonable to expect that the implications of the breakdown of such a commitment can and should be tested in an objective way. The reintroduction of an objective test or tests to ensure that the state of irretrievable breakdown of marriage has been established will permit the community interest in the protection of marriage and the family to be best served. An objective test or tests will ensure that only the person complaining of conduct can make application for dissolution of marriage. Also, objective tests for the establishment of irretrievable breakdown will institute an inquiry into the circumstances of the marriage which will greatly facilitate any necessary decisions as regards custody.

There are in my amendment a brief number of these tests. For example, adultery is retained as a test since, in all societies except the most promiscuous, a continuous adulterous relationship is regarded as a fundamental breach of the marital consensus, which is substantially based upon a sexual relationship. ( Extension of time granted) It also seems desirable to retain, as an objective test of the fact of irretrievable breakdown, a lengthy period of separation subject to a wide discretion in the court that after consideration of all of the circumstances it is not harsh and oppressive to either party or contrary to public policy to grant the decree. I submit that we have come to the stage where we must put this question to the test. It needs to be put to the test. Many people in the community are crying out for something to be done. There is a great sense of injustice particularly on the part of those people who do not want to see the marriage break up and I believe now is the time to put that matter to the test and for us to stand up and be counted upon it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The removal of the concept of fault from the grounds for divorce, which Senator Harradine now seeks to turn around, was of course exhaustively debated in 1975. The view which prevailed in 1975, after that very extensive debate, was that fault ought to be removed from the dissolution decision, freeing the court to concentrate on being satisfied as to the fact of irretrievable marriage breakdown and on deciding the most equitable distribution of property, the proper level of maintenance and, of overwhelming importance, the best possible arrangements for the welfare of any children of the marriage. The approach which prevailed to enable the court to focus on those matters and not to be diverted by considerations of fault has come to be accepted almost universally in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: Of all the achievements wrought by the Family Law Act in 1975-in many ways revolutionary achievements-the removal of the concept of fault I believe has been the best understood of those changes and the most universally accepted. In endeavouring to recreate in many ways the situation which prevailed before that 1975 legislation, Senator Harradine is trying to flog life back into a horse which is very dead indeed. The demonstration of just how dead that horse is is the condition of the benches, particularly on the Government side but on the Opposition side as well, in the course of this debate. People do not regard this any longer as being a real issue, though they are concerned about many aspects of the way in which the Family Law Act is operating and are concerned to ensure that the operation of the Act is improved. In opposing Senator Harradine's amendment, I speak not for the Government but for myself because, as I indicated yesterday, this is one of those clauses on which the Government has decided to allow a free vote so far as its members are concerned-as it will in relation to all the other matters we are to debate which it can be argued do raise moral considerations or questions going to the preservation of the institution of marriage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why limit it?
—I acknowledge the howl of pain from Senator Missen.
—Who makes the judgment?

—It has been the subject of debate in the party room and I do not want to get again into the internal affairs of the Australian Labor Party , which I do not think would be of any interest to anyone but members of the Labor Party. In respect of the major matters in which it is clear that strong moral views are held, we readily accept that it is appropriate that there be an untied vote. This is one of those matters. I simply make that point. I believe that my views in this respect, although others may choose to speak for themselves, are in fact reflective of those of my Party and indeed are reflective of the overwhelming sentiment in the community at large.

SPEECH.PARA: Many points could be made about Senator Harradine's proposal, and no doubt Senator Missen and others who participated in the work of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act will make them. The only particular point I wish to emphasise is that there is a fundamental inconsistency in the particular proposal that Senator Harradine has put before us. So far from making it more difficult for parties to an unsatisfactory marriage to obtain a divorce and going in that way to preserve marriages from too quick or too unthinking a dissolution, which is one of the stated objectives of Senator Harradine's amendment, I believe his proposal will have the reverse effect. It can be very strongly argued, as it was argued by the Joint Select Committee, that to introduce now the grounds that Senator Harradine proposes-the fault grounds plus the extended period of separation that he would require-would increase the probability of instant divorce being sought and obtained. There is real encouragement provided to spouses who wish to contrive one of the fault grounds- adultery is the usual candidate in this respect-to obtain the instant divorce that many of them would prefer.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is continuing adultery, and in your own words it would not get on before the court for 18 months, anyhow.
—I did not say it would not get on for 18 months.
—That is what you were saying the other day about contested cases.

—That is in relation to property matters, not default grounds where there is consent by the parties concerned. I have quoted before, much to Senator Harradine's disgust, the United Kingdom Law Society report of 1979, entitled 'A Better Way Out'. He is not appreciative of the efforts of lawyers at all in this respect, least of all United Kingdom ones. Nonetheless, a major report devoted to these particular matters has been prepared of recent times. It was noted that only a very small percentage of undefended divorce petitions were based on the ground of two years separation with consent, which is the closest approximate ground that I can see to the Harradine amendment. What has happened is that there has been a much greater reliance on the fault grounds rather than people being prepared to wait out that period of two years' separation which Senator Harradine would provide for, among other considerations . The particular point that was made very vigorously by the Joint Select Committee was that the combination of the availability of an immediate fault ground plus a longer separation period in fact will be likely to result in many parties colluding to obtain a fault divorce, which is the very antithesis of what I take it Senator Harradine wants to achieve with this amendment.
—But the situation in the UK is that either party can apply.
—Yes.
—Well, that is not the situation that I am proposing here.

—I am not sure that that undermines, anyway, the force of the point I am making. It would still be possible if the grounds proposed by Senator Harradine were to go into the Act for the parties to join together to obtain by collusive means a divorce rather more quickly than they can obtain a divorce at the moment. I do not understand the honourable senator's basic thrust .
—With consequence to property and custody matters?

—No, I am not saying consequential matters will be able to be resolved in any shorter time frame than they are at the moment but the divorce which would enable the parties to be free of the formal shackles of marriage and enter into new matrimonial relations, which is the very thing Senator Harradine wants to dissuade people from doing without a long period of careful reflection about what they are doing, seems to me to be unlikely to be achieved; in fact, the contrary will occur because of the particular combination of grounds which he would make available to the parties.
—That is not so.

—The point can be made later on in the debate by other speakers. It is not a ground that I wish to track over in any enormous detail because there have been very lengthy debates on this whole subject matter, including the implications of the kinds of fault grounds, the combinations of fault grounds and the larger questions of philosophical principles that are involved here. All of these matters were exhaustively debated in this Parliament in 1975 and in the context of the review by the Joint Select Committee. I simply do not believe that the kinds of propositions advanced by Senator Harradine and others who share his views in this place will attract in any way a responsive chord in the great majority of people in the community at large. It is for those reasons that I believe the proposal ought to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to oppose Senator Harradine's amendment and other amendments that seek to change the grounds for divorce in the Act which has operated since 1975. Apparently the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has given papal dispensation on certain moral grounds to various votings for or against Senator Walters's amendments and I think some of Senator Harradine's amendments. I happen to have a strong moral principle in favour of effective and useful legislation and an effective and useful Family Court of Australia. I intend to move amendments on this.
—What is that?

—My moral principle is that we ought to be doing what we can to make an effective operation here. I cannot see anything other than nonsense in the idea that in this place we should distinguish between amendments based upon some conscience grounds. My conscience is strong. I am in favour of amendments, particularly ones that have been examined at length by joint committees. I hope that members of the Australian Labor Party will seek their conscience rights, if that is what they have to do to carry out this nonsense, so that they can vote for such amendments and make proper use of the facilities of the country to obtain the best provisions that we can for family law. However, that is a problem for the Labor Party members, and most of them are not present in the chamber. I wish they were showing a greater interest in this debate. Senator Harradine's amendment is based upon his own concept--
—To be fair, there are not many Liberals either.
—I agree with that. There are very few Liberal members present and the National Party of Australia is very poorly represented also.
—Fifty per cent.

—I am sorry; I have done it an injustice. Two members of the National Party are here. I think it is disappointing that so few members are here. They may be called on later to vote in divisions on some of these matters; but perhaps they are listening to this debate.
—Order! I ask Senator Missen to return to clause 20.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, thank you for reminding me. Clause 20 is the important aspect of this matter. Senator Harradine bases the amendment upon his principles, which are that marriage is a covenant for life. I agree with that. It happens to be my belief as well. But it is not one that a lot of people have been able to undergo because of the very unfortunate situations in which they have found themselves over the years. Their lives have become a misery and to force them to stay in marriage with another party would be disgraceful. Before I became a member of this Parliament I practised extensively in this jurisdiction, and I saw the nonsense that had to go on regarding proof of evidence. It fills me with horror that Senator Harradine is trying to revive that monstrous system. Senator Harradine says that it is based on section 43 of the Act. He makes the same mistake as our former colleague, Senator Martyr, kept making; that is, that section 43 of the Family Law Act is a definition of marriage. Marriage and the obligations of marriage are defined in the Marriage Act, not in the Family Law Act. Section 43, as its side heading shows, contains the principles to be applied by the courts in connection with actions under the Family Law Act. Members of Parliament in 1974 wanted to state those principles and they were inserted as a guide to the Court. Section 43 is not a definition of marriage and it does not say that marriages are only those that preserve a union of man and woman for life.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the amendment is concerned, I take further the point Senator Gareth Evans made. Under the proposed amendment we would probably have quicker divorces and less time would be spent in trying to reconcile the parties, if possible, or to conciliate where it is not possible to bring them together. At the moment the Court must have objective proof of 12 months separation. That has to have happened. Senator Harradine's amendment would take away that requirement. Parties would be able to get divorced at a very early stage. They could prove that the marriage had broken down irretrievably by showing a number of things. Desertion rears its ugly head again, but in this case it is called 'wilful desertion', and a period of two years is specified. That would take the parties a while to prove. Who knows what wilful desertion will be? That is a different thing altogether. Then, continuing adultery is put forward as one of the possible ways of proving breakdown. What on earth is continuing adultery?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what it means?

—I do not know what it means. By the sound of it, it means being regular in one's habits and constantly committing adultery. I do not know what it means. I will have to bow to other senators' greater knowledge of this subject, from a practical point of view. In the old Act there was a reference to a repeated act of adultery. I think that under that ground wives could divorce their husbands only if they could show a repeated act of adultery on the part of the husband.
—That is going back a long way.

—It is going back a bit, but that was the law up until 1959. Turning it the other way round, the husband could divorce his wife for one single act of adultery. I can understand repeated acts, but I cannot understand continuing adultery. I do not know to what extent one would be able to do that. Presumably that would show up in a few circumstances.
—How many hours a day, would you say?
—I do not intend to follow Senator Chipp down this murky path.
—It is not murky; it is delightful.

—Everyone to his own delights. Senator Harradine's amendment specifies a period of separation of not less than two years. It was attempted to include the same provision in the Act in 1974 but it was knocked out by the Parliament. In this case, the Court would have to be satisfied that it was not harsh and oppressive to either party or contrary to public policy to grant the relief sought. That would be very difficult. One can see in those proposals the complete restoration of all the rottenness of the fault grounds as we had them. When the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act referred to these arguments it put the argument for retaining the present grounds in this way, which I think is well said:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for reform of the law of divorce was established at the time of introduction of the reform and the indignities, hypocrisies, expenses and delays associated with the old system based on grounds were notorious and that a return to such a system in whole or in part would be a social disaster.

I say hear, hear, to that. All the attempts that Senator Harradine has been making elsewhere to use more conciliation, to try bringing the parties together and so forth, would be defeated by such an amendment. All these matters were considered by the Joint Committee, which did not recommend any proposals such as these. It is interesting that these additional means of proof are basically the law in England at present, and England wants to change that law and follow Australia's more modern law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told you that?
—The honourable senator could not have been listening. That was the evidence before our Committee.
—What? A bunch of lawyers?

—They are not a bunch of lawyers. A number of people who were very specialised in the social welfare area and people who had experience in the Court in all kinds of ways, not just lawyers, appeared before the Joint Committee. Just because some lawyers were involved does not mean they did not know what they were talking about. The 1971 English law abolished the old grounds for divorce and replaced them with irretrievable breakdown, but that can be established only by proving one of five facts set out in the Act. Three of them were akin but not identical to the old grounds of adultery, cruelty and desertion and, therefore, imputed fault to the respondent. The other two dealt with periods of separation. For heavens sake, surely we do not intend to go back to what is soon to be abandoned, I hope, in England, because that has proved to be a quite unsuccessful way of handling it. To bring back into this Act the fault grounds, to bring back the bitterness and hatred, the old inquiry agents and others who were needed to prove these things--
—It was awful.

—As my colleague says, it was an awful procedure. It was degrading for the parties and for everybody concerned. I leave the matter there. I trust that we will have no part of this amendment or others of this sort.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In voting on this amendment I will be acting in pursuance of my own conscientiously determined position and not in accordance with any attempt-not that there was any attempt-to bind my vote by the Parliamentary Labor Party. Senator Harradine's amendment raises very squarely the question of the ground upon which this Committee should permit society to recognise that a validly married couple have come to the end of their partnership in life, that it has disintegrated to such a degree that a dissolution of the marriage ought to be formally acknowledged by society. I indicate to the Committee that I do not support Senator Harradine's attempt to introduce a further list of criteria, with echoes of the old fault system, into the description of the grounds for divorce presently provided for. I do so for a primary reason, and I bolster that reason with some memories of the realities of the past which have just been adverted to in the remarks between Senator Missen and Senator Hill.

SPEECH.PARA: My primary reason is that Senator Harradine's reintroducing of a list of grounds, with echoes of the old fault system, tends to mislead the Australian community as to the causes of the breakdown of marriage in our society. I offer the Senate the following quotation from a book which I looked at last night in the Parliamentary Library. Under the heading 'Marital Disorganisation' it states :
The vast changes brought about by industralization create problems that married couples are not always well prepared to face.
There is a contrast between industrialised society and the more stable societies of agriculturally based communities. It continues:

The causes of marital disorganization and divorce are difficult to determine, and it is certain that there is no single simple cause. The legal grounds for divorce are of little real value for understanding the causes; and such often- mentioned factors as drinking, desertion, or adultery hide more basic factors that have caused both the undesirable behaviour and the divorce . . .

That article puts the disintegration of marriage, which is of alarming proportions, into the context of the unstable industrialised society in which we live. The book I quoted from is the New Catholic Encyclopaedia. That is hardly a journal of trendy left wing opinion. It is a sober assessment by the authors of that article on marriage of the causes of disintegration. As I said, they indicate that it is not easy to equate the old fault system with an idenfication of the causes of dissolution of marriage. Indeed, this is the same conclusion as was reached by the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act entitled 'Family Law in Australia'.

My basic position is that marriage and its dissolution occur quite apart from a social, formal recognition of the fact, whether it be of the marriage or of the dissolution. Both at common law and at canon law it is not absolutely juridically necessary for there to be witnesses or for there to be any sort of formal, social recognition of the fact of marriage. Of course, that is the normal situation. But if two people cohabit with the intention of a life-long partnership and they cannot have witnesses present to their pledging of that life-long partnership nevertheless a marriage exists. As I said, public ratification, a ceremony or a ritual, are not necessary to the existence of the marriage. It is exactly the same in relation to the dissolution or disintegration of the marriage. My point is that marriages disintegrate, dissolve or fall apart, quite apart from the social recognition or public acknowledgment of that fact.

It is true that society generally, and the parties indeed, have an interest in the formal recognition of that disintegration of the partnership because there are consequences that have to be dealt with whether in relation to the custody of children, property settlements, the concessions which society makes to a married relationship in taxation laws and so on. Of course, the law of bigamy has to be kept in mind because frequently, the former partners of a marriage wish to enter into a new cohabiting partnership and they wish for that to take place within a marriage situation. For all those reasons society has an interest in publicly ratifying, recognising or acknowledging that the disintegration or dissolution of the marriage has occurred. But my point is that the sole, proper interest of society is to determine whether that disintegration or dissolution of the partnership has indeed occurred. It is not proper to the wider Australian society, even if it is possible to establish it, to try to delve into the supposed or presumed causes-the symbolic activities which are said to underly the dissolution of the marriage. There may be forums in which that ought to occur. But I do not believe that it is the proper function of the Family Court of Australia to delve into those supposed causes.

Further, the reason why I feel obliged to oppose the re-introduction of the list of criteria put by Senator Harradine is that anybody who has sat in the divorce courts, as I did as an articled clerk, and listened to the embarrassment , the humiliation, the bitterness, the exaggeration, the conniving and the collusion between the parties in relation to the setting up of the fault ground would not want to see a rekindling of that traumatic atmosphere. I think it is very significant indeed that those with the most knowledge of how family courts actually operate and operated are the ones who are so strongly in favour of the present system as opposed to that which operated in the past. It is significant that the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act at paragraph 3.30 of its report states:

The changes implemented in 1975 are supported by many submissions that the Committee has received. In particular they receive the support of organisations representing those most involved in the administration of the law, such as the Judges of the Family Court, the Family Law Advisory Committee of the Law Council of Australia, marriage guidance and counselling agencies, Councils of Social Services and other community bodies.

In other words, those most involved and with the best memories of how the old system worked are those who are most adamant that those embers of all that traumatic bitterness ought not be rekindled. I believe that if Senator Harradine 's proposals were accepted by the Parliament, those embers would be rekindled.

Let us consider some of the grounds put forward in Senator Harradine's amendment. One is to permit dissolution if it is proved to the reasonable satisfaction of the Court that the other party to the marriage has behaved in such a way that the applicant cannot reasonably be expected to live with the party. I imagine that this would cover situations of cruelty, alcohol or drug- induced intoxication, refusal to consummate the marriage or engaging in crime. But those are only some of the instances which flash before the imagination as activities which might satisfy this very vague criterion. It is exceedingly difficult to circumscribe or describe what might fall within that ground. I think it ought to be rejected on the grounds of that very failure to be specific , that vagueness which attends it. Then there is the alternative ground--

TALK.START.PARA: —It is forcing a subjective judgment on the Court, too.

—It is forcing the Court to try to come to a judgment in relation to criteria which are extremely vague and not circumscribed at all. But there is one criterion that is perhaps more particular and that is that a marriage may be dissolved if it is reasonably demonstrated that since the marriage the other party to the marriage has committed continuing adultery. This must be taken to speak of separate acts of adultery, unless it is attributed to stamina or something, but there is no indication of how many acts of adultery should be taken to constitute continuing adultery or how frequent or how related those acts should be. In any case, why ignore a single act of adultery if the party committing that single act of adultery attaches the significance to it that it is a demonstration, a symbol or a final indication that the marriage partnership , as far as he or she is concerned, is at an end. A single act of adultery can be as dramatic an indication of the dissolution of the marriage as a continuing series. Indeed, it may have more significance than perhaps frequent acts of adultery with very casual partners to which no significance is attached by the party indulging in them. For those reasons, looking even at the detail of the amendment proposed by Senator Harradine, I cannot support it because of its vagueness and because, more fundamentally, it is misleading as to the true causes of disintegration of marriage within Australian society.

SPEECH.PARA: The present law, which I support, provides that in effect substantial disruption of the marriage relationship must have occurred for at least 12 months before the filing of the application for dissolution. For completeness I will read in full the wording of the section which I continue to support:
48. (1) An application under this Act by a party to a marriage for a decree of dissolution of the marriage shall be based on the ground that the marriage has broken down irretrievably.

(2) Subject to sub-section (3), in a proceeding instituted by such an application, the ground shall be held to have been established, and a decree of dissolution of the marriage shall be made, if, and only if, the court is satisfied that the parties separated and thereafter lived separately and apart for a continuous period of not less than 12 months immediately preceding the date of the filing of the application for dissolution of marriage.
(3) A decree of dissolution of marriage shall not be made if the court is satisfied that there is a reasonable likelihood of cohabitation being resumed.
That section is one which in conscience I can support, and do support by rejecting Senator Harradine's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly on Senator Harradine's amendment. I do not support it because its intention is to reintroduce fault as a ground for divorce. Any divorce law must present problems for people who believe in marriage as a union for life to the exclusion of all others. As Senator Harradine has pointed out, the Family Law Act in fact defines marriage in this traditional way. Yet it has proved itself able to operate in such a way that the divorce rate has greatly increased. There is widespread concern that since 1975 the Family Law Act may have contributed to that situation. Nevetheless, as legislators we are bound to provide adequate, workable and fair laws for the community for whom we legislate. It is not proper for those of us who may not believe in divorce to impose our moral views on the community as a whole, which I think probably vastly disagrees with such views.

SPEECH.PARA: The great feature of the Family Law Act 1975 was to do away with the fault concept. In many countries with societies that are largely cohesive in their moral attitudes towards divorce, divorce is not permitted. That is probably the only logical position. But, as I have said, that is not the situation in our community and as legislators we have to have regard to the widespread community support for a divorce law. In that case the best approach is to try to find a basis for that law which is as fair and workable as possible and also one which has regard to the great personal sensitivities that arise in this area.

There is no doubt that the old fault basis of divorce and the proceedings based on fault offended people who were engaged in them. It offended the lawyers who had to act for people in such cases, particularly when they involved cruelty. The type of conflict that developed between parties in such cases was most depressing. People criticised the fault ground based on adultery because it involved private inquiry agents, snooping and all that sort of thing. But I think probably the criticism of the fault ground would be better directed to the areas of cruelty and constructive desertion, as they were known. Certainly, the first limb of Senator Harradine's amendment would reintroduce all those sorts of disputes.

Although it was a major social and legal experiment, and certainly needs to be closely monitored, the central feature of abolition of fault in the Family Law Act should be preserved. As I have said, there are growing concerns in the community about machinery aspects of the Act. Nevertheless, I would be very reluctant indeed to come to the conclusion that the reintroduction of fault as such as the ground for divorce is required. I certainly do not believe that the experience that we have had with the Act, in both a legal and a social sense, would justify that. I am fortified in that view by the findings of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act, which Committee was set up as a consequence of my motion when I was Attorney-General. I had in mind that that Committee should give close consideration to the question of grounds for divorce . That Committee reported to the Parliament in favour of, although not unanimously in favour of, the retention of the central feature of the Act, the no fault ground.

For those reasons I oppose this amendment. However, I am attracted, as I always have been, to a longer period of separation as the single no-fault ground for divorce. I believe that a one-year separation is too short a time for people really to determine whether a marriage has irretrievably broken down. Secondly, I believe-this is borne out by the experience we have had of the Act-that the easy availability of divorce as a result of only one year's separation does not place on parties to marriage sufficient inducement seriously to face their responsibilities to each other and to their children, and I emphasise to each other as well as to the children. What is really required to be built into the legislation are road blocks which will make people wake up to themselves and to their responsibilities. When the original Bill was introduced into the Senate in 1974 I moved an amendment to provide for a 2-year separation. Nothing that I have seen or heard since then has made me qualify that view, which I still hold. I have indicated a simple amendment along those lines to provide for two years separation instead of one year. That will be debated separately. The only aspect of Senators Harradine's amendment which would attract my support is the fourth limb, although I believe it introduces considerations which go too far and I could not support it as it stands. However, I certainly do support Senator Harradine in his efforts to require people, by our legislation, to have regard to their very great responsibilities when they enter into a matrimonial relationship.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly to this amendment. I am sympathetic with what Senator Durack has been saying and the principles he has set out in regard to marriage and the standards that he would seek to achieve concerning the dissolution of marriage but I am not convinced about his foreshadowed amendment. Whilst I am sympathetic with many of the statements that Senator Harradine made in his speech I do not support his amendment. Senator Harradine's amendment goes to the heart of the Family Law Act. It relates to the vital clause that sets out the grounds for the Family Court to regard a marriage as irretrievably broken down and so subject to dissolution. The four grounds which Senator Harradine's amendment would intrude in place of the one universal ground at present in the Act would, unfortunately, bring back a subjective set of judgments to the Family Court in such proceedings and would bring back an assessment of fault.

SPEECH.PARA: The principle in the Family Law Act that was achieved in 1975 was the exclusion of consideration of fault in marriage breakdown. Marriage was seen as a commitment by two people sincerely and genuinely intending that commitment to be lifelong and permanent. I think all of us who have spoken, not least Senator Harradine, Senator Durack and myself, very much want to emphasise that marriage is a lifelong commitment, is permanent and is intended to be shored up, supported and safeguarded by this legislation and by all that we may say in this debate. The arguments that were put forward at the time of the passing of the Family Law Act by the Parliament, the experience since and the express evidence given to the parliamentary inquiry about the exclusion of fault as a ground for dissolution all point to the same conclusion, and that is that the public of Australia now accept-they accepted it at the time of the establishment of the Act-that the Family Law Act is an appropriate way of defining the grounds for dissolution of a marriage.

Therefore I cannot support those parts of Senator Harradine's amendment that would bring fault back into the Family Law Act. Nevertheless, I am sympathetic with those involved in a marriage relationship who suffer the consequences of behaviour which is such that the applicant cannot reasonably be expected to live with the other party. I am also sympathetic with a partner who is subject to the relationship being in jeopardy or broken because of adultery. I recognise and support what Senator Gareth Evans has stated about the difficulty of interpreting what continuing adultery means or even the lack of clarity about the word 'behaviour' in proposed new sub-clause 48 (2) (a), and whether it relates to cruelty, criminality or other offensive behaviour that would lead a court to consider it being reasonable for the marriage to be dissolved. The point I make is that there is still a remedy for this behaviour or this adultery in the section in the Family Law Act which presently provides for separation. Together with State laws to inhibit or to prevent assault, there are remedies for a partner to a marriage. They can gain relief from offensive behaviour and ensure separation in the face of adultery.

I recognise what I understand to be Senator Harradine's intentions with regard to the phrase 'continuing adultery'. An adulterous act may lead to pressure upon a marriage relationship, but that act should not then be taken as a weapon with which to bash the head of a partner. It still ought to be recognised in this chamber that reconciliation can be achieved if there is a willingness on the part of both partners to come to terms with what may have happened and to be genuinely reconciled to each other. Great weight is still placed by many in this chamber and in the community on forgiveness, repentance and reconciliation-on coming together again. So I do understand Senator Harradine's intention in distinguishing between an adulterous act on the one hand and continuing adultery on the other. In lawyers' terms there is difficulty in exact interpretation. I am sympathetic with the situation that Senator Harradine seeks to address himself to but I do not support those parts of his amendment that seek a remedy in this way.

Paragraphs (c) and (d) of proposed new section 48 (2) relate to desertion and to continuous separation for a period of two years. I regard these as tantamount to the present provision in the Family Law Act. Both matters can be covered by continuous separation but with one change, and that is that there be a two-year period instead of one. I do not support a two-year period as a ground for dissolution of marriage despite the fact that in 1975, at the time of the debate -which I followed closely, although not in this chamber-I would have been one who voted for the two-year period and not for the 12-month period. The difference in the vote in the House of Representatives at that time was only one . I believe it is appropriate for those who still conscientiously seek to achieve that two-year period to put that amendment forward here and to test it in the arguments in this chamber. However, whilst I supported a two-year period in 1975, experience and the testimony to the parliamentary inquiry as well as my own conversations with many in the community have led me to accept the provisions now in the Act. For these reasons, whilst very much being amongst those who wish to reinforce marriage as a permanent and lifelong relationship, as the basic relationship for all of our society, I am not moved by the arguments of Senator Harradine nor by my colleague Senator Durack with regard to any of these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: — My amendment has been characterised by Senator Tate and the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, in a totally unacceptable manner. Neither of them attempted to give to this amendment the consideration which I believe is due to it. Senator Tate said of the amendment, or said of me that in putting this amendment forward, I am tending to mislead the general public as to the causes of the disintegration of marriage and of marriage breakdown. That is absolute nonsense. I do not consider, of course, that the provisions in the legislation are the essential causes of marital breakdown. Quite obviously they are not and for Senator Tate to talk like that is arrant nonsense. He had opportunities, both last year and this year, prior to this debate coming forward, to enter into discussions with those who were interested in having inserted into the legislation some genuine support for the institution of marriage and he can do so in the future. He did not do so on the most recent occasion. So I take exception to the characterisation of this amendment by Senator Tate in that manner. Quite obviously the statement that he quoted has merit but it has nothing to do with the debate in hand. In the legislation at the moment there is a provision which entitles the court simply to administer the law without proper inquiry if an application is made and that application is based on irretrievable breakdown as defined, that is to say, separation for 12 months.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague has said that that unilateral decision came about on the vote of one person in the House of Representatives in 1975. The onus now is on those who supported it and who continue to support it to do something about the consequences of that decision, because the consequences of that decision are that there are an increasing number of divorces. The marital breakdown is not caused by the provisions in the legislation but, for the dissolution to take place, then the provisions in the legislation are all important. The question of a test of irretrievable breakdown is very important in that context. What the legislation is saying to anybody is that if there is separation for 12 months, even though that separation might occur as a result of circumstances quite outside the marriage-the person concerned may be in the Army serving overseas or somewhere else-that is irretrievable breakdown. That is the test that is applied .
Progress reported.
Sitting suspended from 12.46 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it a fact that, as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald today, Mr Phillip Adams is to be appointed Chairman of the Australian Film Commission? Is it a fact that Mr Adams was consulted by the Government on the changes to taxation arrangements and Australian Film Commission funding announced in last week's Budget, which will mean that the AFC will have a strong influence on the content of future Australian films? Was the Government considering appointing Mr Adams to this position at the time it took these decisions? Is the Minister aware of Mr Adams's views on what constitutes a 'high quality film', the words used by the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment in his statement to the House of Representatives last week? Do Mr Adams's views on this subject coincide with the Minister's views?

—I have not seen the article to which Senator Martin's question refers. At this stage I have no knowledge of the intentions of the Government with regard to the new Chairman of the Australian Film Commission, nor do I know of any consultation which has taken place between the Government and Mr Adams on the matter of changes to the film tax legislation. However, I will relay Senator Martin's queries to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and make sure that she gets an answer to them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Is the Minister aware of a publication called the Small Business Letter which offers, for a $68 subscription, 250 more ways to cut tax including:

QUESTION.PARA: How to receive up to one-third of your salary tax-free.
Three dozen ways to receive tax-free fringe benefits.
How to legally make tax-free money from real estate.
17 steps to survive an income tax investigation.

It also mentioned other equally dubious tax dodges. Can the Minister indicate what action can be taken with regard to this publication, which appears to be blatantly challenging the legitimate tax measures of this country?

TALK.START.PARA: —The publication entitled the Small Business Letter is a mixture of information and advice of a factual nature about the taxation legislation and what is written into it and of handy hints on how to evade tax-handy hints, I suspect, of highly variable quality. For example, in a recent issue the Small Business Letter claimed to show how to circumvent the new tax arrangements for lump sum superannuation payments before the enabling legislation had been introduced, which is a pertinent comment on the intellectual integrity of the people who produce that publication.
—Uncanny anticipation!

—Or an example of their uncanny perspicacity. It must certainly be regarded as an anti-social publication because if the information contained in it on how to dodge income tax is effective, it is obviously anti-social. On the other hand, if it is not effective, it is a publication put together by charlatans who aim to exploit gullible would-be tax evaders. I think the best response by the Government to publications such as the Small Business Letter is a continuation of the crackdown on the tax avoidance and tax evasion industries. That is a matter which this Government is pursuing. Unlike the previous Government, we will pursue it without fear or favour and legislation in pursuit of that objective will be debated in the Senate, certainly in this Budget session and possibly during the current sittings of the Parliament. There will then be an opportunity for all non-Government senators to show whether they are serious about cracking down on tax evasion and tax evaders.

—I direct a question to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Will the Federal Government be allowing the mining of uranium at Roxby Downs in South Australia? If so, is this because of deposits of minerals other than uranium at that site? Considering the large deposits of gold at the Jabiluka site in the Northern Territory, will the Government allow mining of uranium and gold at that site? If not, what is the difference between mining at Jabiluka and mining at Roxby Downs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister was yesterday asked in the House of Representatives a question which referred to this matter, amongst others. With respect to Roxby Downs, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: In the context of this policy on existing mines-and Roxby Downs-the Government is currently undertaking a review of all aspects of the industry, including the international safeguards aspects.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what he said to the BRW.

—I could incorporate the whole answer, but I think it is just as easy for Senator Kilgariff to read it. The second question Senator Kilgariff raised refers, although he did not use the term, to clause 64C of the Labor Party platform, which speaks of a situation in which uranium is mined incidentally to the production of other minerals. In the case of Jabiluka there are significant quantities of gold in the deposit but, from memory, they would represent less than 10 per cent, at present market prices, of the output of a mine if commenced there whereas, on the forecast production levels of the company involved at Roxby Downs-Western Mining Corporation Ltd-just above 60 per cent of the market value, at present prices, of the envisaged production relates to minerals other then uranium-a mixture of gold, silver and copper.
—Is 40 per cent incidental?

—It is incidental in that it is a minority. But the point I was really making, Senator Macklin, is that uranium comprises-I do not want to be held precisely to this figure-above 90 per cent of the value of the potential output from Jabiluka and something less than 40 per cent, at present prices, of the potential output from Roxby Downs, as projected by the producers. Therefore, there is a very significant difference in the relative importance of the minerals concerned.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has he seen reports to the effect that the Opposition intends to repeal all of Labor's legislation on assets tests and on lump sum superannuation payments? Does the Minister believe that this will in any way help pensioners, apart from the few who have considerable assets? How does the Opposition's call for a needs -based income security system, as espoused by Senator Messner, fit in with his statement a few weeks ago that all age pensioners, regardless of income and assets, should receive fringe benefits at an estimated cost of around $190m?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, my attention has been drawn to a Press statement put out today by the Leader of the Opposition, in which he gave an undertaking that the Opposition, on return to government, would repeal all of Labor's legislation in this area. This includes any legislation on the assets test, the taxation of lump sum superannuation payments and the means test introduced for those aged over 70 years. First, I find this an extraordinary statement, coming from a party that has just gone into opposition, even bearing in mind the fact that it is led by Mr Peacock. The Opposition has not seen most of that legislation. The legislation on an assets test has not been finalised as we are consulting with the various pensioner groups. I find it extraordinary that, sight unseen, the Opposition would give an undertaking to repeal all of this in any case.

ANSWER.PARA: Secondly, I find it an extraordinary statement in view of the fact that Senator Messner himself has admitted that the Opposition has no comprehensive retirement policy but is to develop one. That is not bad for a party that has been in office for the last seven years! In promising to repeal these provisions, Mr Peacock is pre-empting the development of that comprehensive policy. It means that that policy cannot include an assets test, a rational treatment of taxation of lump sum superannuation payments or the present income test for pensioners over 70 years of age.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you say that?

—What an extraordinary attitude for a party that considers itself an alternative government. I have been asked why I say that. If the honourable senator listens to the recording of the radio program in which Senator Messner and I participated at lunchtime he will find that is exactly what it is all about. The Opposition has not told us what it will do when it repeals the legislation, removing some $300m from the revenue in one case, considerably more in the case of lump sum superannuation, and $170m in the case of people over 70 years of age. Will it raise taxes, will it get money from other sources, or will it do what it did for the last seven years and for the 23 years before 1972, that is, allow the base rate of pensions and assistance to pensioners to fall year after year, so that in the end pensioners and beneficiaries are as hard up as they have been after each of the Opposition's previous sessions in government ? It is absolutely irresponsible of the Leader of the Opposition to announce that his Party will repeal legislation which has not been passed and which it has not seen, to announce that it has no comprehensive policy but will develop one and to announce that it will tie its own hands in restricting policy development in this area by these means. Of course members of the Opposition are not fair dinkum and no one believes they are fair dinkum.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Messner today announced that what the Opposition is really about is a needs-based retirement policy. In the last couple of weeks he has announced that the solution to many of the pensioners' problems is to provide free of means test-without any income test, assets test or anything else-all the fringe benefits for those people above 65 years of age. If we want something which is inconsistent with a needs-based policy, that is it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—Senator Chaney, as an ex-Minister, knows that is it. I suggest that Mr Peacock do what the pensioners' organisations and other parties are doing, and that is sit down and actually look at the Government's proposals. If the Opposition wishes, it can even enter into the consultations about those proposals, but it should not pre-empt policies for itself in this way.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security to confirm that the Government has announced that under its assets test single or married pensioners will be able to have unlimited stocks of antiques, jewellery or paintings and be exempt from the test but that, if they have money in the bank, only $1,500 for a single person and $2,500 for married persons will be exempt? Does the Minister agree that it is sophisticated investors who invest in these exempt forms of investment and that ordinary average Australians usually rely on traditional forms of savings? If so, why are these traditional forms of cash or near cash savings being discriminated against? On what basis of fairness does the Minister support the exemption of antiques, jewellery, paintings, caravans and boats as against the savings which represent the main assets of most pensioners?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Chaney for his question. It is typical of the sorts of nitpicking matters that Senator Chaney and others raise. Senator Chaney spent several years as Minister for Social Security desperately trying to do something about those who circumvent the income test. He actually announced in a Budget measure two years ago that he would do something. One of the things he was going to do was to limit pensioners to holding $3,000 in a cheque account. That was the best he could come up with. After questioning from the then Opposition he eventually had to admit that his Government was not going to do it . Senator Chaney and everyone else here knows that some pensioners have very expensive houses on which they have to pay very high rates, et cetera, and antiques and pictures on the wall of the sort he is talking about, but they cannot eat them and they cannot dress in them. They are able to receive a pension because besides their own home and personal possessions they have considerable other assets in property trusts and in schemes which enable them to circumvent the income test and receive payments which under anyone else's system would be defined as income.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Chaney and his colleagues know that what we have to do in this country is get the needs-based system about which Senator Messner so often talks. One of the ways to do that is to introduce an assets element into the means test. If Senator Chaney is suggesting that we should include in that the pensioner's house and the personal possessions in that house, what he is advocating is that we as a government, and his Party if it were in government, should send inspectors around to everyone's house to see and value what is on the wall, to look at and value jewellery, and so on. Under the sort of assets test we are proposing-this is the assets test that successive Ministers for Social Security on the other side administered-we will not have to value people's homes, we will not have to send inspectors around to people's homes, because we consider that intrusive. If Senator Chaney is advocating that, let him do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister address his mind to the question, which asked him to justify the fairness of distinguishing between unlimited stocks of antiques, jewellery or paintings and anything in excess of $2,500 in the bank for a married couple?

—One can justify it in the way I believe I have just justified it . I believe that it is perfectly reasonable to justify it on the grounds that people's personal possessions of the type I mentioned cannot be assessed without intrusion, without sending in the sorts of inspectors that Senator Chaney would like to send. We wish to make sure that assets of the type about which Senator Chaney talked and which are available to be used easily are included in the income test. I remind honourable senators that a single person can have $17,000 in the bank and a married couple $28,000 and still receive a full pension and that a level of $104,000 and $177,000 must be reached for a single person and married couples respectively before they lose their entitlement to a pension. If Senator Chaney suggests that we should introduce an assets test that will mean inspectors being sent around to people's homes, let him say so. If he does not suggest we do that, if he suggests we do not have an assets test, let him come up with an alternative, but he and his colleagues were unable to do that in all their years in government.

—Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that the Queensland Premier has resurrected the discredited Bradfield scheme for water diversion in north Queensland as an election issue and appointed consultants to conduct further studies? Have any feasibility studies been carried out into this scheme? If so, what were the results of those studies?

—I had heard-I must say I found it extremely difficult to believe and had it concerned anyone other than the Premier of Queensland I would not have believed it-that the Premier has commissioned a further study of some type or other into the Bradfield scheme. I think that last year the Queensland Government commissioned a study by the Brisbane engineers Cameron McNamara Pty Ltd into this same scheme. It is not necessary to go into all the details that were given in the report presented by Cameron McNamara, but there are two that are critical. The first is that the delivered cost of water in the area in which it is envisaged the water would be delivered is 20 times as high as it is in the Burdekin. It also raised the very serious possibility of land salination in the area which it was envisaged may be irrigated. I think it could be fairly said that the Bradfield scheme is to water supplies what Milan Brych is to cancer, Stephen Horvath is to transport and Dr Shrian Oskar is to finance and commerce. All of them have been adopted and championed at various times by the Premier of Queensland who has a quite alarming propensity to adopt and champion cranks, crooks and charlatans. Milan Brych, a previous client of the Queensland Premier, is currently facing criminal charges in the United States-
—He has been found guilty.

—I am told that he has been convicted. I am sorry, my information is slightly out of date. He has been convicted on criminal charges in the United States. Stephen Horvath who, I remind honourable senators, claimed that in the boot of a motor car he had a fusion reactor which produced hydrogen which propelled the car and who was championed and adopted by the Premier of Queensland has faded away into the obscurity from which the Premier of Queensland should never have taken him.
