—Order! I suggest that the Minister get back to the answer.

—I am about to wind up, Mr President. Dr Shrian Oskar is an international con man who left a trail of debts behind in New Zealand. He then moved on to Western Australia and got the Court Government to guarantee a loan for an oil-seed factory. Recently, incidentally, a $1 million award was given against him in favour of the Commonwealth for non-repayment of a debt. Immediately after the award was handed down Dr Shrian Oskar skipped the country and has not been heard of since.
—I raise a point of order. Mr President, I ask you to pull the Minister into line and get him to answer the question.
—I suggest that the Minister take note of standing order 100 and not debate the issue.

—Very well, Mr President. I was just drawing attention to the fact that the Bradfield scheme and the Premier's recommissioning of a study into it can be regarded in the same order of credibility as the other matters to which I have referred. Now that the restraining influence of the Liberal Party is no longer present in the Government of Queensland and the Premier who sponsored all these crooks, cranks and charlatans is the Treasurer as well as the Premier, all I can say is: God help Queensland if it does not change the government next month.

—It is very appropriate that you have called me. Thank you very much, Mr President. My question is also directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. I trust that it will not give him the opportunity to give us another long harangue about the Premier of Queensland who is doing the best job as a Premier in Australia that it is possible to do. I know that from personal experience. I ask the Minister: Is he aware that it has been stated that the new excise on fuel oil announced in the Budget could cost the Greenvale nickel mine project in Queensland as much as $3,300,000 a year at full production? In view of the report in the Brisbane Courier-Mail of yesterday's date that the Greenvale nickel mine is having financial problems, will the Government take action to exempt this project from the excise on fuel oil?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware specifically of the report which appeared in the Brisbane Courier-Mail yesterday. I do know that significant quantities of fuel oil are used in the Greenvale refinery. I believe I was told yesterday that the Queensland Government had proposed that this refinery be exempt from the 1.872c per litre excise on fuel oil. I am also aware of the fact that the refinery has incurred substantial losses in recent times. The major reason for those substantial losses was that the price of nickel last year fell to a low point of $1.40 a pound. It has since then recovered quite substantially. As recently as last week, I believe, the price was $2.20 a pound which, while not high by historical standards, is obviously very much higher than $1.40 a pound. Therefore, for that reason we can expect that that refinery will be in a much better financial position this year than it was last year.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the specific reference to the fuel excise, if it is indeed a fact that the refinery is in deep financial trouble and if the Queensland Government believes that some special concession ought to be made for that refinery in isolation, it seems to me that if the Queensland Government were to put such a proposition seriously to the Commonwealth there ought to be some quid pro quo or matching offer from the Queensland Government. I am informed, for example, that the Queensland Government collects three quarters of a million dollars in payroll tax from that refinery. If such a proposal were put forward, provided it could be documented that the refinery was in deep trouble and the Queensland Government was prepared to offer some constructive suggestions on its own behalf , I have no doubt that the proposal would have to be seriously examined by the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I refer him to the announcement in the Budget of a $5 a week increase in the unemployment benefit for under 18-year-olds, to be effective from November. I also refer the Minister to an answer he gave to my question without notice on 11 May in which he stated that the whole area of income assistance to under 18-year -olds is presently under review. I ask the Minister: In view of the very desperate situation currently being faced by many unemployed young people and in view of the minimal effect this $5 a week increase will have, will the Government be introducing any additional measures to relieve the plight of unemployed under 18-year-olds, particularly those living away from home?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do remember the question asked by Senator Foreman on 11 May. Certainly in the Budget we increased the unemployment benefit for those under 18 years of age by $5 a week. I think all of us on both sides of this Parliament would have liked to do more. The increase of $5 a week this year-an increase of $5 a week was given last year which I believe was the only increase since 1975-is not as much as we would have liked to give them. But the fact of the matter remains that within difficult economic restraints that was all we felt we could do. But at the same time my colleagues the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Minister for Housing and Construction and I through a couple of inquiries are looking at the whole area of income support and support for youth, particularly those young people-unfortunately, there are too many of them-who are homeless.

ANSWER.PARA: From memory I think there are about 14 different forms of income support for young people in this country, including social security and education allowances . There is a developing but, as yet, not well developed system of assistance for those who are homeless through refuges and, in some of the States, through the provision of medium term and long term accommodation. We have a very difficult situation in this country in that some 66 per cent of people between the ages of 15 and 19 are in the work force, either employed or unemployed and receiving the unemployment benefit, whereas the equivalent in other countries is about 30 per cent or 34 per cent. We think that these factors all must be taken into consideration. We must look at the whole area of income support and services support for these children. We will be proceeding to do so in the near future, particularly in the area of homeless youth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Health aware of a letter being sent by Medibank Private to pensioners seeking membership within the basic hospital table in which Medibank Private refuses them such membership? The letter states:

QUESTION.PARA: I should point out that as the holder of a pensioner medical card you are entitled to a rebate of 85% of the medical schedule fee and free standard ward accommodation in a public hospital with treatment by a doctor appointed by the hospital. It is not the policy of this fund to accept membership in these circumstances.

Does this mean pensioners are now to be denied the right to have the doctor and medical treatment of their choice in spite of their willingness to pay for private insurance? Alternatively, is this an attempt by Medibank Private to divert pensioner clients to other funds because they may have a higher illness rate? In view of the heightened, indeed critical, role planned for Medibank Private in the Medicare system, can the Minister now give an undertaking that this unfair and discriminating practice will cease?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, just before lunch my attention was drawn to the letter referred to by Senator Mason. On the face of it, I am certainly as disturbed as he is about that letter.
—Why are you going to trust them to handle the administration?

—In answer to that interjection I can only point out that the clients of the private health insurance fund in Tasmania called Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund, rigorously supported by people like Senator Walters, not only do not have cover but also are broke because of the attitude of that Fund. Under section 66, I think, of the National Health Act Medibank cannot in fact refuse adult membership because of age, disease or sex, or for any other reason. Under another section of the Act, which escapes me at the moment, the Minister can in fact direct Medibank to receive such clients. One can only think that the New South Wales Manager of Medibank, who I believe wrote the letter, must have believed that it was economically unwise for someone who had such facilities available to him free to join the fund. However, I have referred that matter to the Minister for Health. I can assure Senator Mason that if, as he and I think on the face of it, there has been discrimination-in fact, I suggest that the prima facie case is that there may have been illegal action-the Minister will take steps to make sure that it does not happen in the future.
—I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Following the South Pacific Forum, what is the future of Australia's South Pacific nuclear free proposal?
—Did you have notice of it?

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I happen to have an answer, yes. Senator Sir John Carrick is surprised at that. Senator McIntosh's question relates to the issue of a nuclear free zone in the South Pacific. As the Senate is aware, the South Pacific Forum took place last week. In the course of the Forum the Government raised, both for consideration on the agenda last week and for consideration on future agendas of the South Pacific Forum, the question of a nuclear free zone. I might say that all nations present at the South Pacific Forum expressed their opposition to nuclear testing and the dumping of nuclear waste in the Pacific. That opposition was put forward in the light of a paper which was presented to the Forum by the Australian Government. Of course, there were some differences of emphasis on this question amongst the parties at the South Pacific Forum, but the overwhelming view of the Forum member countries represented there was that the concept of a nuclear free zone should be further developed. There was a very constructive spirit in the discussions which took place.

QUESTION.PARA: At the end of the conference Mr Muldoon, the Prime Minister of New Zealand, in a Press conference said that he supported the concept of a nuclear free zone as outlined by Australia-that was comfort from a perhaps unexpected source. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, since the South Pacific Forum took place, has expressed the Government's satisfaction in the progress of the issue of a nuclear free zone at that Forum. The Australian Government will take that issue back to the next session of the Forum and the principle of a nuclear free zone will remain the objective of this Government. We believe it will become the objective of all governments taking part in the Forum. This Government will pursue that objective, whilst upholding its commitments under regional alliances , which are the ultimate guarantee of Australian security.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It concerns the proposed assets test on age pensioners and specifically the following statement in the Federal Budget of 23 August:

QUESTION.PARA: Allowing for administrative processes, the new test will not operate until about 12 months after legislation has been passed.

I refer to a subsequent statement by the Minister, made on television, which is in direct conflict with the Budget statement. He said that action would be taken immediately to prevent individuals from disposing of significant assets prior to the introduction of the assets test. I ask: First, how does the Minister reconcile his statement with the unequivocal Budget assertion? Secondly, what action specifically does the Government intend to take to prevent disposal of such assets? In view of the Minister's quite unequivocal statement today that assets such as jewellery, works of art, antiques et cetera will not be counted in any way, can pensioners purchase such assets between now and the introduction of the assets test without being in breach of the law? I stress that in the absence of precise information individuals may unwittingly act wrongly or indeed unwisely in the disposition of these assets. Therefore will the Minister as a matter of urgency spell out in detail the Government's intentions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My first comment is that if Senator Sir John Carrick thinks that pensioners in this country, certainly the pensioners whom most of us in this place are interested in supporting, have the means to go out and purchase the sorts of things he is talking about, he is of course wrong. What was announced on Budget night was that in the assets test there would be deprivation provisions, deprivation provisions that are in fact in the legislation now in relation to the incomes test and were in the legislation in relation to the previous assets test. Of course these deprivation provisions cannot, as Senator Sir John Carrick has said, prevent people from selling anything or giving anything away. The way in which a deprivation provision works is that if people dispose of assets-or as occurred under the previous Minister, Senator Chaney, dispose of income-in order to obtain a pension or fringe benefits they may be deemed to have retained those assets for the purpose of the assets test or the income test.

ANSWER.PARA: I impress upon the Senate that that provision is already in the legislation and has been in the legislation before. Of course it does not include ordinary gifts . It does not include allowances given to children by grandparents. Under the previous assets test, when the limit for assets apart from exempted items was $ 400 or $800, it was considered that giving away $400 or $800 per year was reasonable. That limit is $1,500 or $2,500 under the present legislation. That is a matter I have already discussed with various organisations and it is a matter for future discussion. If we had not announced-

TALK.START.PARA: —It all sounds very confusing.
—There is nothing very confusing about it to people who have a modicum of intelligence. It is Senator Teague's problem.
—You say yourself that you do not know, it is yet to be thought up.

—Senator Walters reminds me of a character in Sybil-she has but one idea and that is wrong. She is incredible in her ignorance. I think rather than interject in such a manner we should urge people on both sides of the Parliament to realise that the deprivation provisions are already there and were administered by previous Ministers. On Budget night the Government announced that large scale deprivation of that type from that date would be considered deprivation under the new legislation. We believe that that is a perfectly reasonable step. We believe that, as with previous governments of this country, both Liberal-National Party and Labor, such deprivation provisions will be administered in a humane and sensible way. That is how they have always been administered. I appreciate Senator Sir John Carrick's question and am grateful for the opportunity to clarify that matter, but I do not appreciate the sorts of statements which are being made that the Government will prevent people from giving away their assets or that it will somehow send around spies to stop people giving away their assets.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I am genuinely seeking this information, but I have to say that Senator Grimes's answer has further confused the matter. I do ask, because it is of enormous interest to all pensioners, that he make a specific clarification. I ask him why, if it was all in the existing legislation, on a channel 9 television program on the Sunday following the Budget he was so emphatic that the Government would pursue these significant assets. If it was known before, why did this need to be underlined? Will the Minister put in writing specifically what are the limitations so that people may not be either in breach of the law or be forced to act unwisely in the intervening period?

—I made the statement on the Sunday program in regard to deprivation in answer to a quite specific question. That is the first thing. The second thing is that the deprivation provisions are already in the legislation as far as the income test is concerned because we have only an income test now. It is only sensible to extend that test to assets. Thirdly, the guidelines as to what will be considered reasonable or unreasonable will, of course, come out in the regulations, but people need not fear that this Government, any more than any previous administration, will be unreasonable on this matter or cause hardship. There are always hardship provisions. A further safeguard is that what exists now but which did not exist in the time of the previous assets test is an increasingly effective system of appeal against administrative decisions. I think all those factors will protect the pensioners in this situation.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and follows from a question asked earlier in Question Time by Senator Reynolds. In view of the outrageous tax avoidance rorts that the previous Government allowed to continue in this country, will the Minister outline what steps are being taken by the Government to recoup some of the vast sums lost to revenue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Senate is aware, in the previous session of Parliament the Government introduced recoupment legislation. That legislation was defeated in the Senate. It is the Government's intention to reintroduce some aspects of the bottom of the harbour legislation which were rejected by the Senate in the previous session. I have seen recent Press reports-I hope they are untrue-that it is the intention of the Opposition to oppose that legislation in the Senate. My answer to this question, if I make it somewhat elaborate, will in a sense give food for thought to the Opposition about the course of conduct upon which it is apparently determined to embark. It is an extraordinary Opposition which comes in here day after day expressing bleeding heart views for wealthy and privileged groups in the community when the community as a whole recognises that the rejection of the tax recoupment legislation in the last session was a disgrace. The community was entitled to have the benefits of those Bills.
—Ask Senator Richardson what he thinks.
—The honourable senator can ask Senator Richardson what he thinks .
—He is not here, as usual.

—No, he is not here, because he is sitting on a committee. Senator Chaney agreed to him sitting on that committee today, contrary to what Senator Chaney said yesterday. The rejection of those Bills was a disgrace. The fact is that honest taxpayers in this community are being prejudiced by the persistence of the Opposition in supporting the interests of a minority of people prepared to evade tax.

ANSWER.PARA: The new proposals in the legislation which will be introduced into the Parliament shortly are, of course, a watered down version, if I can use that expression, of the legislation which was introduced previously. But they still involve a substantial amount of revenue. In addition to that legislation, the Government has, in the Budget context, also announced that section 26A of the Income Tax Act, which taxes speculative gains, will be strengthened to overcome the technical means which have been used by tax avoiders to avoid tax. Both those measures will be brought forward within the next two or three weeks in this Parliament and we will then be able to see the position of the Opposition once again. The Opposition's new found piety in relation to this legislation is rather hollow because, after all, it was Mr Peacock, the leader of the present Opposition, who supported the previous weak-kneed bottom of the harbour legislation introduced by Mr Howard. What is the expression, Senator?

TALK.START.PARA: —Discredited.

—It was introduced by Mr Howard, the discredited former Treasurer of this country. Once again the Government will proceed with this legislation. It will continue to proceed with legislation of this kind until tax avoidance in this country is stamped out.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, who said in the Australian on 26 July that the Budget would contain many of the policies the Australian Labor Party had developed for small business and industry before the election. He said the Budget would help small business in areas such as design, marketing, new technology and exports. Can the Minister explain to the bitterly disappointed and confused small business community where his Government has honoured any one of its pre-election policy commitments that were promised in the Budget, or is it another case of the ALP making election promises and then reneging when in government?
—First of all, let me say that I am interested to see what Senator Boswell says I said in the Australian. I take it that he was referring to a Press report of what I was supposed to have said.
—That is too old.

—No, it is not too old at all. Senator Walters is too old; that is the trouble. What I said at a forum in Sydney was that in the course of the Budget session the Government would announce policies which related to small business. Senator Boswell has asked a serious question; he has approached the matter in a serious way. He referred in the context of the Budget to design and marketing and things of that kind. In the Budget itself the Government made available $180,000, I think, to the Industrial Design Council of Australia, which in our view is a body very relevant to the needs of small business. The Fraser Government prevented any funding or ceased any funding of that body. The Government has already announced initiatives in relation to exports. It has also funded in the context of the Budget the Productivity Promotion Council of Australia and a number of other bodies relevant to the needs of small business.
—It helped the quangos. The quangos need lots of help.

—I am not concerned about the quangos. From listening to the questions today I would have thought that the honourable senator was more concerned about quangos. I am concerned about the needs of small business. In the next two or three weeks the Government will be announcing a number of other initiatives relating to small business. If the Opposition thinks those initiatives will be announced as a result of any noises made here by Opposition senators, they are making a mistake. I draw the attention of Senator Boswell, who is seriously interested in this subject, to two other matters. The Government has already taken steps to set up a small business division within the Department of Industry and Commerce.
—More bureaucrats.
—Nineteen more bureaucrats.
—Will this lead to a small business led recovery?

—The Government has freed the Commonwealth Development Bank from Loan Council approval and has given permission for the Commonwealth Development Bank to grant equity capital to small business. As I have said, a number of other measures which go to the question of equity capital will be announced in the next few weeks. I mention these matters because a wide range of considerations have been taken into account by the Government in relation to small business. It is all very well for somebody to interject about a small business led recovery. I do not care how it is led but it is very important that it take place after seven years of Fraser Government during which the growth rate of this country was absolutely despicable in an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development context.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. I refer to an article in the West Australian of 13 July in which it was reported that a recent study into linguistic problems found that many Aboriginal students were being held back by their teachers because of perceived language problems which were actually more cultural than individual based. Given that Professor Eagleson believes this to be a fairly widespread problem, will the Minister advise what action can and will be taken to ameliorate these effects, particularly at the classroom level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very well aware of the range of disadvantages that have prevented Aboriginal children from advancing in education. It has certainly been the case in Western Australia, where until recently there was a conservative government, that no special efforts were made to deal with the language needs of Aboriginal children. In fact, until the change of government no Aboriginal cultural or language programs were incorporated in the state schools at all, although some initiatives had been taken with some non- government schools, such as some Catholic schools in the Kimberley region, where culturally appropriate and Aboriginal language based programs have been developed. However, with the change of government in Western Australia and federally, Aboriginal people in Western Australia can expect some initiatives that will lead to much more appropriate and, therefore, much more effective education being made available to Aboriginal children, not only in Western Australia but also nationally.

ANSWER.PARA: I will not take up the time of the Senate at this stage in reciting all the initiatives that the Federal Government is taking which will assist Aboriginal children in their access to education, but I will draw Senator Coleman's attention to the decision of the Federal Government to re-establish the national Curriculum Development Centre. That is under way now. In fact, the first meeting of the reconstituted Curriculum Development Centre will be held on Friday. One of the top priorities the Government has referred to the Curriculum Development Centre is the development of materials for use in the teaching of Aboriginal children. Those materials will be relating to both the history and culture of Aboriginal society and also the diverse range of Aboriginal languages which are still spoken in Australia and which this Government is determined to see do not die out for want of attention at the educational level.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Special Minister of State. Has it been drawn to the Minister's attention that the Labor member of parliament for Kingston, Mr Bilney, ran up a $10,000 telegram bill in one day, several weeks ago, at the taxpayers' expense? Is there any limitation on a member of parliament doing as Mr Bilney did, that is, sending off 104 identical telegrams to his Labor colleagues-all of which criticised the Prime Minister, Mr Hawke-at a cost of $8,299 and then, within the day, sending off a further 104 telegrams, at a cost of $1,227, reversing the earlier message and saying: 'Dear colleague, on reflection I think I have been somewhat hasty'? Does the Minister agree that this is a gross abuse of taxpayers' money?

—I am familiar with the circumstances of this matter because I took some action in respect of it. The question of Mr Bilney's telegram to a wide group of members of the parliamentary Australian Labor Party was drawn to my attention at the time. Following that I telexed Mr Bilney-I sent one telex- seeking some explanation of the matter. The circumstances were that Mr Bilney lodged what he believed to be a telex after hours at the telex office of the General Post Office in Adelaide. He assumed at the time that the message would be sent by telex. It was, in fact, sent by telegram, Mr Bilney's assumption about how it would be sent proving to be incorrect. The expected costs upon which Mr Bilney acted as an assumption were not correct. I mention this because I sought an explanation of this matter from the honorable member for Kingston. That was the explanation which I was given. Insofar as the general question of the entitlement of members of parliament to send telegrams, and large numbers of telegrams, is concerned, it has been the view of all governments over recent years that there should not be any interference in a member's right to send telegrams as the member sees fit.
—It is up to his electorate to deal with him.
—I assume, confronted with what the Sydney Morning Herald described this morning as an almost invisible Opposition, that Mr Bilney will do very well in Kingston and will be prepared to run that risk.
—We don't send $10,000 worth of telegrams.

—Senator Chaney says that the Opposition does not send $10,000 worth of telegrams. If we want to play a sort of boy scouts game about it, I can go back over the record and show that some of the previous Government's members did so. I could go back over the record and show that but I do not want to do so because I think Senator Teague has asked a serious question. A matter which ought to be of concern to all parliamentarians is that we exercise the privileges which we have in these matters with care and in a sensible way. As I say, all governments have recognised that there should be no interference with the rights of members regarding these matters. Those rights should be exercised sensibly and in moderation. For that reason I explained the action I took in relation to Mr Bilney's telegram and the response which he personally gave regarding that matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I take it that the Minister does believe there was a gross abuse of taxpayers' money. With regard to the inference of the telex, I ask: How many members of parliament actually have telex receiving facilities? Why was it, when asked by the Press at the time , that Mr Bilney said: 'One is entitled to an allowance for telegrams and that sort of thing'?

—I do not seek to explain what Mr Bilney said. One is allowed money for telexes and that sort of thing. What he said is absolutely correct. I told the Senate what Mr Bilney did, that is, he took his message to the Adelaide General Post Office. He does not have a telex machine himself. He took the message to the telex office of the GPO in Adelaide and sought to send it from there. That is the explanation, which I believe. Senator Teague, in the third part of his question, was concerned to know how many members of parliament have telexes. I do not know. I would think about eight.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ASSETS TEST AND TAXATION OF LUMP SUM SUPERANNUATION PAYMENTS

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of reports that the Opposition has pledged itself to throw out the Government's proposed assets test and the new tax on lump sum superannuation payments if it is returned to office?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. It is a matter of concern to honourable senators that they get a reasonable number of questions in Question Time. To ask the same question twice really does seem to be an abuse of the procedures of this place.
—Senator Childs has not yet asked the question. I ask him to ask the question.

—I am asking the question so that the Leader of the Government in the Senate can indicate the view of the Government. Is it not the case that the Government's proposals are aimed at fundamental inequities in the system? Can the Minister give an assurance that the new measures will be to the long term benefit of all taxpayers and that pensioners will not be unfairly disadvantaged?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the last part of the question is that that is the Government's intention. But, of course, two issues have aroused the venal ire of the Opposition during this Budget session and since the mini-Budget of 28 May. The first was the change to lump sum superannuation tax arrangements. The second was the assets test, which my colleague Senator Grimes has addressed on a number of occasions during Question Time today. The purpose of the first of these actions was to deal with the gross inequity of superannuation pensions being taxed and lump sums not being taxed. The purpose of the second was to deal with the fact that people with substantial assets have received a full pension while people in a poorer economic group have received reduced pensions as a consequence. I only add to what my colleague Senator Grimes said in relation to this matter as it has been raised today, and in the light of the Opposition's attitude to the matter, by quoting from today's Sydney Morning Herald. In referring to the Opposition's decision, the newspaper stated:

ANSWER.PARA: This appears to be inconsistent with Liberal Party rhetoric that assistance to retired people and welfare payments generally, should be provided strictly on a needs basis . . . only when the Opposition has established its own clear goals can it credibly attack the directions of the Labor Government.
It is a less eloquent summary of a newspaper's views of what my colleague Senator Grimes said so eloquently during Question Time today.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy or, perhaps, to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs as the question touches on the responsibilities of both Ministers. In light of the promising oil strike at Jabiru I off-shore from Darwin and in light of the continuing uncertainty about the Timor gap problem-that is, the uncertainty about where Australian territory ends and Indonesian territory begins-what action is being taken by the Government to solve this important practical problem?

—I understand that there is an area of uncertain or disputed territory, which Senator Chaney called the Timor gap. But I understand that the area in which the promising oil strike which was announced last week was made is not in that Timor gap area. I will confirm that. That was the preliminary notification that came to me a few days ago.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Would the Minister check with the appropriate Minister as to what action is being taken as I think there is renewed interest in the area which is subject to uncertainty.
—I think in that case the appropriate Minister to answer the question would probably be the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I will see that that matter is followed up.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Jack Evans asked me a question seeking further information from the Minister for Aviation in relation to a question on the domestic airline industry. I have been advised by the Minister for Aviation that in 1981 the former Government implemented revised airline service arrangements which continued the existing two-airline policy for a further period of at least eight years. These arrangements, including the Airlines Agreement 1981, were incorporated in legislation enacted by this Parliament. The arrangements require the two-airline policy in its current form to continue at least until early in 1990 and provide for one or more of the parties to give notice of termination of the Agreement five years after it came into force, such termination taking effect not less than three years after the notice is given.

QUESTION.PARA: Senator Evans is correct in recalling that in Opposition the Australian Labor Party was critical of what it regarded as the excessive inflexibility of the two -airline Agreement. The Government however has a duty to uphold the Agreement and the legislation passed by the former Government. The Minister for Aviation has advised me that he has indicated that he proposes to initiate late in 1984 a review of the current air service arrangements with a view to determining what changes should be made and introducing such changes as soon as it becomes possible to do so. In the meantime, the Government is actively encouraging the airlines to develop further air fare initiatives, including those which may be of assistance to the tourist industry in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to Senator Grimes's remark, in answering a question from Senator Robertson, that I had stated that the introduction of an un-means-tested, free pensioner health benefit card would solve the problem of double dipping. In the first place, I make the point that I have never advocated that. In fact, my point in raising the question was to draw attention to the fact that there are alternative means by which people can contribute to their own welfare, whether by way of a pension or in connection with health care. The statement iterates certain means by which that can be attained.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point about which I claim to have been misrepresented relates to the question of repeal and Senator Grimes's statement that, in fact, the repeal which we claim to be taking into account relates to his assets test, that is, this Labor Government's assets test. Since the Senate has now resolved to refer the matter of retirement income policy to the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare it would be wrong for honourable senators on this side of the House to prejudge the outcome in regard to whatever matters might be brought forward in its report affecting retirement income.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-My personal explanation also relates to comments made by Senator Grimes. While I am quite aware that this chamber knows only too well that he is loose with the truth I do not think that people outside are as aware of that fact. He made the statement that I had always been a great supporter of the Tasmanian Druids Medical and Hospital Benefits Fund, which went broke. He knows darned well that I was very active in trying to make it possible for the clients of that fund to get their just compensation. Indeed, I have never supported the Druids in any way at all. But as people listening today may not know about Senator Grimes's normal comments, I thought I should make a personal explanation about this matter.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Matter of Urgency

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 7 September 1983, from Senator Peter Rae:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
'That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources, which is in the best interests of this country and the world'.
Yours sincerely,
Peter Rae
Senator for the State of Tasmania.
Is the motion supported?
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That in the opinion of the Senate the following is a matter of urgency:
The continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources, which is in the best interests of this country and the world.

I thank the Senate and my colleagues for giving me the opportunity to speak in relation to this matter which is of considerable urgency and importance. It relates to the continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources, which is in the best interests of this country and of the world. In speaking to this matter I make it quite clear that I do so on behalf of the Opposition and, in particular, on behalf of the shadow Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Chaney who is, at the moment, otherwise engaged. To indicate something of his and the Opposition's attitude to this matter I would like to make a couple of brief quotes. First, on 12 August in Darwin Senator Chaney said :
Another major area of concern is Labor's attitude to the uranium industry. This is an industry where Companies want to proceed and where job creating activity is possible.
I emphasise the words 'where job creating activity is possible'. On 27 August, in referring to the Roxby Downs protest, he said:

It is a futile protest because an Australian withdrawal from the world uranium market will have no impact on the continued supply of the mineral, including from countries less concerned with safeguards aimed at preventing nuclear proliferation. It is futile because with the support of Federal and State Labor Governments and its very own niche in the ALP Platform, Roxby Downs is the one new uranium project guaranteed approval. It is destructive because the last thing Australia can afford now and in the near future is to put extra barriers in the way of new jobs. Roxby Downs will provide many thousands of construction and production jobs well into the next century.

It is with those sorts of themes that we wish to approach today the discussion of this important matter at a time when a combination of the drought and the world recession has seen Australia suffer very substantially in an economic downturn, which we hope is slowly turning around. Unless there is a clear policy to encourage the development of Australia's uranium resources, one of the potentials for economic recovery will be adversely affected. Let us get it quite clear from the start that, in relation to nuclear energy, there is a very large area of misconception. It is important that public debate can take place and continue to take place as part of the educative process in this matter. Nuclear energy is clean. Nuclear energy is comparatively safe. Nuclear energy is cheaper than oil and cheaper than coal. I believe that we must get away from the very understandable emotions of the 1940s and what happened-

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is your proof for those statements? They are all wrong, every one of them.
—I wonder whether Senator Chipp will let me make my speech and I will elaborate on those statements.
—Quote your sources.

—I will go on to quote my sources if Senator Chipp will let me make my speech and not continually interject. I cannot quote the sources at the same time as I try to summarise what I propose to say. I repeat that nuclear energy is clean, that it is comparatively safe, and that it is cheaper than oil or coal. I went on to say that we must get away from the emotions of the 1940s, which are understandable. It is interesting to see that in a protest taking place outside this chamber at the very moment, there is a reference to 'No more Hiroshimas'. We would have the unamimous support of every person in this chamber for that sentiment. No one would suggest that we should look to have a world situation in which a disaster such as Hiroshima is a potential or a likelihood.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the misconceptions that needs to be clarified is the vast difference between nuclear energy and nuclear power. We repeatedly see television programs from Europe showing some nuclear protest group. The distinction which they so often carefully fail to draw is that more often than not the protest is about the placement of nuclear weapons on the dividing line between East and West which occurs through so much of Europe, particularly in Germany. It is very understandable that people protest and are concerned about that. In relation to nuclear energy, as I will show in a moment with a quote, there is an entirely different attitude. Australia can look at what the World Health Organisation has said about this. Senator Chipp wanted me to quote, and I will give him a number of quotes from responsible bodies, or bodies which I believe are responsible bodies, which have asserted views on nuclear energy that apparently would be news to Senator Chipp. The first quote is from the Director-General of the World Health Organisation, Mr Mahler, in a 1982 publication entitled 'Nuclear Power, the Environment and Man', in which he states:
Nuclear power is a fact of life that must be looked at objectively and rationally.
That paper, published by the World Health Organisation in conjunction with the International Atomic Energy Agency, states:

From these considerations it can be concluded that: In the near historic future -over the next century-fossil fuels will have to be partly replaced by new energy sources. Sources available for this purpose are nuclear energy, and renewable forms of energy, such as solar energy, wind, geothermal energy, hydropower and biomass.

Most of the renewable sources of energy, however, do not provide high energy densities, and without new forms of collecting systems they will not be uniformly appropriate. Therefore, they may not be able to meet the major needs of continuous electricity generation and heat production for industry and urban areas.

Mankind is threatened by an early exhaustion of many of the most valuable raw materials, such as crude oil and gas. It is urgent to postpone the time of exhaustion until these materials can be replaced by other fuels.
Nuclear energy, with development of fast breeder reactors, is a centralised source of energy that can contribute to the needs of electricity and heat production over a long period of time.
I emphasise that this is a World Health Organisation publication. It continues:

Conservation and more efficient use of energy has received increasing attention as the costs of energy have risen, and this rise increases the amount of economically recoverable reserves, and conservation reduces the demand. As a result, the useful lifetime of the affected resources is increased.

That is on page 15 of the publication to which I referred. It is generally accepted that Australia, having been blessed with natural reserves of uranium, has an opportunity to provide for a real need of the energy world. Again, at page 17 of the World Health Organisation publication it is stated:

Thus the present nuclear capacity is expected to increase more than two-fold during the next five years, more than three-fold during the next ten years and by a factor of six to seven within the next 20 years.

In other words, irrespective of the views of a relatively small minority of people on nuclear power, the world assessment, as made by the World Health Organisation, is that within the next 20 years there will be an increase by some six or seven times in the nuclear capacity of the world. In May in Canberra the Australian Institute of Energy and the Institution of Engineers Australia held an excellent seminar entitled 'Energy 83'. That seminar assessed the Australian and world situation in relation to various forms of energy. A very broadly representative group of people came together for the purposes of that seminar. Certainly, very considerable expertise was available. One of the points that was made in relation to the requirements for nuclear power worldwide is set out on page 245 of the first volume of the publication of the papers and other documents associated with that seminar. It shows that as at 30 June 1982 there were 31 plants on order in the world, with a total capacity of 29,000 megawatts. There were 224 plants under construction, which will have a total capacity of 201,000 megawatts, and there were in operation 261 plants with a total capacity of 155,000 megawatts. This makes a total of 516 nuclear power stations either operating, under construction or on order around the world.

Page 246 of that publication sets out the estimated resources of uranium as at 30 June 1981. It shows Australia as one of the major holders of resources of uranium. Australia has an estimated reasonably assured resource of 294,000 tonnes and an estimated additional resource of 264,000 tonnes out of a total of about 3,300,000, which gives us something under 20 per cent of known world reserves. One might think, therefore, that we have some obligation to service what the World Health Organisation has identified as a very real and growing world demand. By providing that resource, Australia has the opportunity to improve its earnings and its standard of living but, most importantly in current circumstances, to increase its employment opportunities. As I think Senator Chipp and some of his colleagues will agree, there are people who are very genuinely concerned about nuclear energy-the safety of its operation, the question of waste disposal, and the question of its leakage to nuclear weapons production. I hope that Senator Chipp will listen to this because it is relevant to people's concern that the Methodist Church throughout the world spent some two years on a major consideration of the morality of nuclear power. I would have thought that of all the religious organisations and institutions in the world which were more likely to express a concern on this issue than others, it would be the Methodist Church.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you say that?

—Because I believe it to be very socially conscious on this sort of issue, a far more socially conscious body of people than many of the other more long term institutions. I am not saying anything rude about any of those organisations. What I said was not meant to be an insult; if anything it was meant to be a compliment. It is a matter upon which I would have expected the Methodist Church to take a very serious and very conscientious review. After some two years of a world study it concluded in favour of the morality of nuclear energy production. That point needs to be made and made again.
—John Wesley should have turned in his grave.

—Maybe things have changed and people's knowledge has expanded . Maybe the expansion of knowledge has enabled those who are up to date with the facts to come to the conclusion which I believe to be inescapable, and that is the conclusion to which I will be leading-that nuclear energy is safer and cleaner than most alternative forms of energy. As I said earlier, there is an importance in distinguishing between nuclear energy and nuclear weapons. Australia's approach has given us a proud record of utmost responsibility. We have signed nuclear safeguards agreements with Canada, Finland, France, Sweden, the Philippines, the Republic of Korea, the United States, the United Kingdom and the European Atomic Energy Community, EURATOM. These agreements were signed by the end of last year and further agreements with other countries have been negotiated, including Japan and Switzerland, enabling a large number of countries, comparable in their social and economic responsibility, to proceed with agreement on the approach that should be adopted by a responsible country in the utilisation of uranium resources and nuclear energy.

SPEECH.PARA: On looking at some of the comparisons between nuclear energy and coal one could not seriously contemplate putting forward an argument that coal would be used in favour of nuclear energy if one had a direct choice. The United States energy authority has shown that for the last two years in that country, where the cost of production is probably the highest in the world and where management has been probably the least effective or the most negligent-the cost of nuclear power is trending down in comparison with coal and is cheaper than coal per unit produced on the American basis of comparison.

I turn now to the environmental consequences of nuclear power as opposed to coal. If we consider the questions of acid rain and the greenhouse effect I still cannot understand how anyone could suggest that we should contemplate the use of the foul and extremely expensive method of production of power from the exhaustion of fossil fuels in comparison with the utilisation of uranium. A thousand megawatt station releases 7 million tonnes per year of carbon dioxide and a nuclear power station releases nil. The source of that information, I point out to Senator Chipp, is the Atomic Industrial Forum in New York and it is quoted in many places with approval. Sulphur dioxide releases in tonnes per year are 24,000 from coal and nil from nuclear power. On looking at the annual waste disposal problem and all the rest of the figures that I would have thought are starting to become resonably common these days in the knowledge of people, it is very hard to say on any basis of comparison that nuclear power is not cleaner or safer. I thought it was significant that on the day of the Harrisburg Three Mile Island negligent handling problem, from which there was no resulting damage to an individual and from which the President's inquiry showed no form of damage--

TALK.START.PARA: —How in the name of God can you say that?

—The President's health commission inquiry showed that a person would have had to have stood in one place for a year to have received any more than the normal readout of radioactivity. But on that day a large number of people-I will not quote from a newspaper article because I cannot find the cutting-were killed in a coal mine collapse. That did not receive any front page coverage anywhere in the world. It appeared at about page 23 somewhere. In comparison no one was killed as a result of the Harrisburg incident. That is one comparison. My colleagues can refer to others.

SPEECH.PARA: We have a problem in that the Australian Labor Party is unclear as to which way it is going in the provision of jobs and the development of this industry for Australia. The Labor Party is not yet clear as to what it will do for the future of Australia's participation, either for Australia's benefit or for the benefit of the world. I would have thought that we had some responsibility to do as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) suggested in his speech to the anniversary conference of the Australian Institute of International Affairs, when he said:
Australians must recognise what is happening and accept that we either keep up or lose out.

I would have thought that was one of the Prime Minister's quotable statements on nuclear energy. We must either keep up or lose out. The world will not wait for Australia. We have seen recently that both the Federal Labor Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the South Australian Premier, Mr Bannon, have grasped the nettle in relation to the Roxby Downs question but they have not been able to ovecome the problems in some of the sections of the Labor Party with regard to the general development of uranium. One can only imagine that those people will happily say they would rather see energy provided, insofar as it has to be provided around the world, by means of the exhaustion of fossilised fuels with all the attendant ills and adverse effects on human life and the environment than move towards continuing to provide to the world, subject to adequate safeguards to ensure that there is no misuse of nuclear waste, the uranium with which Australia has been blessed and which can enable us to increase employment opportunities in this country, increase the wealth of this country and the opportunity of development, and provide heat and succour to the rest of the world. I think that this identifies very clearly one of the major issues in Australia, one which we will need to debate and debate until we get quite clearly a judgment from the Australian people on an informed basis, and information is one of the things that Australians have been denied too often in the past in relation to this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened to Senator Rae and I think he has competently presented a pro- nuclear case, most of which was rational, but he did not demonstrate any urgency in speaking on what is supposed to be a matter of urgency before the Senate. I qualify the words 'most of which was rational'. One of Senator Rae's comments, which I wrote down, was that nuclear power is clean, safe and cheaper than oil or coal. Those three words-'clean', 'cheap' and 'safe'-
—I used the word 'comparatively'.

—Well, they are rather subjective. That is the point I was going to make. It is certainly correct that in some locations nuclear power is cheaper than oil or coal, but it is not correct that in all locations it is cheaper than coal. It is more likely to be cheaper than oil in all locations.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the wording of the alleged matter of urgency to which I have referred . There have been some important matters with respect to uranium and nuclear policy upon which this Government, on taking office, acted with urgency. The broader questions, however, ought to be considered at greater length. I will say more about that later. This urgency motion, which refers, in part, to 'the continuation of responsible development', clearly implies that that development which has so far taken place has been responsible. That is not the case, as I will demonstrate later. On the question of urgency, to suggest, as the motion and the framework in which it is presented do, that there is an urgent need to make exhaustive decisions-a comprehensive, all-embracing decision-about uranium policy and nuclear power is, I believe, in conflict with if not mutually exclusive to being responsible.

Matters of detail did require urgent action and urgent action was taken by this Government. Six negotiating determinations for six companies had been issued by the former Deputy Prime Minister. They were promptly cancelled by the present Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen). Quite apart from the environmental and military objections which are widely held towards nuclear power, it was, in purely economic terms, irresponsible for the former Deputy Prime Minister to have issued negotiating determinations to that number of producers, given the demand for uranium, irrespective of any non-economic constraints and given the demand for uranium in the foreseeable future. Shipments of Australian uranium to France have been suspended as a protest against French nuclear testing in the South Pacific.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have not been suspended. They had not taken place. They were not due until October this year.
—There was a shipment due in July of this year. It was suspended because of the French practice of letting off atom bombs in our backyard, something they would not dare to do in their own backyard.
—But Mr Hawke-

—I should like to expand on that. I will not name the individuals but a good deal of this is on the public record. It is well known that the question of whether Australia should be involved in uranium supply is a contentious issue within political parties, between political parties and in the community in general. There are prominent members of the Australian Labor Party who have publicaly expressed strong support for uranium mining but whose view also is that under no circumstances should Australian uranium be supplied to France while it continues to test atomic weapons in the South Pacific. With respect to France, it is not just a question of the clear environmental and ultimate military dangers of atomic testing. This testing is, in my view and in the view of many others, an unacceptable last vestige of European colonial arrogance. France would not dare test atomic weapons in the Mediterranean. So the French have gone to a place on the globe about as far away from France as it is possible to get and have decided to test them there. Action was taken quickly by the Government with respect to that. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden), almost immediately on becoming Minister, ordered a review of the nuclear safeguards policy. Shortly afterwards he appointed an Ambassador for Disarmament in an attempt to pursue a policy aimed at ensuring that the nuclear industry is not misused for the production of nuclear weapons and ultimtely for nuclear war.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of safe waste disposal operations, the Government allocated in this year's Budget $1.332m for the Synroc research program as against an expenditure of $0.268m last year. I should add that an amount somewhat greater than $0.268m was allocated last year but not spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, but it was the same amount, was it not? It was very close to it.

—It was not the same amount. It was somewhat less. It was much underspent. Expansion of that program is planned for this financial year. The Government is also-again this has been a matter of much public comment- conducting a comprehensive review of the nuclear industry in Australia. A number of Cabinet submissions either have been prepared or are in the process of being prepared and, as I stated in the Senate yesterday, ought to be considered by Cabinet probably within the next month. Those reviews cover the Nuclear Non- Proliferation Treaty, the industry within Australia and also the Atomic Energy Act, that draconian piece of legislation first passed by this Parliament in 1953 , in an hysterical McCarthyist climate, which has been allowed to remain the law or the principal Act under which uranium has been mined in Australia for far too long. That broad question to which I have referred, the determination of policy on nuclear non-proliferation, on the Australian industry as a whole and the Atomic Energy Act, is a question on which I suggest it would be irresponsible to make hasty decisions. This Government is acting responsibly in preparing submissions covering the whole range of nuclear activities upon which ultimately a responsible decision will be made.

SPEECH.PARA: That, I suggest, contrasts sharply with the irresponsibility of the previous Government. I remind the Senate that the motion refers to 'the continuation of responsible development', which unarguably implies, if it is accepted by the Senate, that development up to now has been responsible. Indeed, the attitude of the previous Government was that if it could get a dollar out of uranium it did not care what the cost elsewhere may be. The Atomic Energy Act, to which I have already referred, is an example of the previous Government's neglect. The previous Government was happy to make uranium available to France on an ad lib basis. I have referred to that as well. Indeed, if the gung ho attitude of the former Deputy Prime Minister were to be accepted as the definitive statement of the previous Government's policy on this matter-and it was accepted by the previous Government-one could well get the impression that Mr Anthony would have sold uranium to Idi Amin if Idi had not run out of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the need for safeguards approval? How do you negotiate that one?

—I am about to refer to the safeguards as a very good demonstration, a powerful demonstration indeed, of the irresponsibility of the previous Government. On 5 June 1978 the then Prime Minister, when addressing the United Nations General Assembly, said that he favoured a complete ban on re- processing fissionable material which would have allowed extraction of plutonium , the raw material for nuclear weapons. In July 1979, just over a year later, the Government abandoned a policy it had announced on 24 May 1977 which was that exports of uranium would be covered by the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards from the time they left Australian ownership. That change, I might add, was designed to protect the commercial interests of commercial exporters, an example of the pursuit of the dollar once again, regardless of all other costs. In January 1979 the then Government announced that it would allow companies to enter conditional uranium contracts before safeguard agreements had been concluded with the importing country, thereby repudiating Mr Fraser's 24 May 1977 statement requiring 'prior conclusion of bi-lateral agreements between the Australian Government and countries wishing to import Australian uranium'. The problem of waste disposal was likewise trivialised by some members of the previous Government. On 28 August 1977 the then Prime Minister asserted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . let me emphasise as forcefully as I can that here the scientific knowledge does exist-
that is, on waste disposal-
The technology does exist. The scientific knowledge and technology have been applied to the problem of waste.
That was in 1977. In March of 1982, almost four and a half years later-

TALK.START.PARA: —What was he referring to? Could you complete the quote?
—He was referring to waste disposal.
—It was the French vitrification process, wasn't it?

—Mr Fraser said that the technology did exist for the safe disposal of waste. I am not sure what particular technology he was referring to. That is relatively unimportant, as honourable senators opposite will know when they hear what I am about to quote. On 16 March 1982, 4 1/2 years later, Senator Sir John Carrick, who was the Minister with joint responsibility-I suppose that would be the most accurate way to put it-for uranium policy in the previous Government, said that he had:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . no knowledge of any firm proposals to construct facilities for the final disposal of high level nuclear waste . . .

With that statement he gave away Mr Fraser's previous assurances that the technology was there and that there would be no problems. The question of the disposal of nuclear waste was trivialised by the previous Government. Its public statements on uranium were closely linked with its general gung ho politically inspired attitude and promotion of the so-called resources boom. Mr Anthony once asserted that 500,000 jobs were on tap at will from the development of uranium in Australia. Mr Viner, the former honourable member for Stirling, one of the many involuntary retirees from the previous Government, asserted in the House of Representatives that for every job directly associated with the uranium industry there would be a multiplier of 15, that is, for every person employed in mining uranium, 15 more people would be consequentially employed elsewhere.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was never good at maths, was he?

—No. The multiplier, which is a bit of economists' jargon, is a variable but the normal multiplier is in the vicinity of three to four. Anything above five would be extraordinarily high; nevertheless, Mr Viner asserted in the House of Representatives that a multiplier of 15 applied to uranium.
—Anthony put it higher.

—Mr Anthony did not actually quote a multiplier, he just came out with a figure of 500,000 jobs, presumably plucked straight out of the air. The matter of Roxby Downs has been raised today in Question Time. I think I should briefly summarise our position. The Australian Labor Party platform makes special provision for consideration on a case by case basis in section 64c for the mining of uranium where it is mined incidentally to the production of other minerals. At the rate of production projected by the company involved, Western Mining Corporation Ltd, and at current prices the uranium at Roxby Downs, amounts to something less than 40 per cent by value. Irrespective of any political or moral constraints or objections, on a purely economic assessment, the potential for exports of uranium from Australia on a reasonably optimistic forecast over the next five years is a maximum of an additional 12,000 tonnes. That amount could be supplied if there were no other constraints or objections. The plain fact is that at present the world market for uranium is very slack and likely to remain so for some considerable time. Admittedly, that situation may change in the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: For the reasons that I have given, the Government objects to the terms in which the Opposition has framed its matter of urgency. It does not accept that the discussion legitimately falls into the category of a matter of urgency. More importantly, the motion refers to 'the continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources'. As I have shown, development up to this point has not been responsible. This Government is pursuing a responsible policy. The Standing Orders do not allow for amendment of a motion of urgency, but I seek leave to move such an amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it is not permitted by Standing Orders, it can be done by leave. Is leave granted?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Peter Rae

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. It is given in a spirit of co-operation and in order to have the matter debated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Delete all words after 'urgency' and substitute the following:
'Responsible development of Australia's uranium resources which requires:
(a) measures to improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of nuclear non- proliferation safeguard systems;
(b) satisfactory arrangements for the storage and disposal of nuclear waste materials;
(c) mechanisms to ensure satisfactory safety, occupational health conditions, and environment protection within the mining industry in Australia.'

Essentially, the amendment removes from the Opposition's motion the clear implication that development up to this stage has been responsible, which the Government does not accept. Therefore the Government would not have voted for the motion as orginally moved by Senator Peter Rae, but on which he has been kind enough to grant leave to move the amendment I have circulated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Townley Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: — This matter of urgency deals with the mining of uranium and its export for peaceful purposes. I am indebted to Senator Kilgariff for allowing me to speak in this debate. It is an issue in which I have a fair deal of interest. I know that Senator Kilgariff wanted to speak on the matter and has a lot of material prepared. I am grateful for the help he has been to me. When we talk about the mining of uranium, no matter what motion might be before the Senate, we have to think of the end use of the uranium. Today we are suggesting that mining go ahead in Australia only for the peaceful end use of the product. No one who has read anything about the likely effects of an all out atomic war can be anything but horrified by those prospects. Most people feel that there cannot be a limited atomic war. Such a conflict would escalate into a much larger one.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate on uranium I believe there have been some clever moves by those opposed to atomic power to confuse the public by speaking of nuclear proliferation from nuclear stations and technology. Let me say quite clearly that I do not believe proliferation has come about or will come about because of our selling uranium to other countries. I believe our safeguards are sufficiently tight. Australia is extremely rich in uranium, most probably the richest country in the world in that regard. But no matter what the conservationists say about our leaving uranium in the ground, such an attitude will not stop the development of atomic power stations. The mining and enrichment of uranium and the development of atomic power stations will go ahead . Australia has nothing to gain and a heck of a lot to lose if it adopts the selfish attitude of not supplying uranium to the rest of the world.

I do not know whether it is generally recognised but our national debt situation even last year, before the horrific deficit in our Budget this year, is quite critical. I had the Parliamentary Library prepare a few figures comparing what we owe per head of population to the international banking community with the figure owed per capita in Poland, Brazil and Argentina, countries about which so much has been written and discussed recently. Those figures show that Australia has a per capita liability of $US1,880, that Poland has $US790, Brazil $US950 and Argentina $US1,820. In other words, we are worse off in that respect than any of those countries. For the sake of clarity I seek leave to have that very simple table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
