TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I believe it is up to us to do what we can to reduce that debt. I mentioned those figures to someone and he said: 'Yes, but Australia will be able to repay its debts'. If we stop development of one thing after another in this country, which is apparently what the left wing socialists want us to do, we will not be able to repay our debts. I must say that the Australian Democrats appear to take a very similar view to that of the socialists. Certainly, they exhibit little scientific or engineering knowledge and their attitude in supporting non-development seems to align them very closely with the extreme left of the Australian Labor Party, the extreme socialists who I feel do all they can to frustrate the development of this country. The Democrats and others helped to stop the hydro development of South West Tasmania. That will compel Tasmania to install a coal fired power station. When the Premier of Tasmania, Mr Gray, looked at an atomic power station while he was in the United States of America, Senator Chipp went quite bonkers, and once again without any reason except, I believe, a political reason, leapt into print saying that 'an atomic power plant in Australia would be bad', or words to that effect.

SPEECH.PARA: As an engineer, let me say quite clearly that I would much prefer to live down wind of an atomic power station than I would of a coal fired station with its inherent acid rain, atomic fallout from the burning of coal and other environmental problems such as ash. I believe that Senator Chipp and his party show either complete ignorance of this matter or, more likely, are appealing to the unfounded fear on the part of some of the public. We in Tasmania do not yet need anything other than the hydro power that is still available. But when the time comes that we do I hope, for one, that our needs will be produced by atomic power and that the coal and oil that we have in Australia will be retained for future use. If we do not have atomic power, and these resources are used at anticipated rates, the resources will be depleted in a mere 100 years.
What do some of the eminent scientists say about nuclear power? Let me quote a few extracts from a little book called Challenge to Australia. The late Sir Barton Pope, at page 7, says:

Australia, or any other country, must not anticipate selfishly withholding its resources from desperate and needy nations. The world must become closer knit and interdependent. Compassion must displace selfishness.
At page 8 of the book he says:

With coal resources reserves in part for its alternative uses in the supply of gas, oil and petro chemicals, at some stage during the century ahead probably we will be dependent on nuclear to service major energy needs and to bridge the gap to new discovery.
At page 13 he says:

Nuclear energy has got right out of perspective and understandably is clouded with emotionalism with its initial application to war. Science and the world nuclear industry must stand rebuked for remaining so remote from the community at large who have unfairly been left uninformed and vulnerable to misinterpretation.
Further, on the same page, he says:

Our very survival may well depend on the use of nuclear power for civilian use. The world in the next century will become acutely aware of the great debt to nuclear science and will pay tribute to its creators.

What, I ask honourable senators, could be clearer than that? An eminent scientist has made a statement that our very survival may well depend on the use of nuclear power for civilian use. Sir Barton Pope points out that without nuclear energy the lives of many people who will be part of the expected population growth over the next 50 years will not be spared. On page 13 he also says:

A Nobel Prize would be totally inadequate recognition for the scientist and those millions so spared would owe a great debt of gratitude to the opponents of nuclear for civilian use who, when better informed, had the courage to reverse their expressed opposition and emotionalism of today.

We all must, of course, work towards the proper standards of safety for the nuclear industry. The safe mining, enrichment and use of uranium present engineering and physical problems that are being solved. However, we cannot solve the deaths from coal mining and black lung disease. We cannot stop the acid rain that falls down wind from a coal burning power station. I believe that engineers and scientists unfortunately do not offer themselves as politicians often enough but maybe it is time more of them became involved and assisted in the education of the community in matters such as this and other scientific aspects.

The late Sir Barton Pope is not the only scientist to say that we need to share our uranium wealth. Sir Macfarlane Burnet at page 26 of the book, which I must say is prefaced by a statement from the Governor-General, said:
The only presently conceivable alternative with a sufficiently long-lasting supply of planetary material is controlled nuclear fusion analogous to the primary source of energy in the sun.

Of course, until controlled nuclear fusion is perfected we will need atomic energy, as now produced in some 25 countries, 19 of which are building more stations. I believe that the little book from which I have been quoting is well worth reading by all honourable senators. If we do not go nuclear, if oil runds out, if eventually all of the coal is used, and in fact life on earth is not destroyed first by the effects of burning coal, how will places such as Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and the Philippines, to name just a few in our immediate vicinity presently using atomic power, get on? Are we selfishly going to sit on the uranium that we have? Will we let these people and others go without because of our unthinking attitude? No sensible person would suggest that. I believe we should be co-operating on a world-wide basis in developing an industry and assisting in the atomic area. At page 33 of the book from which I have quoted Sir Mark Oliphant said:

. . . it is impossible to put the clock back, to wipe out the nuclear knowledge which made the weapons possible, or to forgo the peaceful uses of nuclear energy in a world where fossil fuels, especially oil and gas, are being depleted rapidly.
At page 34 he stated:
Withholding Australian uranium would not prevent the erection of a single reactor.
He further stated:

As one who has been involved all my life in nuclear physics and nuclear energy, who has participated in many international discussions with Soviet and other workers in these fields, and in scientific and technical aid to developing nations, who is committed to the search for peace, I am convinced that Australia would be foolish not to mine, use, and sell uranium.
He went on:
Nuclear power stations are now far less polluting and are safer, than coal- burning equivalents.

That is exactly what Senator Peter Rae said earlier. My position is clear. I agree with those gentlemen. Perhaps I should commend to the Senate the detailed reading of the preliminary paper that Mr A. E. Ringwood was good enough to send to me recently. It involves the disposal of higher level atomic wastes in synroc -a synthetic rock-as a means of handling the high level wastes such as caesium 137, strontium 90, plutonium and neptunium. This is the way that the world should be looking and going. In that paper he details how to store safely the wastes of those atomic reactors. I admit that there is a need to educate the public in the matter of safe storage, and I will be doing my best to help in that regard over the coming years.

It seems to me that the Research School of Earth Sciences at the Australian National University has made a great contribution to solving the waste problem of the nuclear power stations. Its idea of disposal is to drill holes into stable rock, which has the advantage of getting the waste right out of likely low storage mine repositories that are much lower under the ground. It would be millions of years before any of that material once again was circulated anywhere in the world. I have almost run out of time, but I do suggest that all honourable senators read that article and start reading a little about the atomic energy needs of this world. It is something with which we are going to have to live. It is an engineering problem, and I believe that it is one that is getting closer and closer to perfection as time goes by.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wholeheartedly endorse the closing remarks of Senator Peter Rae, who said: 'We must debate and debate'. This, however, makes considerable nonsense of the fact that we have before us a matter of urgency. It is a question with which we cannot possibly grapple in a two-hour urgency debate it is quite inappropriately dealt with as a matter of urgency. We do not retreat from debating this subject. In fact I think the Australian Labor Party could legitimately lay claim to being the political party which has spent an inordinate amount of time and energy on debating this question and in public, unlike the Liberal and National parties. If Senator Townley's suggestion that Australia should pay its international debts with uranium sales is an example of the level of debate that occurs in those parties, they had better keep that debate in private and behind cosed doors until the tone improves. The morality of such proposals would be strongly questioned by the millions of Australians and others who deplore the notion that Australian uranium may find its way, quite easily under current conditions, into weapons capable of most appalling destruction. We are prepared also in the Labor Party to go on debating this matter in public as long as there are serious unresolved economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium and the development of nuclear power.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to concentrate on the hazards and the lack of safety within the normal operation of the fuel cycle as distinct from acts of terrorism or risks of nuclear war. This question most closely involves those people who, up until now, have been involved with the mining and processing of uranium in Australia, those who currently are working in mines, and those who, in the future, will also be exposed. Radiation, of course, occurs naturally. Man-made radiation from medical radiology, industrial processes, fall-out from nuclear tests and nuclear power production is encountered in varying doses by all of us at one time or another. Medical radiology is the greatest contributor to radiation. Amongst the types of exposure which are most commonly encountered, of course, are somatic exposure directly to the individual, or genetic exposure to descendants of those exposed. The effects of these have been widely documented but are still not fully understood.

The difference in interpretation of various studies has left us further confused. Obviously there are differences in sensitivity between individuals who are exposed to constant levels of radiation over constant periods of time. It is known that large doses of 100 to 200 rems delivered repeatedly to a large part of the body injure or kill a large number of cells and lead in a matter of days to very obvious injury or to death. Low doses of radiation, however, such as those experienced by people who are mining and processing uranium and by people using machinery and technical equipment which is known to emit doses of radiation are worrying us more and more. We are finding that young women, for instance, who have handled visual display units daily for a matter of months or years are complaining of increased incidence of miscarriage and birth deformities. There still is no definitive work that links those factors, but we do know that the amount of radiation that the workers are absorbing is not measured. It is the machinery that tends to be measured.

A few years ago I had discussions with a gentleman from Rumania, who told me that in five districts uranium had been mined for some years until suddenly it was discovered that there was a drastic fall in the birth rate. At that stage mining ceased in four districts and much smaller amounts of uranium were being mined under safer conditions. The cumulative effect on the islanders in the South Pacific has been impossible to quantify. By effect , of course, I mean the effect of the fall-out from the French testing in the Pacific. We do know that there is a steady stream of patients with neoplasms of various types coming to Sydney for treatment from the Pacific Islands. We also know that large numbers of people are going to France and New Zealand for treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a causal relationship?

—I am not claiming any definitive information about the causal relationship. We are aware that great difficulty is being encountered by the World Health Organisation, which has as yet not been able to obtain information necessary to prepare a comprehensive assessment on the long term effects-both the somatic and genetic effects-of low level radiation on the population of the islands in the South Pacific which has been at risk for many years from French nuclear testing.

SPEECH.PARA: An American mathematician Sister Rosalie Bertell set out some years ago to design a method of recording and storing medical data and discovered that the population which was under study was showing in quite young people a very high incidence of diseases usually associated with ageing. Conditions such as cardiovascular diseases, osteoarthritis, hypertension, artereosclerosis were occurring in the young and middle aged, cutting decades off their lives, making old people of them before their time. The only explanation for this was that this population had been exposed to low level radiation-lower than what till then had been considered dangerous-from tailings from a nearby uranium treatment plant.

A careful scientist, like all mathematicians, Sister Bertell checked and rechecked the results of her study and finally, satisfied of the validity of her findings, set out to alert thinking people to the implications of exposure to low levels of radiation over long periods. Publicity which has been directed to the more dramatic effects of higher doses, such as lung cancer from the inhalation of radon gas by miners-not only underground miners-and genetic disorders such as were recorded in Kerala in India in 1976, has tended to distract attention from the high profitability that whole communities of exposed workers and their families are aging at abnormal rates.

Anthony Wedgwood Benn, in Issues of the 1970's, called repeatedly for the sorts of controls that were advocated in the Australian Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry in 1976. I refer briefly to some recommendations of the Ranger Inquiry to remind the Senate of the language that was being used at that time, which I believe is not totally relevant and has not lost any of its impact. The first recommendation was:
The hazards of mining and milling uranium, if those activities are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify the decision not to develop Australian uranium mines.
In every one of the recommendations the report uses those terms. The second recommendation was:

The hazards involved in the ordinary operations of nuclear power reactors, if those operation are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify a decision not to mine and sell Australian uranium.

That is what the Australian Labor Party has been saying all the time. There are hazards. We are looking for safeguards. We are looking for reassurances. We want to be absolutely certain that we are not exposing Australian workers and their families to unseen but nonetheless extremely serious consequences. I refer again to Anthony Wedgwood Benn. He was particularly concerned, given the United Kingdom experience, about the implications of nuclear technology, of which mining uranium is of course an essential element. His concern was for democracy and for human rights. He said:
Before we proceed any further we must look at the need for democratic control in the light of the following considerations.

First, its close connection with military policy in regard to the development of nuclear weapons which are the most sophisticated technology available, the most dangerous, and the one covered by the greatest secrecy.

Second, the link between the military and civil use of nuclear technology makes it a matter of public concern. The production of plutonium, the development of enrichment and reprocessing all carry the risk of proliferation or vulnerability to terrorism. These are also reasons for shrouding civil nuclear processes under conditions of top secrecy.

Third, the wide gap between expert understanding and public knowledge of nuclear matters which is used to justify the exclusion of laymen-even M.P.'s and Ministers are laymen for the purpose-from the knowledge of what is really going on for fear they might not understand.

Anthony Wedgwood Benn had a rather horrifying experience when he was Minister in charge of such matters in Great Britain. In 1976 he discovered that there had been two major leaks at Windscale and some weeks had elapsed before their full extent was brought to his attention. During that time cows grazing close to Windscale had been eating radioactive grass. The milk from those cows had been directed to very many thousands of families in home counties in Great Britain, with what effect we can only guess.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the Government would not release the report.
—Exactly. Anthony Wedgwood Benn continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Fourth, the high rate of spending even in civil nuclear technology creates powerful vested interests in the industries that live off parliamentary budgets.

It may not be widely appreciated that Federal subsidies to the uranium industry in Australia rose from $30.1m in 1977-78 to $83.6m in 1981-82, a real increase of 110 per cent. This included $37.8m to the Australian Atomic Energy Commission , $8.2m towards exploration and development, $23.2m on the Commonwealth uranium stockpile, $4.4m on environmental protection and $10m on infrastructure for the Jabiluka township.

There are costs, problems and hazards associated with many technologies. For the motion of the Opposition to have any force whatsoever one would need to be convinced that what it describes as responsible development, which the Opposition seeks to continue in terms of this motion, gives high priority to the problems of safety, terrorism, civil liberties, proliferation and the environment. Where is the evidence of such concern? There has been no recognition at all of our responsibilities, this generation's great trust as stewards of this country and of the planet. The truly responsible approach to this question is the one to which this Government is committed, as outlined in Labor Party official policy. The responsibilities we have are unique in human history. We will be handing over to future generations responsibilities of monitoring and guardianship which we cannot be sure they will be in a position to discharge. That being the case, in 1983 we must acknowledge that there are still serious, important and potentially crucial questions to be resolved. They cannot be resolved as a result of a discussion of an urgency motion; they can be resolved only in the context of a responsible government prepared to face up to these important responsibilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate was initiated by Senate Peter Rae of the Liberal Party, who moved that the following matter of urgency be submitted to the Senate for discussion:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources, which is in the best interests of this country and the world.

The Australian Democrats totally, unequivocally and passionately disagree with the premise put by Senator Peter Rae and by the Liberal Party of Australia. Before I embark on my own remarks, I refer to a couple of things that Senator Rae mentioned. He said that the Methodist Church of the United Kingdom had come out steadfastly in favour of uranium mining. Since his speech was broadcast my phone has been inundated with calls to the effect that it was not the Methodist Church but a committee set up by the Methodist Church to report to the Methodist Church and that the committee did not have any member who was opposed to nuclear energy. I make the comment that if the honourable senator is quoting the Methodist Church of the United Kingdom he could quote the Uniting Church in Australia and many other churches who are steadfastly opposed to uranium mining and regard it as immoral. If the Liberal Party wants to put the view that uranium mining creates jobs and therefore we should continue with it, with great respect, I would liken that argument to saying we should have more road accidents because that would employ more tow truck drivers. I believe that, regrettably, because of the Labor Party's acquiescence to development in Roxby Downs and in granting two Queensland uranium companies authority to negotiate new uranium contracts, the policy of the Labor Party, or some leading members of it at least, is based on four false assumptions.

The first false assumption is that uranium mining is safe. I would not have thought that any more evidence would be needed by the Liberal Party that uranium mining is unsafe than the report of the Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry , which I understand was commissioned by it some years ago. That report unequivocally stated that uranium mining and milling does cause cancer-not 'may' ; it does cause cancer-and may cause gene mutations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen any evidence of that? I have not seen any.

—Senator Jessop sets himself above Mr Justice Fox, who inquired into this for years. He says he has not seen any evidence of it and therefore uranium mining does not cause cancer. Mr Justice Fox, who looked into this matter for years, stated definitely, unequivocally, that it did cause cancer and may cause gene mutations in future generations. That was a royal commission set up by the Government of this country. So enough of the myth that uranium mining is safe. Mr Justice Fox also said that there is no known way of safely storing the wastes of uranium mining. I would be fascinated to hear Senator Jessop, a self-confessed expert on these matters, nominate what ways of storing uranium mining wastes have now been proven safe forever-not just 100 years and not just 200 years, but forever.

SPEECH.PARA: The second myth is that nuclear technology is designed for peaceful uses only. The fact is that nuclear weapons can be produced only from uranium or its by- product, plutonium. There is no way of creating nuclear weapons other than by mining uranium and using the by-products. A report by the Pentagon to President Johnson in 1965 stated:
The world is fast approaching a point of no return in the prospect of controlling nuclear weapons . . .
Why did it conclude this? It went on:
Atomic power programmes are placing within the hands of many nations much of the knowledge, equipment and material for making nuclear weapons.

Yet members of the Liberal Party have said today that nuclear technology is designed for only peaceful uses. The connection between nuclear power and nuclear weapons is very clear to those at the highest levels. I refer to those nations that have or plan to have nuclear weapons, or which are about to have them. I ask Senator Rae, who is a man I respect totally, to listen to this terrifying list of nations that are about to have nuclear weapons: South Africa, Pakistan, India, South Korea, Taiwan and Argentina. Where have those nations received their plutonium? They have received it from reactors that are allegedly operating for peaceful means.

So it is a myth to say that just because nuclear reactors are operating peacefully they do not lead to the proliferation of nuclear weapons. These countries have got the necessary materials from so-called civilian power plants and enrichment facilities fuelled by uranium. They have acquired the potential despite the international agreements that Senator Townley mentioned. International agreements are not worth the paper they are written on if countries like these can acquire nuclear weapons. Take India, for example. Did it not explode a nuclear weapon in May 1974, nine years ago? Do Senator Rae and members of the Liberal Party ignore that fact? Where did India get the ability to produce such a weapon? It got it from a reactor and from uranium provided by Canada and the United States of America which was intended for peaceful purposes .

The next myth about mining uranium is that the world is energy hungry and cannot survive without nuclear power. This is the third great false assumption. It is suggested that the world is so hungry for energy that unless we have nuclear energy we will be condemned to an impoverished life, particularly those people who live in the Third World. That is not the case. Nuclear energy provides only 9 to 10 per cent of the world's electricity. The International Atomic Energy Agency-hardly a left wing organisation-estimates that it will contribute less than 5 per cent of the energy needs of the less developed countries by 1990. I have been to such countries with Senator Rae. Does he really believe that those corrupt dictators in Indonesia and the Philippines would put nuclear power to the use and benefit of the poor and the peasants? Would the benefits not be limited to the big cities of Manila and Jakarta, so that the fat, rich and corrupt Indonesians and Filipinos could grow fitter, fatter and richer? To what extent would peasants benefit from such uranium development? I suggest that they would get virtually no benefit.

Of course Australia has an obligation to assist the less developed nations. It is wrongly assumed that technology such as nuclear power offers the only alternative. The vast capital costs of nuclear power reactors just cannot be accommodated by the fragile economies of many of the developing nations, especially those already saddled with massive foreign debts. There are alternatives to nuclear power. One of these, solar power, is now operating commercially in the United States. The Solar One power station provides 127 megawatts of power for domestic use.

The fourth great myth is that if we are to be a party to international safeguards we have to be involved in selling uranium. This is probably the most dangerous myth. Why do we have to be involved in the promotion of the nuclear fuel cycle to have a voice in the world calling for an end to the insanity of the nuclear arms race? I challenge both the Government and the Opposition-both of whom use this excuse to justify the expansion of the uranium industry-to explain this to the Senate. It has never been explained to me why, if we stopped mining uranium, our voice would be stilled in world councils. A person does not have to be a rapist or a victim of rape to talk about its indignity and horror. What is different in the case of uranium? Would someone please explain that to me?

International safeguards have been and have been seen to be an abject failure. Nuclear weapons have spread to new countries despite all international agreements. It is utterly irresponsible to contribute uranium to an international cycle that has increased the spread of nuclear weapons and will continue to do so simply for financial gain. That is the morality of the heroin pusher. Another speaker in this debate has already put this point of view. The heroin pusher is a despicable creature who sells for gain without any regard for the consequences, on the basis that if he does not sell it to drug addicts, someone else will. I submit with great respect that that is a morality of which a civilised country should not be proud.

In conclusion, let me put the subject of this debate into its proper context. The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, complimented Senator Rae. I concede that he spoke in a dignified and rational way, but one would have thought we were having an economic debate. One would have thought we were talking about the mining of coal or some other resource. This is not a topic restricted to local concern. It does not concern the future of a gold mine, a coal mine, a power station or even the Franklin River. This is a subject that involves the existence on this planet of life as we know it. That is what we are talking about today. As I speak here, 50,000 nuclear warheads are stockpiled by the super-powers for use against people. That figure is almost incomprehensible. From what other source do they come if they do not come from uranium-uranium that we mine, mill and export. As I talk in this Senate today, the United States of America has 12,000 atomic warheads targeted against the Soviet people. The Soviets have 8,000 atomic warheads aimed at the people of the United States, Europe and Japan. Let us not delude ourselves. At this moment the Soviets have nuclear warheads targeted against the people of Australia. Does anybody deny that proposition?

From where did these warheads come? They did not come from coal or oil; they came from uranium. Let me drive this message home to those fools who write soothingly in newspapers about the need for uranium mining. Each one of those 50 ,000 warheads is up to 80 times as destructive as the bombs that incinerated 200 ,000 people at Hiroshima and Nagasaki. If I am accused of being emotional, let me repeat that and see whether that sort of statement does not raise some emotions in people who listen. Each one of those 50,000 warheads has as much destructive power as all of the bombs released in World War II.

The shooting down of the Korean Air Lines jumbo last week surely shows us how easily those weapons could be used. The same mad general or group of generals who pushed the button to shoot down that Korean jet are the same generals who have the same sorts of powers over another kind of button which releases their nuclear toys against the other people of the world. They have their counterparts in the United States. The decision was made by a commander with a military mind, a mind that was programmed to respond only in a violent manner without regard for human life. That is a commentary on generals. Generals are trained to kill. Generals are trained to reach an objective by violent means. It is the only means they know. In the event of a larger conflict or threat the same military mind could well be itching to use his biggest and most favourite toy-the nuclear device. For him it would be as easy as downing the jumbo.

Those who believe that we have to flog our uranium to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons fail to see the lessons of history. Those who fail to heed history are bound to relive it. The world cannot continue to live with the arsenals of death which it has created and those potential arsenals which it has promoted. For those reasons the Australian Democrats totally, unequivocally and passionately oppose the mining, milling and export of uranium in any form for any purpose. For that reason we will be voting against the Labor amendment which calls for a responsible development of uranium because we do not believe that uranium can be developed responsibly. We will certainly be voting against the Liberal motion which praises the mining, milling and export of uranium.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government cannot accept the matter of urgency that has been put before the chamber by the Liberal and National parties . That matter of urgency has been expressed in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources, which is in the best interests of this country and the world.

The proposal must be rejected because we on the Government side cannot accept for one instant any suggestion that the previous Government acted in a responsible way and it is only a question of continuing that responsible attitude to the development of this uranium resource. It is certainly not a matter of urgency that the actions of that previous Government be continued and endorsed. In fact, it is a breathtaking audacity on the part of members of the Liberal-National parties to come into this chamber and claim, as a matter of urgency, that a responsible regime be put in place to govern the development of this uranium resource. In the seven years that they were in government they failed totally to do anything but take piecemeal, ad hoc decisions in relation to uranium development. At the end of their years of government this country was still without a legislative framework, a statutory formula, within which uranium resources could be developed if that were thought to be desirable.

As honourable senators will know, time and again the Liberal-National parties brought into this chamber amendments to the Atomic Energy Act which attempted to patch up a legislative framework that was conceived in the 1950s, in those Cold War years, when Australia's uranium resources from Rum Jungle were placed at the disposal of our allies for the development of their nuclear weapons programs. Year after year the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats pleaded with the Government to come up with a better statutory framework if indeed it were true that Australia's uranium resources might be developed for peaceful purposes and commercial profit. The Fox Ranger Uranium Environmental Inquiry recommended strongly against the use of that Act for the granting of an authority to Ranger to mine uranium. That recommendation of the Fox committee was never acceded to or implemented by the previous Government. The previous Government never responded to that key recommendation of the Fox report. Members of the Opposition now have the barefaced audacity to come into this chamber and say it is a matter of urgency that we get on with the development of this resource.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can stand aside and let somebody get back into government who will.

—The Opposition will not be back in government for many years. We intend to undertake consideration of the development. That consideration is essential. The failure of the parliamentary members of the Liberal-National parties to come to terms with the provision of a comprehensive, well thought out and well considered approach to this problem is not surprising. The party organisation behind them failed totally to grapple with this problem. There is one thing that can be said about the Labor Party: In a public and totally responsible way and at great pains and cost to ourselves, we, as a major political organisation, have tried to identify the dangers associated with the development of this resource. We have put forward certain criteria which must be fulfilled if that resource is ever to be developed. As I say, as befits a great national party seeking the allegiance of the Australian people we-and, I should say, the Australian Democrats-have tried to grapple with this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: During the suspension of the sitting for lunch I went to the Parliamentary Library and obtained a copy of the Liberal Party of Australia's federal platform . It is dated May 1982. Under the heading 'Energy and Natural Resources' I looked for some comment on what the political organisation thought ought to be the attitude of its parliamentary members and of the organisation generally in regard to the development of Australia's uranium resources. There was not one word. The word 'uranium' does not appear in the national platform of a party which purports to offer itself to the Australian people as an alternative government. I do not think there can be any more striking contrast between the Government and the Australian Democrats and the present Opposition coalition parties than that. The Opposition, as a political organisation trying to get the allegiance of the Australian people, has not attempted to grapple with the problems which we have identified.

The only point which the Opposition made in relation to the development of an energy policy is that the policy would be best effected by reliance, to the greatest possible extent, on competitive market forces, including the pricing mechanism, which is precisely the point that Senator Townley made; that is, in order to deal with our international debt problem, we should push ahead with this development as fast as possible. That is not the attitude of the Australian Labor Party. We say it would be quite irresponsible to press ahead with merely the international trading and profit motive in mind as the sole criterion.

I would say to the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Chipp, whose views on this I strongly respect, that equally it would have been irresponsible for us to come into government and to immediately, overnight, disrupt the townships which are dependent on the Ranger and Nabarlek mines, to immediately snatch away the livelihood of some 500 workers who are involved in those existing and operating mines. It would have been totally irresponsible to immediately and overnight put in jeopardy the arrangements of the Aboriginal communities which are dependent on the payment of several million dollars under agreements which were painstakingly arrived at. We intend to have more responsible and measured deliberation on these matters. I think Senator Chipp would concede that that is the proper way, as a national government, to go about our responsibilities in relation to these matters. We should take adequate time to ensure that the consequences of any decision are well thought out. In particular is this the case in relation to the international obligations of Australia.

In the Government's amendment to the motion we say that responsible development of Australia's uranium resources requires, amongst other things, 'measures to improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of nuclear non-proliferation safeguard systems'. As Senator Chipp so eloquently pointed out, there is no greater threat to the world's survival as a place where humanity can continue to unfold its history than the prospect of the nuclear holocaust which is so imminent. With the re-examination of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty which is to be undertaken in 1985 by the international community, it is extremely important that the Australian Government urges the countries presently adhering to that treaty to continue to do so and to try to encourage other countries to give their allegience to that international arrangement.

Mr Acting Deputy President, in relation to that you will be aware that this Government has, for the first time, appointed an ambassador for disarmament, Mr Richard Butler. His primary task will be to work on the Committee on Disarmament in Geneva. He has been given a very forceful directive by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) that he is to devote his energies principally to pressing Australia's view in relation to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. As Senator Chipp once again pointed out, there are a number of significant countries such as Argentina, Brazil, Israel, South Africa, India and Pakistan which are all in politically unstable areas and which are hostile to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and to the curbing of the desire of nations to acquire the technology to enable them to produce nuclear weapons. It is very important that Australia's voice be heard in those international forums. I believe that this Government is very responsibly trying to add its voice to the sanity which must prevail if we are all to escape the holocaust that hovers above human history in a way which might consume it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I compliment you on the first thing that you did, that is, appointing Richard Butler to that position.

—I thank Senator Chipp. I believe that it is more than a symbolic gesture. I believe that in fact it reflects a very real commitment on the part of the Government to ensure that disarmament matters are given a high priority in the decisions which the Government must undertake in this as in other areas. In relation to the question of storage and disposal of waste materials, I believe that any responsible government will try to accumulate all the relevant material, make its assessment of it and involve the Australian people in the decision-making process. In other words, the same information has to be made available to the Australian people so that they will then be able to make a judgment in relation to this matter. Only yesterday I think all honourable senators received on their desks an article entitled 'Australia's uranium and the international nuclear industry' by Professor Ringwood, the Director of the Research School of Earth Sciences, Australian National University.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Ringwood, in that paper, asserts that the synroc process which has been developed in the Research School of Earth Sciences at the Australian National University displays the capacity to immobilise high level wastes for periods exceeding one million years while the radioactivity decays to safe levels. He then goes on to put the case for the synroc method being a method proved as capable of safely disposing of wastes. In relation to that I went back to some remarks that I made in this chamber on 28 October 1982 on the presentation of the report of the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council . In that report which was put down in the Senate that day it was interesting to note that that Council, in relation to the synroc method of trapping wastes in a way which is said to prevent their leaching or movement into the surrounding environment, amongst other things, said that at present no radioactive waste had been incorporated in synroc. My impression had been that at least laboratory level tests had been undertaken incorporating radioactive waste in material. But according to the Council's report, no such laboratory tests, let alone any further pilot projects, had been undertaken. In other words, there has never been a full scale demonstration stage of the synroc proposal.

What I am saying in relation to waste disposal is that it is not only important that scientific experts agree that a particular method is capable of isolating and putting up impermeable barriers to the dispersal of radiation into the environment, but also it must be the case that any method is readily understood by lay people and by the general Australian community. I believe that the Australian Government is right to act cautiously and responsibly in relation to this matter. It will need to explain fully to the Australian community whether, in its opinion, a stage has been reached by scientific endeavour where the waste disposal problem has been adequately dealt with.

I believe that I have indicated that this Government is acting responsibly and cautiously in preparing itself to make the decisions which will be necessary in relation to the development of this energy resource found so abundantly in Australia. That decision will be made in light of the well articulated policy of the Australian Labor Party which, amongst other things at paragraph 64 on page 135 of our national platform states:
. . . a Labor government will-

(a) make a total commitment to exerting all possible influences on the development of creating effective international arrangements covering nuclear non-proliferation treaties, waste disposal, arms control and nuclear disarmament ;

In fact, the whole of that policy is well worth consideration. It will guide and determine the sorts of issues which the Government is presently addressing. To suggest that, as a matter of urgency, policies adopted and practices indulged in by the previous Government ought to be continued, is certainly not acceptable to Government senators. I believe it would not be acceptable to the great majority of Australians. I believe the Government enjoys the support of the Australian people in responsibly coming to an assessment of what ought to be done in relation to this resource. I believe that that responsible, cautious attitude ought to receive the support of this chamber.
