SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Final working document (for comment) June 1, 1983
URANIUM POWER AND THE PROLIFERATION OF NUCLEAR WEAPONS
A Report Preparedfor theAmerican Nuclear Societyby theSpecial CommitteeonNuclear Weapons and Peaceful Uses of Nuclear Energy
Chauncey Starr, Chairman Electric Power Research Institute
Vincent S. Boyer, Philadelphia Electric Company
Melvin J. Feldman, Oak Ridge National Laboratory
Edward J. Hennelly, E. I. duPont de Nemours & Co.
Myron Kratzer, International Energy Associates, Ltd.
A. David Rossin, Electric Power Research Institute
Gerald F. Tape, Associates Universities
John J. Taylor, Electric Power Research Institute
Preface

The American Nuclear Society (ANS) in 1982 appointed a Special Committee of four ANS past presidents and four senior members to evaluate how the increasing international use of uranium-fueled electrical power systems might influence the future proliferation of nuclear weapons states in current and foreseeable circumstances. Because the political, economic, military, and technical predispositions of each non-weapons nation are determining factors, this study focuses on the inter-relationship of those factors and their relevance to current United States policies.

Although many of the salient points presented in this study have been professionally addressed in the past, the Committee believes that the overview of the composite of the principal interacting factors presented here can provide a fresh and balanced insight to the subject. The Committee members, all of whom have long been involved with uranium power development, are aware of the complexity of these matters and have a diversity of thoughts on the details but, nevertheless, agree that this paper provides a substantive framework for future policy guidance.
In developing its recommendations, the Committee analysed three issues:

First, will the worldwide expansion of uranium power reactors-and their supporting fuel cycles-increase the future number of Nuclear Weapons States (NWS )? More specifically, will a Non-Nuclear Weapons State (NNWS) that obtains uranium power reactors to meet its electricity needs be more likely to embark on a weapons program than if it had its choices restricted to coal, gas, or oil?

Second, all existing weapons have been made from plutonium and uranium produced either in facilities originally designed to support military programs* or in large research reactors not part of electric power systems. Given the growing importance of economic efficiency in electricity generation, and the present separation of military programs from utility power plants dedicated to commercial electricity generation, is this historical separation likely to continue when civilian fuel cycle facilities become more widespread?

* The earliest electricity-producing natural uranium reactors (graphite or heavy -water moderated) were designed to be dual-purpose, primarily producing plutonium for weapons, with electricity as a byproduct. Most of these plants have either been decommissioned or converted primarily to electricity production .

Third, will the widespread use of uranium power, by simultaneously providing a potential source for weapons material and also for reducing dependence on expensive fossil fuels, decrease or increase the likelihood of world peace?
The Weapons Allure

Possession of a few nuclear weapons might be attractive to some nations as a symbol of power and prestige. It might be viewed as enhancing the image of national achievement and self-determination of national destiny, and it might create pride in the nation's ability to use high technology. Nuclear weapons may be seen as a long-term military investment because they are viewed as unsurpassable by any foreseeable technology, a perception that may soon be made obsolete by the continuing improvements in conventional weapons. Some also view the weapon as an ultimate threat to potential aggressors, as well as an intimidating leverage in international negotiations. We need only study the present posture of Pakistan vis-a-vis India to see the consequences of such views. These two countries apparently have strong motivations for currently maintaining their nuclear weapons options. There are, however, major political risks to acknowledged possession of nuclear weapons. For example, Israel has found it necessary to maintain an ambiguous image of weapons capability but not of readiness, and has stated that it will not be the first to introduce nuclear weapons into its region.

Most of the world's nations have not demonstrated an interest in acquiring nuclear weapons. They presumably recognise the doubtful military value of nuclear weapons or perceive no potential threat to their borders, or they are under the military umbrella of one of the superpowers (e.g., the Eastern Bloc countries under the Soviets, or Canada, Mexico, Germany, and Japan under the United States). Most of these nations have supported the Nonproliferation Treaty and have accepted fullscope safeguards. Some have sought weapons-free regions, and most have urged a reduction in the world's nuclear armaments.

There is a small category of countries, however, that apparently has chosen to keep open the option of a future weapon because they may doubt that the above conditions would adequately protect them (e.g., India). suspicions are frequently voiced about nations that have not ratified the Nonproliferation Treaty, have not accepted fullscope safeguards, or are politically volatile, e.g ., the countries of the Middle East, including Israel; the countries of Southeast Asia, including India and Pakistan; and Brazil, Argentina, Chile, and South Africa. All of these countries have publicly renounced weapons activities, although India has already exploded a ''peaceful'' nuclear device. It is these countries that concern the world community. Within these countries, interest in nuclear weapons is most likely to arise from complex considerations of national security, rather than from technical opportunity.

The widespread training and educational activities of the United States during the historic Atoms for Peace program (1950s and 60s) has created a pool of learned professionals in nuclear matters in most developing nations. The technical literature is extensive and current. The industrial systems and devices used for handling radioactive materials are now commonly available from many international suppliers. Further, the International Atomic Energy Agency ( IAEA) program for ''safeguarding'' civilian facilities provides only a periodic inspection audit of such facilities. For these reasons, safeguarding or denial of equipment or technology may deter weapons programs, but cannot prevent their inception. Recognizing both the value of international safeguarding as an alerting mechanism for diversion from civilian facilities and its limitations for preventing weapons acquisition, it is important to examine the international role of the uranium power plant exporting countries, particularly the policies of the United States.
Perspective on U.S. Policies

The emphasis in the United States during the 1970s on the possibility of diversion of plutonium from civilian uranium power systems has seriously distorted public debate in the United States, and has led to a polarisation of political positions. Those familiar with the technology generally hold that civilian uranium power has only a secondary relationship to the international political management of nuclear weapons proliferation. Opposing groups hold that , because civilian power and weapons are of the same genus (i.e., children of the nuclear fission process), the former could lead to the latter and so both are evil; thus, the ''no nukes'' phrase should be applied to both. Those idealogically antinuclear, of course, have exploited this latter perception. Nevertheless, there have been many who favor uranium power and, also, who are genuinely and deeply concerned with the potential for civilian activities to provide a route for weapons material.

The United States Congress' resulting concentration on the proliferation risk aspect of civilian uranium power plants give rise to the Nuclear Nonproliferation Act of 1978 (NNPA), which established strict export policies with respect to civilian uranium technology and fuel. It is interesting that Title I of the NNPA consist of two pages devoted to encouraging ''U.S. initiatives to provide adequate nuclear fuel supply'' in recognition of the international importance of this objective. Title I suggests studies, discussions, reports, and proposals to Congress, but no positive steps. Title II , ''U.S. Initiatives to Strengthen the International Safeguards System,'' contains slightly more than one page expressing intent to cooperate with the IAEA.

In contrast, Title III, ''Export Organization and Criteria,'' and Title IV, '' Negotiations of Further Export Controls,'' consist of 24 pages of minutely detailed instructions to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission on criteria for licensing exports under current agreements, as well as to the Executive Branch, both on the controls to be sought in new agreements and on those that require congressional review before exports of fuel can take place. Title III also authorizes the NRC, and in some instances the President or Congress, to intercede on exports, regardless of previous understandings. The impact of the NNPA is that the United States effectively maintains a unilaterial decision privilege on each export action, although in practice the majority of exports are licensed without difficulty. The complexity of the process and the opportunities for political intervention reduce confidence in the predictability of the outcomes.

As a result, the NNPA has been demonstrably counter-productive. The image of the United States has become that of an unreliable and unpredictable fuel supplier, thus encouraging other countries to create unilateral national fuel cycles, including both uranium enrichment and fuel reprocessing facilities. The renegotiation of contracts forced by the passage of the NNPA also deteriorated commercial relations based on mutual confidence.

The Nuclear Nonproliferation Act also symbolised a drastic alteration of the U. S. domestic policy for developing uranium power as a major long-term source of electricity. The Carter Administration took the position that if these same restrictive policies on the fuel cycle were applied domestically, the United States would set an example for the rest of the world. The fact that the United States was a major nuclear weapons country, with a military weapons program not dependent on its civilian electricity programs, was considered irrelevant by the U.S. Government to such example-setting, but not by the rest of the world. So the domestic U.S. uranium power program was held hostage and seriously damaged by the international image-making objective.

This subject was thoroughly investigated in a two-year international study entitled ''International Nuclear Fuel Cycle Evaluation'' (INFCE), during which the U.S. policy was explored and largely rejected by the 52 national groups involved. Unfortunately, the widespread notion that the growth of civilian uranium power would create more nations with nuclear weapons has remained. Many people in Congress and the general public are not aware of the options and realities of national decision making in non-weapons countries.

The 1970s' example-setting policy of self-denial of a domestic closed fuel cycle, forced on U.S. industry, failed to induce other nations to follow that course, although it did cripple domestic programs. It should now be evident that U.S. domestic policies must be determined primarily by domestic needs and priorities. This is a sound course, especially because the United States is already a major nuclear weapon state using dedicated military facilities, and the activities of the nation's domestic civilian program have no discernible effect on the U.S. weapons position.

As a result of past and current U.S. policy positions, it appears that a de facto moratorium continues on commercial reprocessing in the United States. The utility industry has been forced into the once-through fuel cycle, in spite of the policy support by the present Administration for commercial reprocessing and plutonium utilisation. The present stagnation is aggravated by the NNPA uncertainties on, and obstacles to, the reprocessing of foreign fuel from U.S.- supplied reactors. The unwillingness of the United States Government to accept reshipment and storage of spent fuel closes off that alternative. The only other non-domestic outlet for a nation is international spent fuel storage facilities, on which no action has been taken or is presently planned. This forced storage of spent fuel by both U.S. industry and those it has supplied may well increase weapons material availability as the result of the accumulation of large plutonium inventories in spent fuel assemblies, which become increasingly accessible with increasing storage time.

It is now evident that other countries are no longer looking to the United States to set a model policy for uranium power. The technology and planning leadership has been shifting to other industrialised nations in all areas of the fuel cycle, including enrichment and reprocessing, as well as in reactor experience and manufacturing, including the fast breeder. The lessening role of the United States in these areas of international commerce has substantially diminished the ability of this country to influence the policies of other nations.

During the 1960s and early 1970s, the United States had a coherent domestic program for the very long-term development of uranium power as an eventual major electricity source. The key elements included (1) encouragement of the commercial sale of light-water reactors to utilities; (2) improved technologies for reducing enrichment costs; (3) the demonstration of spent-fuel reprocessing to provide plutonium for recycle in light-water reactors and for inventory of fast breeders eventually; (4) the demonstration of permanent radioactive waste disposal through solidification and burial; and, finally, (5) the continuing development of power producing fast breeders as an ultimate electricity source. It was recognised that these interacting programs required a slowly shifting mix of private sector and federal participation, depending on the commercial viability of each part. Such a national plan undertaken by France has continued to make progress, and it is the clear intent of the Japanese to do the same.

It is now evident that in the light of foreseeable domestic needs, U.S. programs for uranium power should be redirected to the objectives of this earlier plan to fully develop all parts of a national uranium power system. If this were done, the U.S. capability to influence international weapons proliferation controls would be simultaneously increased.

For example, if reprocessing became available in the United States, spent fuel from U.S.-supplied reactors might be accepted from other countries. The separated plutonium might be recycled, used in fast reactors, or, for example, placed in an International Plutonium Storage Center. In this manner, both the '' aged'' spent fuel from other countries and the separated plutonium would be better controlled so as to remove their availability for weapons use.

It must be emphasised that all steps which encourage international trade in uranium power fuel under systems that permit nonproliferation controls also inherently contain the potential for applying fuel constraints by supplier nations if weapons programs are initiated. An ''assured fuel supply'' for civilian programs, administered apolitically (i.e., not held hostage to all kinds of negotiating pressures), must be subtly balanced against the imposition of measures that might interfere with national sovereignty. However, the fuel and reactor supplying states-and the United States in particular-should recognize the great potential value of international fuel trade under a system that supports nonproliferation controls. U.S. policies in the past decade have not been consistent with this view.

The fast reactor development programs of many advanced industrial countries offer a special opportunity for revitalising U.S. participation in creating an international approach to management of trade in nuclear materials and fuels. Fast reactor programs are long-term, and their cost and technology make joint efforts attractive for many reasons. In addition to the benefit of reduced future source requirements for each country, there are potential benefits to nonproliferation from the creation of a safeguarded commercial fuel market for plutonium, and from a cooperative program which might develop internationally accepted proliferation-resistant fast reactor fuel cycles. Therefore, a strong effort should be made by the United States to develop substantive cooperation with other countries engaged in fast reactor development. More importantly, the international institutional arrangements for nonproliferation controls in the trade of fuel materials should be developed in parallel with the technical development of the breeder. A balanced, comprehensive, and long-term U.S. fast reactor program is clearly a requisite for such a purpose. Obviously, a fully comprehensive domestic uranium power program offers many options for participation by the United States in international efforts to strengthen the existing separation of civilian and military activities in other countries.
Existing trends

Nations that have uranium power reactors already in operation on their electrical systems but have not openly indicated weapons activity now number 14, excluding the Eastern Bloc countries dependent on Soviet fuel. By the year 2000, there may be about 25 such nations. In the last eight years no additional nations have demonstrated nuclear explosives. To quote H. Gruemm, Deputy Director General of the IAEA:

''During the decade 1945 to 1954 three countries joined the nuclear weapons club (the U.S., USSR, and UK); during the next decade, two others followed ( France and China); and during the third decade ending 1974, one nation (India) exploded a so-called 'peaceful nuclear device'. Since then there has been no verified nuclear explosion by any State other than the NWS (Nuclear Weapons States) themselves. This decreasing rate of proliferation (or at least of horizontal proliferation) took place while the technology of nuclear energy spread rapidly throughout the world. In 1945 only one country had shown that it knew how to make and detonate a nuclear explosive; today probably some 20-30 countries are technically capable of doing so.

''It would, of course, be quite misleading to suggest that IAEA safeguards, which only came into operation on a significant scale in the late 1960s, have been the principal brake on nuclear proliferation or have had more than an ancillary role in this regard. The main reason why other countries have not followed, at least so far, the example of the NWS has been their perception that it would not be in their national interest to do so. However, it is reasonable to assume that the creation of the IAEA, the conclusion of the NPT and the Tlatelolco Treaty, and the development of IAEA safeguards have helped many NNWS (Non-Nuclear Weapons States) in assessing their national approach to nonproliferation. The assurance that NPT and IAEA safeguards give to the international community of continuing nuclear restraint on the part of the countries which accept safeguards on all their activities, has raised confidence and lessened the incentive of other countries to obtain nuclear weapons.''

Proliferation implies a relatively rapid increase in nuclear weapons states. This certainly is not the case now; no new country has carried out a known nuclear test since 1974, although suspicions recur that some nations may have undertaken preparatory steps for a weapons option. Many countries have the technical capability and spent fuel from power reactors but have chosen not to produce weapons, although it certainly is likely that they have studied such a course. The important questions of interest are whether the present abatement in weapons spread will continue, and what impact policies of the United States and other advanced countries might have on future decisions of the NNWS.
National options

Why have so many countries chosen to expand uranium power plant capacity for their electricity supply, and yet not chosen to add nuclear weapons to their arsenals? Consider first two major elements of national welfare: economics and military defense.

The major motivation for uranium power plants is the contribution they make to a peacetime economy by providing electricity at lower cost than alternatives and by permitting a reduced dependence upon imported fossil fuels. Except for the countries with ample indigenous low cost fossil fuel supplies, empirical evidence shows that the uranium power cost saving relative to fossil fuel power is large.

An equally important motivation is security of supply. Uranium power plants run a long time between fueling shutdowns (1-1 1/2 years for 1/3 core replacements) , so they are relatively insensitive to sudden international disturbances. Conversely, fossil fuel plants have inventories that are usually measured in weeks. Nevertheless, some countries do prefer to limit their future reliance on imports of enriched uranium fuel, looking instead to building domestic enrichment plants and spent fuel recycling facilities.

Nuclear weapons do not enhance a nation's economy or its security of energy supply. They may be viewed by some countries as contributing to their ultimate national military security, but this is a debatable point. For the two '' superpowers'', possession of large deliverable weapon inventories provides the deterrent of mutually assured response, with the objective of making war a ''no- win'' situation. It is not evident, however, that a small number of nuclear weapons has a significant military value for a developing country. The many small-scale wars that occur worldwide do not provide a military stage for effective use of nuclear weapons. In these circumstances an equivalent investment in conventional weapons would be more useful militarily. Even for the superpowers, emphasis is being placed on new conventional weapons. To quote Robert S. Cooper, Director of the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency1:
1''The Coming Revolution in Conventional Weapons,'' R. S. Cooper, Astronautics & Aeronautics, p. 73, Vol. 20, October 1982.

''The next generation of advanced surveillance systems and precision-guided standoff weapons may provide a conventional military power so formidable as to rival in the tactical arena the deterrent effect nuclear weapons have had on strategic war.''

Further-and perhaps most importantly-unless nuclear weapons are developed without external knowledge, preemptive action by neighboring countries might be taken in both military and non-military ways, and this might be very damaging to the national welfare. Most developing countries are very dependent on exports and imports for their survival. For this and other reasons, they are quite vulnerable to external actions, particularly by neighboring countries.

Even if a nation possessed a few nuclear weapons and the appropriate delivery systems, their use would be severely inhibited by the international opprobrium attached to ''first-use'' of such a weapon, as with the present attitude on biological weapons. Even a superpower like the United States is troubled by this issue in maintaining for NATO the current first-use option in Europe as a counter to the adjacent massive Soviet conventional and nuclear forces. For a smaller country, first-use might provoke both military and non-military international intervention with potentially drastic consequences.
The Basic Premises to this Study

In considering the issues described in the Preface, the Committee took as given several basic premises as to the future of uranium power and the technologic aspects of proliferation. These premises represent generally accepted views derived from many years of professional analysis and review presented at numerous meetings worldwide.

1. The growth of uranium power worldwide is continuing and is inevitable over a long term, especially in view of its competitive economic relationship with coal , oil, and gas, and the need by many nations for diversity of supply. Recently, for a variety of reasons, this growth of uranium power in some countries has been slowed by economic recession and uncertainties, political opposition, and regulatory delays, but long-term growth is expected to continue.

2. As the number of uranium power plants increases, there will be an increased need for fuel cycle facilities at the ''front end'' to provide fresh fuel ( enrichment plants) and at the ''back end'' to store the spent fuel or to recycle it through chemical reprocessing plants. These facilities can be physically separated from the power plants, as each facility usually can support many power plants. Thus, they may be operated either nationally or internationally to meet economic or political criteria.

3. Front end facilities are needed to provide low-enrichment fresh fuel for light-water cooled power reactors, and to provide purified heavy-water for natural uranium types. Fuel enrichment plant internal sequences can be altered to produce highly enriched U235, a basic material for weapon use. However, this is not done easily, and would be extremely difficult to conceal from safeguard inspectors.

4. Every commercial uranium power reactor creates a byproduct fissionable material, plutonium, which can be separated from the spent fuel. The isotopic quality of the product from present commercial power reactors will differ from that desired for optimum weapons manufacture, performance, and use; however, nuclear weapons explosions can be produced even from these poorer grades of material separated from today's power reactors, although such weapons have uncertain effectiveness, reduced confidence in initial performance, and added handling difficulties. The complications and uncertainties that would be added to a nation's initial weapon program by using spent fuel from power reactors as a source of weapons plutonium, would generally warrant the additional investment of resources, effort, and time required to produce good weapons-grade plutonium from systems dedicated to that purpose.

5. The technical experience appropriate for the design and operation of the front and back ends of the uranium power fuel cycle is also applicable to dedicated military activities. Even without the benefit of experienced people, a new group may perform adequately, as the needed technical literature is vast and readily available.

6. Because of the serious nature of a national decision to acquire nuclear weapons, it is likely to be planned as a deliberate multi-year program, and the options need to be considered on that basis. (The opportunistic ''overnight'' decision is discussed in the text, but does not appear to be logical, attractive , or likely.)

7. A system of safeguards (e.g., IAEA inspection and verification) can provide warning of a diversion of fissionable material and thus deter the misuse of civilian activities, but international safeguards alone cannot prevent a nation from acquiring a weapons potential-they can only deter.

8. In the more advanced developing countries, which have the technical resources to produce a nuclear explosive device, the denial of technology, fissionable material, or equipment may make a weapons program more difficult to achieve, but cannot stop it, and may create a national political challenge conducive to initiating a weapons program.
Weapon Material Options

Given a motivation to increase military strength, a nation must still make the decision of whether to put available resources into nuclear weapons or conventional weapons. The leadership must also decide the route for the acquisition of nuclear weapons, if it chooses that goal. For most nations, once a decision to acquire nuclear weapons is made, the acquisition of sufficient material, either U235 or Pu239, is a matter of time and available skills and resources. The basic technologies are well known, and there are a number of possible routes2. Diversion from the civilian power cycle is but one route. In general, the aggregated political and economic costs associated with diverting nuclear weapons materials from civilian-cycle spent fuel are likely to be much greater than the costs of a separate dedicated military program for the production of nuclear weapons materials. The dedicated military program has been and is most likely to be the preferred course for a nation seeking a nuclear weapons arsenal. The issues of nuclear weapons proliferation among nations preceded the growth of civilian power plants, and the concern would exist even if all civilian programs disappeared.
2 ''Nuclear Power and Weapons Proliferation,'' Chauncey Starr and Edwin Zebroski , American Power Conference, Chicago, Illinois, Vol. 39, 1977, pp. 26-33 (a detailed review of alternative paths).

Any non-weapons nation likely to embark on a costly weapons production and delivery system would wish as its centerpiece of these efforts a weapon of assured reliability and performance. A nuclear weapon made from reactor-grade isotopically mixed plutonium will involve increased fabrication and handling hazards, and its performance will be uncertain345. A further serious handicap arises if a weapons testing program is neither economically nor politically practical. However, if a non-weapons state is primarily interested in achieving ''international prestige'' without regard to the consequences, then reactor- grade material might be acceptable.
3W. Meyer, et al, Nuclear Safety, Vol. 18, 1977, p. 247.
4S. Sahin and J. Ligou, Nuclear Technology, Vol. 50, 1980, p. 88.
5C. Heising-Goodman, Nuclear Technology, Vol. 50, 1980, p. 242.

Facing these facts, a Non-Nuclear Weapons State must consider that its national allocation of technical and management skills, capital, military support systems , and political prestige domestically and internationally are all at stake. The organisation of such a program, involving technical industry and both military and civilian bureaucracies, is a formidable task for any country, especially if it must be undertaken in a clandestine manner. There is always the chance of public disclosure of a nuclear weapons program in a heretofore non-weapons nation, even if such a program can be initiated clandestinely. Moreover, exposure of the activity is much more likely if the civilian power cycle is interfered with in order to divert fuel. Thus, the political consequences of a disclosed nuclear weapons program move a national decision toward that clandestine route most likely to remain secret.

As an initial step to a national weapons program, leading scientists and engineers would probably be consulted on the alternative courses with regard to (1) availability of knowledge, skills, technical infrastructure, and industrial resources; (2) time required for producing the first weapon; (3) effective management of a clandestine project; (4) probability of success; (5) overall cost; and (6) probability of premature international disclosure of the technical operations through procurements and otherwise. A possible approach for the most cost-effective means of obtaining a reliable nuclear weapon might be to seize one from a stockpile of a weapons state; but this approach would likely be discarded for fear of an immediate military or other retaliation from the weapons state. Thus, the national decision makers would examine indigenous alternatives to weapons material production such as the following, with the preferred order depending upon the experience of the group and the facilities already available:
I. High expectations for reliable weapons performance and ease of fabrication.
(1) Enrichment of natural uranium to produce highly enriched U235, using any of the several available technologies in new or existing facilities.

(2) Production in new military facilities dedicated to weapons-grade plutonium, consisting of a low-temperature natural uranium reactor (graphite or heavy water ), and a small chemical separation Purex-type plant.

(3) Unloading selected low-burnup fuel from existing civilian power or research reactors by modification of their operation, and subsequent processing in a new dedicated Purex-type plant. Such operating modifications would most likely alert safeguard inspectors.
II. Lower expectations for initial weapon performance and more difficult fabrication.

(4) Diversion of normal burnup civilian reactor spent fuel and separation of reactor-grade Pu in a new military Purex-type plant. Safeguard inspectors, if present, would be sensitive to such diversion activity.

(5) Diversion of reactor-grade Pu from an existing commercial Purex-type plant under international inspection, if such a plant is in the country (an unlikely situation for a small nation), with the obvious risk of alerting the inspectors.

The actual choice of any of these routes would depend upon the specific national resources of skills, experience, industrial infrastructure, existing facilities, available time and money; and the balancing of these factors with the political risks of failure and international responses.

Finally, any group of scientists and engineers responsible for the success of a national mission would obviously prefer high-quality weapons material and would urge a proof-testing program for the first weapon design. If such a test program were not politically acceptable, there would be increased pressure for high- quality weapons material in order to improve the chances of having a usable first weapon.

Thus, a decision not to pursue a clandestine all-military route, but rather to obtain weapons material from existing civilian facilities would be political in nature rather than technical. The consequences of such a decision could be that international safeguard procedures would reveal the diversion; that other international alerts would develop; and that, when detected, the international response would be serious.

Today the options list would end here. However, if future use is made of suggested schemes for adulterating plutonium to downgrade its weapons usefulness , or for diversion hardening of civilian chemical separation plants and other fuel cycle facilities, then diversion of commercial fuel would likely become the most arduous route to follow. Adulteration and hardening would not only substantially increase the number or difficulty of the steps required to extract usable weapons material, but would also increase the likelihood of detecting diversion activity. Nevertheless, in secure parts of the world, today's reprocessing plants can be adequately safeguarded.

Because commercial-scale reprocessing of spent fuel is appropriate only for large uranium power systems, these will be economically justifiable for domestic use in only a few advanced industrial nations. However, several smaller non- weapons nations are building, or planning to build, small fuel reprocessing plants, presumably to obtain experience for the future. Because small separation plants are sensitive facilities, their detection and monitoring is essential. Safeguarding these operations will be as important as safeguarding commercial plants. The associated need is the safeguarding of long-term spent reactor fuel storage, which could be a plutonium resource for a diversion plan.

In some conceivable circumstances, the availability of civilian power facilities could reduce the additional facilities needed for a weapons capability. Thus, safeguarding civilian activities is a very important international endeavour to further inhibit their use for producing weapons material. International safeguarding would certainly alert the world if '' overnight diversion'' to extract plutonium from spent fuel was attempted for a quick and symbolic weapon.

To further separate the operations of civilian power from weapons programs worldwide, an apolitical and economically attractive fuel system should be established to provide any non-weapon states with the option of an assured fresh fuel supply, and to accept from these states their spent fuel (as the Soviets now arrange through their fuel leasing arrangements). The sensitive elements of the fuel cycle could thus be maintained in controlled domains, and the need for each nation to close the fuel cycle domestically would be removed.
Contribution to Peace and Stability

It should be pointed out to those who would do away with civilian uranium power on nuclear weapons proliferation grounds that such a course would be counterproductive in terms of their own objectives. The basic contributions that uranium power makes to international peace and stability include the following:

1. Uranium power offers to the developing world significant help in escaping from the highly destabilizing bondage of fossil fuels. Nature has been capricious in its distribution of fossil energy sources. This fact has already produced severe international tensions as nations vie with each other to ensure adequate oil supplies. Fiction writers and military strategists have postulated scenarios in which attempts to secure oil fields by use of conventional weapons could escalate into a nuclear holocaust. Even a modest uranium power program can result in an appreciable lessening of the tensions that accompany the quest for oil.

2. A second contribution of uranium power to international peace and stability relates to the NPT. This treaty, which has now been signed by 117 nations, involves as an important element a bargain struck on a global scale between three signatory nuclear-weapon states on the one hand, and a much larger number of non-weapon states on the other. The essence is that the non-weapon states agreed to forego nuclear weapons in return for two undertakings by the signatory nuclear-weapon states: to enter into serious arms control negotiations; and to provide technical assistance to the non-weapon states, particularly the less developed ones, with respect to the peaceful uses of uranium energy.

With regard to this latter obligation of the NPT, it should be recognised that if, in response to political concern about weapons proliferation, the industrial nations should be forced in the future to dismantle their domestic uranium power programs, and thus their reliability as fuel, equipment, and technology suppliers, their ability to provide support to the developing countries and to enforce safeguards would be seriously disminished. Such circumstances would actually encourage the spread of those facilities we seek to minimize.

3. A third benefit of uranium power to international peace and stability relates to environmental effects. The emissions from the worldwide combustion of fossil fuels are a matter of continuing concern because their alteration of the natural ecological chemistry crosses national boundaries and may affect natural habitats throughout the world. More uncertain in its potential long-term global effect is the growing accumulation of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, which theoretical speculation indicates might cause worldwide increases in temperature and major climatic changes. Uranium power offers a means of providing electricity without contributing to these environmental risks.
Conclusions

It must be emphasized that diminishing the motivation for weapons acquisition is the most important long-term objective for U.S. policy. Immediately important , however, would be a co-ordinated effort by the internaional community of nations to strengthen the economic and political barriers which inhibit additional countries from undertaking weapons acquisition programs. Clearly, the abandonment of co-operation in peaceful uses of uranium power would encourage uncontrolled and unsafeguarded national programs.

In summation, therefore, the common international policy of the reactor supplying states should be to (1) assist the developing countries in an efficient expansion and management of their uranium power plant capacity; (2) provide a system for an assured supply of fuel for these plants and for the handling of spent fuel; and (3) strengthen the international safeguarding system of civilian activities in order to discourage diversion of material for military use.
Turning to the issues raised in the Preface to this paper, the following conclusions are drawn:
(1) International trade in uranium power equipment and fuels will grow and will not be diminished by restrictive U.S. domestic activities or U.S. foreign policies.
(2) The reduction of U.S. activities in uranium power systems also diminishes U .S. influence in achieving prudent and appropriate international non- proliferation controls.

(3) The worldwide expansion of uranium power reactors has not been and will not in the future be an influential factor in determining whether additional nations will choose to become nuclear weapons states. Even in the absence of uranium power, the nuclear weapons potential would remain.
(4) If any nation decides to embark on nuclear weapons acquisition, it is most likely to follow the route of a dedicated military facility, rather than diversion from civilian power systems.

(5) The several benefits of uranium power are evident to developing nations, and the resulting reduction in energy resource importation and consequent enhancement of economic and internal stability and national security will contribute to a substantial reduction in conflict issues between nations.
It is clear that nuclear weapons proliferation is primarily a political issue related only marginally to uranium power development.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The last sentence of the document states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that nuclear weapons proliferation is primarily a political issue related only marginally to uranium power development.

It is very important for Senator Chipp and others to realise that conventional weapons which are just as deadly as atomic weapons are available. We have only to look at the satellite particle lasers which are now in orbit and have a huge destructive capacity not to mention chemical and biological weapons. I interjected when Senator Chipp was talking about the disposal of waste and he flattered me by saying that I was a self-professed expert. I do not think that but I do say that the technology associated with the disposal of waste is well advanced. The technology associated with the nuclear industry will very quickly reach the stage where the nuclear waste of today will be the nuclear power source of the future, with absolutely minimal environmental problems.

If Senator Chipp has not seen it, he may be interested in the disc that I have here, which is a little less in diameter than, and about the same thickness as, a 20c piece. It represents the accumulation of waste that would result from the provision of electricity for each individual in Australia in a full year if we were generating the electricity by nuclear fission methods. I also have interesting notes concerning the latest technology associated with storage. It revolves around the relatively insoluble borasilicate glass with which the nuclear waste is amalgamated and which renders the particular substance fairly inert. As was demonstrated earlier, other work is proceeding on other media such as synroc, which seems to be the scientific and engineering answer to the problem. Of course, having been glassified and vitrified, the waste is encased in concrete, and perhaps stainless steel, and lodged in geologically stable circumstances.

I also mention that in South Australia the Dunstan Government led the way as far as uranium enrichment was concerned. During its years in office, that Government went well along the track in presenting a case for South Australia to have a uranium enrichment plant. This was followed up very effectively by Mr Tonkin when he was in government. The Liberal Government successfully managed to get through the indenture Bill that enabled the Olympic Dam project to go ahead, with the help of course of Mr Norm Foster who crossed the floor and was subsequently expelled from the Labor Party for his interest in the development of that State.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak briefly in reply to the amendment and to identify what is happening. The position is that the original motion which I moved proposed that we consider as a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources, which is in the best interests of this country and the world.

The Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Walsh, for the Australian Labor Party, sought leave to move an amendment to that motion. It is not strictly possible for an amendment to be moved to an urgency motion, but leave was given for that to happen so that the matter could be clearly voted upon by members of this chamber. That was the reason leave was given for the Government motion, which would delete all words after 'urgency' and substitute the following:
Responsible development of Australia's uranium resources which requires:
(a) measures to improve the efficiency and the effectiveness of nuclear non- proliferation safeguard system;
(b) satisfactory arrangements for the storage and disposal of nuclear waste materials;
(c) mechanisms to ensure satisfactory safety, occupational health conditions, and environment protection within the mining industry in Australia.

The difference between the motion which I moved and the amendment put by the Government is that our motion states that it is a matter of urgency and in the interests of Australia and the world to continue the responsible development of Australia's uranium resources. In speaking to that I asserted that we had a proud record of achievement in regard to nuclear non-proliferation safeguards, nuclear waste disposal and environmental and health conditions, to ensure that the mining and export of uranium could be conducted with safety. The Government amendment implicitly denies this and states, in essence that the present nuclear non-proliferation systems are not adequate, that the storage and disposal arrangements are not satisfactory and that there are no adequate arrangements for health and environmental protection, all of which are propositions with which we disagree.

The record of the previous Government was such that those matters were considered important and were attended to. There is a record of achievement in relation to them. However, we are not saying that we do not agree that further steps are always necessary to achieve higher levels. We are proud of the measures that have been taken. For the reasons which I have outlined, we will oppose the Government amendment, which suggests that the measures already achieved are not adequate. We say that we are proud of those measures but believe that they can be improved upon. Continuous efforts should be made to improve upon those measures and achieve the highest possible level of safeguards in uranium mining and with regard to nuclear non-proliferation, the safe storage and disposal of waste and occupational health and environment protection. Therefore I take it that in closing the debate we will now proceed to a division on the motion for amendment put by the Government and then, if that is lost, proceed to a division on the motion I moved, as follows:
The continuation of responsible development of Australia's uranium resources, which is in the best interests of this country and the world.
That is my understanding of the procedure which will follow.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Walsh's amendment) be left out.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is a very important document which deserves close consideration and debate in the Senate at an appropriate time although, of course, at the moment we do not have that time. However, although the report contains a number of matters which are of departmental domestic interest and concern, some most important and valuable sections of the report deal with international relations and Australia' s participation in those areas of the world with which we are concerned. In particular, I have been struck by the assessment made by the Department of Foreign Affairs in the independent departmental report before us of the world situation as at the date of preparation of the report. That assessment is clearly still relevant. I propose to muster a few quotations from this report which I think give us great cause for concern. Page 1 of the report states:

International relations are more disturbed and less predictable than at any time in the last 30 years. The underpinnings of international order, mutual understandings between the superpowers and the structure and functioning of the system of international organisations are less stable now than in any period since the Second World War.

The report goes on to provide, in my view, a very clear analysis of the major reasons for the destabilisation that has so grossly occurred and which is the subject of that very serious comment. The report refers on page 2 to the areas of Soviet interference in Poland, Kampuchea and Afghanistan and, of course, other destabilising activities associated with the communist world, namely, the Cubans in Angola. At pages 12 and 13 it points to recent Soviet statements on arms control and the intensification of the Soviet Union's propaganda campaign to take advantage of the intense political debate on arms control now taking place on both sides of the Atlantic. Further, on page 20, it talks of the international climate in 1982 being 'not conducive to productive negotiation on arms control and disarmament'. It states:
Mutual trust and confidence are required before this can happen. Soviet policies exacerbated international tensions as a result of the development, production and deployment of weapons systems-
It mentions in particular the mobile SS-20s targeted on western Europe, the continuing Soviet presence in Afghanistan and the situation in Poland.

The report points quite clearly to the basic reason for Soviet expansionism, aggression and provocation and an unwillingness to participate seriously in arms control negotiations. It participates, but not in a co-operative way. When we are faced with the barbaric act against the Korean airliner which we debated in the Parliament yesterday, I think we should take very sobering note of that act and place it in the context of the problem that the world faces, which the Department of Foreign Affairs has pointed out to us is probably the worst that we have faced for 30 years. It is a very great comfort to note that the Department identifies the crucial need for Australian foreign policy-to maintain a basic unity and strength with the Western alliance. I would like to develop the question posed by this threat and the solution that is so clearly necessary for us at all times to understand and promote. I seek leave to continue my remarks at a later stage.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak on the report of the Australian Maritime College. I wish to refer briefly to one matter. It involves the qualification or comment made by the Auditor- General in relation to the financial statements of the College. The Auditor- General said:

SPEECH.PARA: I also report that in my opinion the value of the asset, Training Vessels, is overstated in the Statement of Assets and Liabilities by the amount of a bounty of $983,390 paid by the Commonwealth Government to the shipbuilder, and the balance of the Statement of Capital Accumulation is similarly overstated. Note 9 refers. I consider that the value of the asset should be shown at its cost to the College, namely $4,012,967.

The question arises of how a bounty is dealt with so far as the assets of the acquiring body is concerned. When it purchases a ship a bounty is paid by the Commonwealth. Is the asset taken in at the total construction cost or the net cost to the person acquiring it? It seems to me to be a rather extraordinary situation that when a bounty is paid the Auditor-General says that the full value should not be taken but only the net cost to the purchaser or acquirer of the asset. The Maritime College is most regretful that it became embroiled in the middle of this matter. It took advice as to what way its accounts should be prepared. Having taken advice, departmental amongst others, and received one sort of advice it then received comment from the Auditor-General that its statements ought to have been prepared in a different way. It found itself in the middle of an argument which held up the preparation of its accounts and amounted to a form of qualification.

I suggest that the way in which a bounty is dealt with in the financial statements of a statutory authority-I think the matter is likely to arise from time to time-ought to be given further consideration by the appropriate committee of the Senate. I believe the appropriate committee is the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations. I invite that Committee to give thought to seeking a reference in relation to this matter. The situation seems to be such that a perfectly responsible body such as the Maritime College, which has done an excellent job-I totally support what Senator Archer has said about the achievements it has already notched up-can be thrown into a state of confusion and be involved in considerable cost and delay in the presentation of its financial statements when it has this sort of situation thrust upon it through no fault of its own. It seems that somebody ought to clarify once and for all in what way such a bounty should be dealt with and a direction should be given to all statutory authorities with regard to that matter.

Finally, I would like to make the comment that the Maritime College this year ran an international symposium on safety at sea which was attended by people from all over the world. It was an extremely successful international event. I compliment the Maritime College on its achievement and hope that it is the first of many such international functions to be conducted at the College and through the auspices of that excellent body. I thank the Senate for the opportunity of speaking to this report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The material provided is essentially an exchange of letters between the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Premier of Queensland in relation to the financial year 1982-83 and the continuation to the end of that financial year of the Commonwealth's commitment to the Burdekin Dam project that had been undertaken by the previous Commonwealth Government. However, since that date the Commonwealth Government has made statements about the expansion of funds for the Burdekin Dam project of a quite considerable kind. In Queensland, my own State, mention of this issue has caused, probably more than anything else, a feeling that we are about to have an election. Indeed, this project has been a fairly standard election gimmick; it is on again, off again. It is extremely gratifying to see that at last development of the project may be taken out of that area and that work may begin in earnest.

However, I point out that we are now in an extremely difficult situation with regard to the dam; one to which, I believe, we ought to pay close attention. The dam's original specifications and development plans were prepared on a dual premise. The first part of that premise was that reticulated water would be provided to the growing urban centres of north Queensland, in particular to Townsville. However, a week or two before the Prime Minister announced in north Queensland the increased funding for the Burdekin Dam, there was also an announcement about the second stage of the Ross River project which essentially would provide Townsville with water well into the year 2000, at least at its current projected rate of growth. If we except Townsville and look at the other growth centres in north Queensland, we see that none of those could provide the basis for any substantial need for an urban water supply well into the year 2000 .

We then turn to the second use for which the dam was originally projected-the further development of the cane industry in the Burdekin River area. As honourable senators know, the Burdekin River area is the most productive sugar area in Australia, both in gross terms and in terms of production per acre. It seemed then a reasonably good idea that development of cane in that area, which has already shown its economic viability and very great profitability, ought to be expanded. Since that time the international sugar scene has changed extraordinarily. It is not a matter of cyclical rise and fall. There is now a fairly reasonable projection that the international sugar market will not return to the buoyant times we have seen in the immediate past, for two main reasons. One is that the European Economic Community, through its internal agricultural support mechanisms, has turned the EEC from a net importer to a net exporter of sugar in the last five years. That situation is unlikely to be reversed. Those who know the working of the agricultural mechanisms within the EEC know how closely held that whole package is in terms of the common market agreement.

The other factor influencing the international sugar scene is the deliberate policy decisions made by a number of countries to move to a point of self sufficiency. Amongst those countries is Indonesia. In the 1950s it had been an exporter but dropped to become a very large importer of sugar. It is now rapidly moving to the point of being self-sufficient as are a number of other major countries. The international sugar scene is such that the excess of sugar above world consumption goes on to the stockpile every year. Therefore, it is unlikely that even in the short or medium term there will be a return to the buoyant years of the international sugar market. Consequently, water from the Burdekin Dam cannot be used for the purpose of growing sugar. I believe it is now extremely important that there be close deliberations and planning for the further development and use of water from the dam which is being developed. We should ensure that we do not in fact have another episode of what happened with the Ord River.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the advantage of reading the paper which is before the Senate and therefore I make some preliminary remarks and indicate that I will seek leave to continue my remarks. A number of statements have been made today and in recent times in this Parliament to the effect that somehow the arrangement under the previous Government for building the Burdekin Dam had been tentative and the dam was purely an election issue that cropped up from time to time. I quite clearly want to put that suggestion to rest. In point of fact, quite firm arrangements had been made in respect of the sharing of the costs. The Commonwealth Government was to bear the cost of the construction of the dam itself. The Queensland Government was to bear the cost of any preparatory work and any downstream and ancillary work. Equally, the Commonwealth Government had in fact allocated an initial sum of money for the current year as had in fact the Queensland Government. I rely on memory, but I think the Commonwealth Government's contribution was of the order of $6m and the Queensland Government's $7m or $8m. A substantial amount of money had been allocated in the current year. Equally, in announcing the bicentennial program, the Commonwealth Government made it abundantly clear that in current prices the dam would attract approximately $80m of Commonwealth money. So I want to emphasise that the dam had in fact been commenced-the financing had been arrranged and the project was afloat at the time of the election. Since I would like to refresh my mind on the paper, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I just wish to make a couple of brief remarks in relation to the National Water Resources (Financial Assistance) Act and the Burdekin Dam project. As the previous speaker Senator Sir John Carrick said, it is very difficult to comment to any great extent on this paper because it was not available to honourable senators prior to its being listed for presentation. This project, which is pretty dear to the hearts of the people of north Queensland, has been used as a political football over a long period.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not able to comment directly on the paper because, as I said, it has not been available. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

If I am not mistaken, it appears to me that this is the first time that a document has been tabled by a Minister in this form. As I understand it, on previous occasions a list of treaties has been simply tabled. However, the document before us summarises what the treaties are about and, as such, is an advance on the previous practice. Subsequent to the High Court decisions in the Tasmanian dam case, I referred to the fact that the Ponsonby rule applies in the United Kingdom wherein the government tables in the Parliament all treaties 21 days prior to their ratification. Of course, in the United States of America the President requires the advice and consent of two-thirds of the United States Senate prior to the making of a treaty. That, of course, will be the subject of consideration when I bring in the treaties Bill at a later stage. In 1961 the Australian Government gave an undertaking to the Parliament that it would lay all treaties before Parliament 12 sitting days before their ratification. In fact, the spirit of that undertaking has not been adhered to by recent governments and that is why I intend to introduce the treaties Bill.

In the meantime, I am pleased to see that the Government has taken this matter a little forward by tabling a document which contains a summary of treaties. I believe that such a step is important. However, I also believe that sufficient opportunity has not been given for proper consideration of the treaties. I will be elaborating on the reasons for that at a later stage. I do not believe it is proper for me to do so on this occasion. During the parliamentary recess a treaty about which there was a great deal of public debate, received ratification. I for one was concerned that an attempt should be made to ensure that an opportunity be given for that treaty to be the subject of debate in this Parliament in the fullest sense. That opportunity is not given to us when treaties are tabled in this way. It is my intention to seek to rectify that. However, I congratulate the Government at least for preparing a summary of the treaties and tabling them in this manner. It is an advance on what has occurred previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Senate's attention should be drawn to the fact that information relating to 16 treaties has been tabled for the purpose of informing both Houses of Parliament of the actions taken by Government with respect to certain treaties, exchanges of documents and agreements. This represents the first step which was referred to by Senator Harradine. Some 16 matters are being brought to the attention of the Parliament. Twelve were initiated in the life of the previous Government. Only four of the new arrangements were initiated by this Government. I think it is true to say their tabling represents a forward step.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it should be pointed out to the Senate that the documents concerned are the responsibility of the Executive Government rather than of the Parliament as such. It may be, of course, a question of some debate as to whether the Parliament as such should have the right to set aside arrangements that are entered into between governments. I make that distinction. They are arrangements , treaties and exchanges of notes that represent agreements between governments as such and not parliaments as such. In that sense, I think it would probably have to be conceded that the Parliament is being kept informed, for the first time, of the precise nature of the arrangements that are represented in the 16 documents which have been presented. Hitherto, they have been largely represented in the form of Press releases or statements without the Parliament officially being informed. To that extent, I think the Government is to be commended. I think we have to accept the fact that the Executive Government, which has a mandate, has the authority and responsibility of entering into arrangements at a governmental level.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to make a few remarks in respect of the tabling of the information about 16 treaties. I certainly welcome the fact that some advance is being made, in that the Parliament is being given more information than it has previously been given in relation to these treaties. However, I think that a great deal more thought, attention and work has to be done to give Parliament a greater role in the process of the consideration and ratification of treaties. In that respect, I am particularly interested in the fact that Senator Harradine has foreshadowed that he will be introducing a Bill which would cover treaties. That is a matter which honourable senators in this chamber will have to consider closely. I hope the measure will come on for debate in the near future.

SPEECH.PARA: Certainly as a result of the decision of the High Court of Australia in the Tasmanian dams case, it has become apparent not only to the Parliament but also to the people themselves that the enormous executive power which is contained in the treaty making and ratification process is one to which this Parliament itself will have to pay great attention. I hope that the Government will extend the form in which it presents this material. I think the Senate would have been assisted if the schedule had been appended to a general statement. It could have explained over what period of time the treaties were entered into and could have given a little more information about the various categories and so on. At least this is a step in the right direction. The question of-

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON SCIENCE, TECHNOLOGY AND THE ENVIRONMENT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -The Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment has resolved to resume the inquiry into land use policy which was commenced by its predecessor in the last Parliament under terms of reference given it by the Senate on 5 June 1981. The Committee will pursue its inquiry under the following terms of reference:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for a co-ordinated approach to major land use problems in Australia, with particular reference to:
(a) the impact on the Australian environment of current land use policies; and

(b) the development of a co-ordinated national approach to land use policy having regard to the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth, State, Northern Territory and other territory and local governments.

Prior to the lapsing of the inquiry with the dissolution of the Thirty-second Parliament, a total of 196 submissions had been received, and five days of public hearings had been held. The Committee's interest in land use policy is longstanding, going back to its 1976-77 inquiry into woodchips and the environment.

We believe that the inquiry should focus, not so much on actual land use problems, but on what the Commonwealth can do to mitigate problems and on whether a national, co-ordinated approach to land use policy formulation could help in their resolution, bearing in mind that the States and the Northern Territory have exclusive constitutional power in many land use matters. After discussing the land use policy, the Committee felt that because of the number of submissions received and the public hearings held it was important to those who represented that section of the community that the Standing Committee on Science , Technology and the Environment conclude the report on land use policy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clause 20 (Dissolution of marriage).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be most difficult for the public, let alone members of this Committee, to follow this debate by reason of the fact that we are chopping and changing and debating other matters in between. A suggestion has been made that the Senate should meet on Friday of next week or the week after to have a good go at discussing the Family Law Amendment Bill and to have the matter thoroughly canvassed and debated. I certainly would be in support of that proposition, because I do not think that either the Bill or any of the proposed amendments are being given the attention which they deserve.( Quorum formed) It is most difficult for members of this Committee to follow what is being discussed in regard to this legislation because at present, I understand, some senators are attending two Senate committee hearings and are not able to listen to any of this debate. I believe this is the reason that this matter, which is a very important matter, should be dealt with at a special sitting of this Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Since the Government has chosen to have consideration of the Family Law Amendment Bill interwoven with other business, it falls to me to continue with the attempts that are being made to ensure some legislative support for the institution of marriage. The purpose of amendment (19) is to achieve that. It seeks to repeal section 48 of the Family Law Act, which enables a dissolution of marriage on the ground of irretrievable breakdown, defined as 12 months separation. That section of the Act is inconsistent with section 43, which defines marriage as:
. . . the union of a man and woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you listen? It doesn't do that at all. It is a definition of marriage.

—I thank Senator Missen. One point that has been brought against the proposal I am making is the one that has been suggested by Senator Missen and one which he suggested in his speech in opposition to this amendment. What he virtually says is that in section 43 of the Family Law Act the definition of marriage as 'the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life' is not the legal definition of marriage.
—That is right.
—I refer Senator Missen to section 46 of the Marriage Act, which I referred to in my speech in support of this amendment. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . before a marriage is solemnized by or in the presence of an authorized celebrant . . . the authorized celebrant shall say to the parties, in the presence of witnesses the words-
''I am duly authorized by law to solemnize marriages according to law.

''Before you are joined in marriage in my presence and in the presence of these witnesses, I am to remind you of the solemn and binding nature of the relationship into which you are now about to enter.
Senator Missen should listen to this part:
''Marriage, according to law in Australia, is the union of a man and a women to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life.''

That puts to rest the canard brought up by Senator Missen and others throughout the debate on this matter. It is quite clear that that is what marriage is according to the law of Australia. If that is the case-as is quite clearly stated in section 46 of the Marriage Act and in section 43 of the Family Law Act -section 48 of the Family Law Act, which provides for the dissolution of a marriage after 12 months separation, deserves to be deleted and something should be inserted in its place.

TALK.START.PARA: —But you are not suggesting it should be binding for life, are you?

—I am suggesting that there should be some form of objective test and that an arbitrary period of 12 months separation is not sufficient time to allow those who have committed themselves to the care of each other and their children to give the marriage a go.
—On your argument, you should be wanting to abolish divorce altogether.

—As I have said in my speech in support of this amendment, we live in an imperfect society and we, as legislators, must recognise that fact. In recognising that fact we should not create a situation whereby clear, patent injustices result. Under the present provision, such clear and patent injustices do result. The injustices result, for example, from the fact that one of the partners to the marriage can deliberately desert the other partner and then file an application for the dissolution of that marriage without the consent, and sometimes with the positive dissent, of the other partner. That, of course, creates a number of problems.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sorry Senator Tate is leaving because I wanted to deal with his matter in a moment. I am attempting to ensure that there are some objective tests and that , on the basis of those objective tests, application can be made by one of the parties. The amendment would not interfere with the concept of the agreement between the partners to the marriage where they separate and thereafter live separately and apart for a continuous period. In my amendment I suggest that that period ought to be two years. It would not interfere with that concept. This amendment would bring into the situation a recognition of the fact that there are many people for whom the Family Court is simply an administration of injustices. I believe that if we as a legislature continue to accept section 48 as it stands, we will be doing an injustice not only to the people who feel such grief about it all but also to the institution of the law.

I come to the point made by Senator Tate in opposition to my amendment. He indicated that I am attempting in some way to mislead the public as to the causes of marital breakdown. I did not say that the law is the cause of marital breakdown, not at all, though Senator Tate ought to recognise, as everybody else does, that the law has a teaching role. The fact is that the law does provide the means for dissolution and it provides that means in such a short period that the partners to the marriage do not have a chance to ensure that the marriage continues or that reconciliation can take place. I have other amendments relating to reconciliation which might assist in that regard.

The other matter treated with some sort of ridicule by the lawyers in this place concerned the reason why the amendment refers to an objective test being the fact that, since the mariage, the other party to the marriage has committed continuing adultery. Some people must have strange minds. As I said in my opening address, all but the most promiscuous of societies recognise that continuing adultery is a breach of the marriage bond.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do they?
—Senator Missen asks: 'Do they?' Does the honourable senator recognise that?
—My views are probably like yours, but that is irrelevant.

—This is an attempt to ensure that adultery as such is not a ground for dissolution. As Senator Teague said, the spirit of reconciliation and forgiveness is one which should be engendered within marriage, but obviously continuing adultery is a serious breach. The statement made by the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) that these further grounds will mean quicker divorces is absolute nonsense. Paragraph (c) provides for a two year period, (d) provides for a two year period, and paragraphs (a) and (b) deal with matters about which there will be contest and with which the Family Court and its apparatus could not possibly deal in a period of less than one year.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of points in relation to Senator Harradine's proposal. For some considerable time I was Deputy Chairman of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act and I think it is important to impress on people such as Senator Harradine the evidence that was presented to the Committee. Most of that evidence was that we cannot turn back the clock, we cannot go from a no-fault situation to a fault situation, and it is not desirable so to do anyway. We are living in a real world. We are not just talking about those people who happen to be in the rarified atmosphere of this chamber. We are talking about those real people outside who have real problems in that their marriages have been irretrievably broken down for a period of 12 months. These people do not want to live together; they do not want to get back together. They are concerned about the effect their feelings for each other are having on their children, because the first person to know that a marriage has broken down is the child of that marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: The child is so perceptive of parents' attitudes to each other that more frequently than not the child is the first person to be aware that there is a rift in the marriage. The child is affected the whole time those people are either in that state of living together but not wanting to, staying together because of the welfare of the child, or living apart for an extended period with the child not knowing which parent will have custody. Those are very real and important considerations to be taken into account when considering amendments to the Act. If children are forced into a situation where they have that dispossessed feeling for a period longer than the 12 months, even more damage is done to the children whom Senator Harradine says he wants to protect. If we really have concern for the children of a broken marriage then we must recognise that the best thing for the children is to have the divorce clear cut.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why there are further amendments being put in. You have missed them.
—I am not discussing further amendments; I am discussing this particular amendment because it is the one to which we are directing our attention.
—You cannot deal with it in isolation.

—I am simply making the point that no more than we can reintroduce fault can we reintroduce an extended period for separation. The only fault is irretrievable breakdown of the marriage. That was the conclusion of every single witness who came before the Committee.
—It was not.
—The honourable senator should go back over the Hansards and see what was said. We had information from people who worked in the community centres; we had information from Catholic priests.
—It was the overwhelming evidence.

—That is right; that was the overwhelming evidence. One per cent may have agreed with the attitude of Senator Walters but 99 per cent agreed with the attitude I am expressing now.
