I sat in on as many of those Committee meetings as Senator Walters did. The reality of the situation is this: We cannot turn back the clock. There is no need for us to turn back the clock. If a marriage has broken down let the divorce be as clean as possible. If we go back to a fault situation we will have all the dirt that we had before when the lifeblood of the newspapers was attending the divorce courts. Honourable senators will see that later on in the amendments is a recommendation for the opening of the courts. Once again, the Press will feed on that.
—But no names.
—The Press has a very nice way of describing people without mentioning names or characteristics. It says: 'The wife of an Army officer living in Booragoon'.
—Read the amendment. It says no identification.

—The Press does not have to identify a person. It can identify by imputation. It has been done before and it will be done again. If we take the advice of all those very competent people who came before the Joint Select Committee we must recognise that we cannot extend the period of the separation any more than we can bring back the fault clause and say that one party has to be proven to have committed adultery which, I notice, is one of the suggestions made by Senator Harradine.
—Continuing adultery.

—Even continuing adultery. Whether it is continuing or not, I do not want it to be a reason why we should not allow people to divorce if they cannot live together. One of the parties to a marriage is the person who can determine whether she can live with her partner or whether he can live with his partner. If either one of them determines that the situation is such that he or she cannot, that person should be quite free, at the end of 12 months, to make application to the Court for a divorce.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. I thank Senator Coleman for her comments. As I understand it, amendments will be coming forward about the need to resolve custody matters prior to the decree nisi being made. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) in his speech, recorded at page 186 of Hansard, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliamentary Joint Select Committee received many submissions advocating extension of the period of separation required for divorce on the grounds that this would enhance the possibility of reconciliation. However, the Joint Committee accepted the evidence of those working in the area of marital therapy- I refer to marriage guidance organisations, the Family Court counselling service and the marriage guidance councils . . .
Evidence was presented to the Committee and evidence has been presented to me also. I just wanted to mention those points.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my short speech earlier today I foreshadowed an amendment consequent upon the amendment moved by Senator Harradine which has just been lost on the voices. I indicated, in opposing Senator Harradine's amendment, that I did so because I do not believe in the reintroduction of the fault ground, as was contained in Senator Harradine's amendment. However, I am not satisfied and have never been satisfied with the simple one-year separation as the sole ground for and as proof of the irretrievable breakdown of marriage which is, in fact, the basis of dissolution under the Family Law Act. In other words, irretrievable breakdown is established only by a one-year separation. As I said earlier today, I believe there are two weaknesses in that approach. The mere fact of separation of one year is not adequate proof of irretrievable breakdown. As no other methods are provided for proving irretrievable breakdown, I think it is necessary to have a longer period of separation.

SPEECH.PARA: When the Family Law Bill was first in the Senate in 1974 I moved the same amendment as I intend to move now, that is, that there should be a period of two years separation. That seems to me a more realistic way of establishing that single ground. Events since the Act was passed by the Parliament-it came into force at the beginning of 1976-have certainly added to the concerns that I felt in 1974, nine years ago. I believe also that the availability as a ground for divorce of a period of separation as short as 12 months is leading people to take a more cavalier attitude to marriage and their responsibilities in it. Earlier today we considered what were called young marriages, that is, marriages of only three years duration. It was suggested that they could not be dissolved except in special circumstances. Although I do not agree with that provision, there is a widespread concern that people are getting married and, after a comparatively short time, they are separating. They do not give the marriage a chance. That they can get a divorce after 12 months separation in itself is assisting this cavalier attitude to marriage and the responsibilities that it gives people to each other and, of course, to their children.

I believe that if a period of two years separation were provided for it would have the effect of encouraging people to give more attention to their responsibilities, to work at their marriages a little harder and to bring to their minds the really serious consequences the law attaches to divorce. We should say to people: 'You have to be separated and apart for two years before the law will recognise that your marriage has irretrievably broken down'. On those grounds we should now take the step of extending the separation period from the existing one year to two years. Accordingly I move:
Page 14, clause 20, at the end of clause, add the following word and paragraph:
''; and
(c) by omitting from sub-section (2) '12 months' and substituting '2 years'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The forces of light on this side of the chamber would oppose the Durack amendment. I hasten to add that this is not a disciplined Government response; it is another free vote matter.
—You are therefore speaking for yourself.
—Therefore I am formally speaking only for myself, but I understand the sentiments on this side of the chamber.
—You are the only force of light.

—I am about the only person from the Government side in the chamber at the moment. Therefore I think the honourable senator is safe in that assertion. I, in any event, oppose Senator Durack's amendment, again appreciating the sincerity with which he put his point of view, a point of view which is shared by many people. As Senator Harradine said, a number of people made representations to the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act for an extension of the period of separation from the present 12 months to two years for the kinds of reasons which Senator Durack has advanced today.

SPEECH.PARA: The really fundamental difficulty, however, which any such proposition faces is that the overwhelming weight of the professional evidence-the evidence of those working actively in the area of marital therapy, marriage guidance organisations , counsellors and so on-is that the prospect of estranged spouses reconciling does not increase with the time available but rather diminishes with the time that they remain separated. Up until the period of about 6 months separation, the evidence-it has been tabulated and placed in the Committee's report at paragraph 3.44-is that properly and sensibly conducted professional counselling can have considerable success in bringing people back together again. But once that tipping point of around six months is passed the prospect of a successful reconciliation being achieved rapidly diminishes. It was with that thought and that evidence in mind, essentially, that the original figure of 12 months was struck. It was very much with that thought in mind, and the evidence to which I have referred behind it, that the Joint Select Committee recommended that 12 months should remain as an appropriate period.

To the extent, again, that overseas experience is relevant in coming to grips with these difficult problems, it must be said that all the evidence available to me is that in Britain, Sweden and West Germany, and in those European countries which have been grappling with these problems, the move has been towards the kind of situation which we now have in Australia-irretrievable breakdown as evidenced by a period of separation which, in the jurisdictions which I have mentioned, either is or has been recommended to be a time period of around six to 12 months rather than any more substantial period. I think the weight of that overseas experience must take its place in our deliberations.

But more particularly the point is the one that I began with: There is no evidence to support the intuition some people have that a longer period of separation requirement would, in fact, enhance the prospect of reconciliation, of bringing people back together. There is just no hard evidence to support that kind of intuition, however well motivated those people may be who express that point of view.

There is one other quick point I wish to make in favour of retaining the 12- month period. At the moment a great deal of hardship is being experienced by people having to wait for the full 12 months to expire before they can obtain their dissolution in order to get court orders relating to property divisions where there is real contest between the parties. We will try to get over that in the Family Law Amendment Bill by putting forward an amendment to give the Family Court of Australia jurisdiction to make property orders before the formal dissolution process has, in fact, been accomplished, to enable orders to be made where the parties cannot agree among themselves to do so for the matrimonial home to be sold and the proceeds distributed, and in other ways to make some financial arrangements for the benefit of both spouses. If, however, that particular amendment, which is of somewhat uncertain constitutional pedigree, should be struck down by the High Court of Australia, we will be faced with a situation where, once again, as the law now stands, the parties will have to wait 12 months before the Court can make these property orders. That is bad enough. But if we have to wait for two years before the Court can exercise the jurisdiction, if it is the case that that jurisdiction can, constitutionally--

TALK.START.PARA: —You are going to get a reference of that power, are you not?

—We are going to seek it, Senator, but getting a reference out of Queensland, for one, will be a labour of Hercules on present indications, even if the other States are more co-operative. I simply make the point that in the event that the sequence of unhappy events to which I have referred takes place-that is, this particular matter being struck down by the High Court and this two-year period being inserted into the legislation-two years of misery will be experienced by spouses in this situation where they are waiting the exercise of the property jurisdiction rather than the one year of misery that they are experiencing at the moment. I am not suggesting for a moment that that, by itself, would be a sufficient consideration to meet the kind of argument advanced by Senator Durack and which, no doubt, will be advanced by Senator Harradine and others on this point. But it is a supplementary consideration which I think should be given some weight by honourable senators in considering this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Gareth Evans said that we should maintain the status quo for separation of the parties of one year. It has not worked to date. Since the introduction of the Family Law Act the divorce rate has been increasing. That, surely, must be of concern to the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans). The stability of marriage and the stability of the family is a matter of great priority in this country. There is now one divorce for every 2 1/2 marriages in a year. Something has to be done about that. We have to be able to say to people: 'You have got to try a little harder'. We have to be able to say to families: 'Some responsibility must be undertaken once marriage vows have been entered into'. If we do not make it a little harder to get a divorce then in the years to come our children and their children will enter into divorce with a cavalier attitude, as Senator Durack has already said. This will make a tremendous mess of the whole country. We will be responsible for not having taken the action which could be taken at this stage. I believe that most of us agree that if section 43 of the Family Law Act means anything it means that the institution of marriage should be preserved and protected. Section 43 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court shall . . . have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

TALK.START.PARA: —You should be against divorce altogether.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, as Senator Missen keeps interjecting about this section of the Family Law Act I ask him whether he believes in this section.
—That section is just the desirable ideal for people. It is not one that determines our divorce laws.
—Mr Chairman, this section refers to 'the Family Court', not 'a desirable ideal'. It has nothing to do with a desirable ideal. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to-
It is not just a nice thought. The Court shall try to have regard to and try to bring about that position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have regard to.

—Senator Missen agrees with that. The section states that the Court shall try to bring about a need to protect the institution of marriage as a union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life. Senator Missen agrees with that section which states that the Court shall have regard to and shall try its level best to institute that principle. Does Senator Missen agree with that?
—That is all it says, yes.

—If Senator Missen agrees with that then surely it is up to us as a parliament to attempt to fulfil the requirements of that section. If we try in some way to fulfil the requirements of that section then there must be something we can do to legislate for a two-year separation and make it a little more difficult for people to enter into divorce proceedings without due thought being given to the consequences. Mr Temporary Chairman, you are looking at the time. Time allowed for the debate has lapsed for the time being. I join in the appeal that Senator Harradine made today. This is a hotch potch debate. Next week we will be debating the Budget. Let us put aside the Family Law Amendment Bill until we can give proper consideration to it. Let us not deal with it in half hour spurts. We will never get through anything if we continue in this way.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.
Sitting suspended from 6.31 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 August 1983, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Senate take note of the papers and the statement.
Motion (by Senator Ryan) agreed to:

That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Chaney, speaking without limitation of time when speaking to the motion that the Senate take note of the papers and the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, this is the first opportunity which the Senate has had to discuss the Budget statement which was brought down in the House of Representatives and the Senate a little over two weeks ago. In the opinion of the Opposition the Treasurer, Mr Keating, has brought down a Budget which will not resolve the central problems Australia faces in 1983. The Budget, like any Budget which has ever been brought down, can be judged from different perspectives. Some people will judge it against what the Australian Labor Party promised in an election which was held only six months ago. They will compare this Budget to what Labor promised then and they will ask: 'What have they delivered now?' Other people will judge the Budget by its impact on individuals and community groups. A third set of judges will take the longer view and judge it on the basis of where they think it will take Australia. It is the fact that there are these different bases for examination which explain some of the differing evaluations of the Budget that we have seen.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my understanding that the Government, and particularly the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer, are quite pleased at the media reception the Budget has had, and it is fair to say that it was unusually well received by the popular Press, even though there has not been very much praise from serious commentators. What praise there was seems to be diminishing and is certainly increasingly hard to find. I think that the favourable reception that the Budget has had is mostly attributable to some very skilful political and public relations work since March 1983. That manipulation of opinion is readily seen in relation to two of the three perspectives against which the Budget can be judged . As far as broken promises are concerned, that is really a matter of ancient history. No one seems to care, just a few months after the election, that there are tax cuts for no one, whereas tax cuts for six million were promised. Nine out of 10 Australians were promised cheaper health care and, of course, the facts are that even when that promise was made two out of 10 already received free health care. In fact, the new Government declared all promises off as soon as it was elected.

The incessant use of the meretricious $9.6 billion figure for the prospective deficit succeeded in convincing much of the public that no other course was open to the Government. Hammering home that figure simultaneously prepared the way for a horror Budget and sheeted home the blame for whatever pain might have ensued on the previous Government. The subsequent projection of $8.5 billion created an illusion of restraint and reinforced the expectation of community sacrifice. There were what appeared to be inspired rumours of personal income tax rises, the fears of capital gains tax which were based on Labor's rhetoric in opposition and in government, and of course Senator Button continued to fuel the speculation about a capital gains tax throughout the months of the preparation of the Budget. The wholesale overturning of promises in the May Economic Statement led to the general belief that almost anything could happen, and led to a dread about the coming Budget which the reality did not meet. So far as broken promises are concerned, as far as the impact on groups and individuals is concerned, the Government has been judged very lightly.

There has, of course, been other discussion on the Budget, and my colleagues the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, in the Parliament and Mr Howard in a speech at the National Press Club have examined the facts of this at length. I do not intend to repeat many of their detailed criticisms here. But it is evident at this early stage of public reaction to the Budget that the Government 's political judgment was flawed in one area of its Budget strategy. That is, the doubt that has been cast over all aged Australians who have made the effort to provide for themselves and that doubt has been cast over them because of the clumsy proposal which the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) has put forward for an assets test. The Government may seek to minimise the impact of that mistake by referring to statements by members of the Opposition, including me, and the Leader of the Opposition. But that tactic conveniently overlooks the fact that in government the Fraser Government replaced the means test with an income test. This Government conveniently overlooks the fact that my concerns, expressed at the 1981 Budget, related to the proper application of that income test, and it conveniently overlooks the fact that its own proposals are quite different. The Opposition, when in government, did not seek to return to the assets test. I ask the Senate: How can the Government justify the distinction between the pensioner who has put his savings into a holiday home-who is penalised by this new test-as against the pensioner who has put the same money into a boat and a caravan? Why is it that in this Government's eyes investment in jewellery and antiques in favoured over more modest cash savings? The introduction of further illogicalities, anomalies and difficulties into the social security system-anomalies, illogicalities and difficulties that the aged people of Australia have to struggle their way through-is not a proper way of meeting what I regard as a very proper objective of restricting access to welfare in the interest of providing better for those in need.

I have mentioned those two perspectives from which the Budget is to be judged. The third perspective is probably the most important. It is certainly the most important for the long term success of this Government and certainly the most important for the future of Australia. It is: Where will the Budget take Australia in a year's time? Where will it take Australia a year from then, and further? The response of the critics and analysts has been mixed; although I think it is fair to say that the further the Budget recedes, the less favourable is the comment. It is fascinating to observe that some of the harshest criticism has come from those-as for instance, those who follow the doctrines of the Melbourne Institute-who believe that this Budget is insufficiently expansionary. But, putting the critics to one side, what is the Government's own assessment of what the future holds? We are told in the Budget that there are hopes of economic growth, that real gross domestic product may rise by perhaps 3 per cent this year, and that real non-farm product may rise 2 per cent in 1983-84, or 5 per cent on a June-on-June basis. This will be a significant achievement if it happens. But the Budget documents themselves show up the elements of risk in the projections which the Government has made. It is a cause for serious concern that the projected recovery is so narrowly based and so heavily reliant on the public sector. There are dangers inherent in financing a deficit and a total public sector borrowing requirement of the magnitude which the Government has provided. There are also dangers inherent in the Government's assumptions about the timing of the United States recovery and its possible effects on the Australian money market.

Some of these perils have been made dramatically clear by the obvious and disturbing discrepancies between the Budget's growth assumptions and the national accounts outcome for the June quarter released on the same night as the Budget. Those accounts for the June quarter show that there was a 2.3 per cent drop in the gross domestic product during that quarter. We may be facing a situation where there is a statistical discrepancy. It may be that later adjustments to the figures will show something which is healthier than that. But we can justifiably ask if the Treasurer would have gambled on the expected recovery that he is predicting in this Budget if the June quarter performance had been known to him a month ago. But the greatest gamble of all is the extent to which the whole of this Government's strategy rests upon the wages accord. I do not believe that tonight is the time to detail all of the Opposition's doubts about the strength and coherence of the accord and of the second-best nature of this Government's whole wages policy. The bargain that the Government struck with the Australian Council of Trade Unions, in its quest for industrial peace and political power, has already been discussed at length in this chamber on the initiative of the Opposition. I think it is timely to point out that on the Government's own assessment, on what the Government is telling Australia, is going to happen, that even if everything goes right by the accord, even if the accord holds to its terms, even if we do get a workable centralised wage fixing system, even if there is a strict limiting of sectional claims, even if the wages growth can be held to 7 per cent this year, even if all those things happen, the Government is telling Australia that we will still have rising unemployment.

There are a great many ifs in what I have just said but they are the Government 's ifs, not the Opposition's ifs, and I repeat them now to remind the Senate that even if the Government can hold the line on its own deal with the unions, we will still have unemployment at over 10 per cent when the next Budget is brought down in August 1984. The Government has predicted more than 10 per cent unemployment. That is predicted on the success of its wages accord, centralised wage fixing, strict limiting of sectional claims, a wages growth of only 7 per cent this year and rising unemployment. Those are the predictions of the Government, but if the Government, the ACTU and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission cannot hold the line that this Budget is predicated on, of course the result will be worse.

The Government purports to be creating jobs in this Budget. The Treasurer predicts that about 90,000 jobs will be created during the period of the Budget, but we have to take into account the fact that about 50,000 of those jobs are make-work, temporary job creation scheme positions and another 6,500 of these jobs are in the public sector. So where are the real increases in full time private sector jobs? Patently those increases are trivial. Temporary jobs will of course be created by the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security to deal with the red tape associated with the withholding tax and the proposed assets test on pensions. But when we are looking for employment for Australia's unemployed, we are looking for permanent or real jobs out there in the working world. That is what this Budget is not going to deliver. The figure put forward by the Treasurer is even more patently a token when it is considered that the housing package, which he claims is creating 30,000 of those jobs in both the public and the private sectors, was part of the May mini-Budget . How many of all the jobs created this year will in fact be the result of the fiscal stimulus which was administered by the previous Government in the last Budget?

I want to return to that central issue. My colleague, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, when he spoke to the National Press Club, addressed at length the issue of wages policy and the extent to which it means that this Budget is a disturbingly fragile document. I do not want to spend a lot of time on that tonight but I do want to remind the Senate again that the Food Preservers Union of Australia, the building workers and the oil company workers have already brought claims against employers in a way which shows that the accord is far from enjoying universal assent in the trade union movement. The overwhelmingly important point I wish to make is that even if everything holds, if this Government succeeds on its own basis in this Budget, the resulting state of affairs will be totally unsatisfactory for Australia and for all Australians. What the Government is telling us in the Budget is that for the forseeable future unemployment in Australia will be such that one in 10, perhaps one in nine of the work force will have no job; that one in four young Australians will have no job and that those figures may actually worsen during this Budget period and beyond. Of course the one in four figure for the young means a smaller proportion for older workers. But the social effects, particularly on the young, stand as a great criticism of this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, listen to it. What hypocrisy.
—And what do those figures, representing all those Australians cut off from normal Australian life, mean for Australia and indeed for our liberal democratic institutions?
—Oh, come on. You had seven years. What did you do?

—This Budget marks a break with the past, a fundamental shift in Australia's political history, and I would remind Labor senators who are interjecting that it was the Curtin Labor Government which, in May 1945, brought down the White Paper on full employment that since then has been part of the credo of every successive Australian government. It has been one of the few articles of political faith accorded bipartisan support for nearly 40 years. Clearly that bipartisan attitude no longer exists. I believe that this Budget shows that the Labor Government, supported by honourable senators opposite, has jettisoned that fundamental belief. I go back to what Mr Curtin said in 1945, and draw the Senate's attention to the fact that Mr Hawke, when he was not in government, chose to use words which were very similar to those of Mr Curtin in 1945. They are very different words from the words we find in this Budget, which represents the actual performance of this Government. In the White Paper entitled 'Full Employment in Australia' the Curtin Government stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Full employment is a fundamental aim of the Commonwealth Government. The Government believes that the people of Australia will demand and are entitled to expect full employment, and that for this purpose it will be able to count on the co-operation of servicemen's associations, trade unions, employers' associations and other groups.
There is a voice from the recent past as well as a voice from 1945.

TALK.START.PARA: —He did not say in six months.
—He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the responsibility of Commonwealth and State Governments is to provide the general framework of a full employment economy . . .

That is what we are here talking about tonight. Is the framework which is provided by this Budget a framework for what honourable senators opposite would claim as a full employment economy? This policy would appear to be what Mr Hawke was promising the Australian people last March. Let me quote from his election policy speech which was delivered, actually, on 16 February, when he addressed this central issue. In the first couple of pages of the policy speech, in which he held out why he should be elected to govern this country, he said:
There are tremendous issues involved in this historic election of the fifth of March-first and foremost, the right of all Australians to a job;
That was the first and foremost issue that Mr Hawke put before the Australian people, the right of all Australians to a job. He went on to say:
For the sake of the one million and more Australians who face unemployment unless there is a change, -
Of course that was a much higher figure than the existing unemployment figure, but Mr Hawke said: 'You had better change because it will go higher' -
those policies must be changed, and will be changed-by the Australian Labor Government after 5 March.
Mr Hawke went on to say:
For the facts are there-stark and grim-for every Australian to see. Seven years of Fraserism have produced: The highest number of Australians thrown out of work in our history;

TALK.START.PARA: —Very true.
—I continue:

SPEECH.PARA: and the highest unemployment rate since the Great Depression fifty years ago. One in ten Australians out of work-
And let us hear these words as very true too, Senator-
a figure no Australian would have believed possible a few years ago and which no Australian Government should ever be forgiven for creating.
Apparently the continuance of that lack of jobs is fine. It does not matter if we leave those people unemployed, it does not matter if unemployment increases. Mr Hawke went on to say:
One in four young Australians looking for work being unable to find work.

In the Budget which has been brought down by the Hawke Government there is no trace of sentiments of the sort that were expressed in the policy speech. In the responses by Government senators in this debate we will no doubt have the sort of cry which we have heard in interjections just a few minutes ago, that the ideal of full employment was lost under the previous Government. I would say to Government senators that that rhetoric is as unhelpful and unproductive as my going back to 1974 and pointing out the great leap in unemployment which occurred under Mr Whitlam at that time. That is irrelevant now. This Budget is about tomorrow, not about yesterday, and about the responsibilities of the Government in accordance with the promises it made to the Australian people.

I put it to the Senate that it is time that we decided unanimously to agree on full employment as one of the central objectives of all governments in Australia . This Budget clearly does not accept that as a central objective. There is little rhetoric about it but the Budget itself in actuality projects a continuing rise in unemployment and offers no hope at all for Australia except a slowing of the rate of increase.

We have had in this chamber a number of public importance debates on wages policy and on its effect on unemployment. On each occasion, in his defence, the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, has made the point that wages policy is just one part of the problem. In each debate Opposition senators have agreed with that statement, but we have pointed out that it is the largest part of our present problem. There is a whole range of other things which need to be tackled. But where in the Budget is there evidence that these things are being tackled? In a Budget that had as its central objective the restoration of full employment, it is clear we would have seen some evidence that all other areas of policy were being tackled with a view to maximising growth and employment.

Such evidence is hard to find in the Budget document. The very size of the Budget, the amount of expenditure, is likely to be damaging to growth. One has to ask whether such a high deficit, with such a high structural component, will leave Australia in a position in which private activity can expand without succumbing to the pressures on interest rates or on the money supply. We have already heard much in public debate about the warnings in the Budget Papers of the likelihood of pressures on interest rates in the event that there is any economic recovery in Australia. Surely, even with the views that this Government has about centralised wages policy, it should consider modifications which could increase employment.

In that respect, I urge the Government to re-examine the 'Report on Youth, Wages, Employment and the Labour Force', prepared by the Bureau of Labour Market Research at the request of the previous Government. That report was introduced by the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Willis, in a very quiet way. He put out a quite disparaging, certainly very low key, statement about the report, yet it raises issues which need close examination if we are concerned about the high levels of youth unemployment. Instead, we seem to have a burying of the report as a question that needs to be examined by this Government. Early indications are that the report is to be buried and discredited. I believe that can be explained on the basis of the Government's concern to avoid disturbing what it calls the industrial relations reality. Senator Button's own field of industry policy should be governed by considerations of what policies will promote growing industries what policies will allow investment to flow to areas where greater growth, profits and employment will occur. We see no signs of that either in the Budget or in the various industry policies announced by Senator Button over the last six months.

Taxation policy is surely important to the way people invest. Last year the Fraser Government took a first step towards encouraging investment in Australian industry with its exemption from tax of the first $1,000 of dividend income. That initiative, of course, was one of the first to go under the new Labor Government. Division 7 tax on companies might be further reduced to encourage the retention of capital in small businesses, currently under so much pressure. We see no action on that front. The bias in the taxation system in favour of fixed assets rather than productive enterprise might be raised as an issue to be tackled, even if not dealt with now. Over recent months the issue was raised squarely by the Deputy Commissioner of Taxation in Victoria. Serious questions were sent back to the government because they were issues of policy and involved changes to existing practices. We have had no response from this Government on that issue. The Deputy Commissioner provided a lead, but there has been no sign of this Government wanting to follow it. The Government could be looking at the disemployment effects, again felt very acutely by small business, of the present payroll tax and workers compensation arrangements; or does this Labor Government believe that it has no role to play because these are State matters? There is a very long agenda for reform in these areas, but there is no evidence that the present Government is even aware of the problems.

If we had a government centrally concerned with full employment, which saw that as its priority policy objective, it surely would have expressed some awareness of the trade-offs which exist in policy areas such as the environment. There are decisions currently before the Government, such as what is to be done about stage 2 of the Kakadu National Park. That sort of decision is of great environmental significance. It will also have significant employment implications. No one could have been more ready than the previous Government to protect important examples of Australia's ecosystems. The declaration of stage 1 of Kakadu and the purchase of land for stage 2 are just two of the demonstrations of that readiness. Surely, in assessing what ought to happen to stage 2 in 1983, careful consideration needs to be given to the development of potential employment situations. We see no signs that this Government is concerned about that sort of issue.

There is also the issue of the balance between social security and educational provisions. When in Opposition the present Government talked very loudly about the relatively low participation rate of Australian youth in tertiary education. The Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, is in the chamber. I heard her deliver many a lecture to the then Minister for Education on that subject. In this Budget the Government has widened the gap between unemployment benefit and the assistance given under the tertiary education assistance scheme. The Opposition should applaud the Government for being prepared to demand that taxpayers better provide for our unhappy and unfortunate unemployed; but many Australian taxpayers would question the balance of incentives for young Australians at the margin who might be making a decision between unemployment and education. Moreover, however well we provide for the unemployed, those benefits will never be a substitute for real employment.

The central complaint I make about this Budget is that it fails utterly to tackle the central issue. It fails utterly to make any real commitment to full employment. It does not even hold out a promise of some return to full employment in the future. The Liberal Party has never abandoned that objective and regards it as a very important policy objective. The Leader of the Opposition has made it clear that we regard it as the most serious responsibility laid on us as we rethink our policies in Opposition and seek to arrive at policies which will embrace that objective. As we come to grips with that objective there will be very serious debate, in this chamber and elsewhere, about what is meant by full employment in the 1980s. Certainly, there will be room for differences of opinion about whether the very low figures we had in post-war Australia are realistic, given the changes in our economy and the composition of our work force. But it would be a red herring for that argument to be raised now in defence of the Government when we have not even begun to turn in the direction of full employment.

The challenge faced by the Government in framing this Budget is clear. No one could imagine for a moment that it was an easy challenge. I believe that it would be fair to say that the Budget may have been the most difficult to frame in the last 10 years. Although I would not agree with the reasons that the Government would put for that being the case. The sudden reduction in economic activity in Australia has given rise to enourmous difficulties for us. Even given those acknowledged difficulties, the Government, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer have fudged it. They have not really turned their attention to the central task of removing the barriers to significant employment growth and to reducing unemployment. The Prime Minister has not fudged on everything. He has not fudged on the possibility of some economic growth. It may be a risky proposition under this Budget, but with some luck we may get it. Big business will certainly be grateful to the Prime Minister if there is a lift in profitability, and that will be good for Australia. The trade unions are likely to be grateful if the living conditions of the employed are maintained.

The people who will not be grateful for this Budget are those one in 10 who are without jobs. It is to be hoped that the few extra dollars they are to receive will do something to reduce their difficulties, but it will not solve their problems. In this Budget the Government holds out to them no hope of change in the next 12 months and beyond. I can only hope that the wider Australian community will see what some see as a welfare problem in its widest implications and that it will demand of this Government that it now concentrate on the central difficulty of creating sufficient employment in Australia to reduce unemployment. In this Budget it has failed to do so. Accordingly, it has failed to meet the promise which it made to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 5 March this year, at a time of national economic disaster, the people of Australia decided to take a new direction. They decided that it was time to get rid of the well tried and failed conservatives and try the socialists. How sad that they got the conservative socialists! This Budget has been a disappointment, particularly to the needy and the disadvantaged. It has been an economic disappointment. It has even been a disappointment to the party members who presented it to this Parliament. It is probably a repetition of the Fraser era-the first budget wasted, as happened in 1976. This Budget should have demonstrated courage. It should have expressed the philosophies of hope that were expressed during the lead up to the election.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government had two alternatives. It could have followed the Treasury line, the Fraser line, the Howard line, the restrictive line-the eight-year proven formula for failure-or it could have taken the stimulatory expansive line. In the event the Government has fallen between two stools. It neither promotes long term economic growth nor does it help those desperately in need of assistance. It is mildly expansionary but not enough to stimulate the economy, to get it going again. It is in fact a short term band-aid in preparation for a 1984 election. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said after the Budget was brought down that his Government was elected to arrest the decline in the Australian economy. That was not the way the people of Australia saw this Government's election. It was elected not only to arrest the decline but also to promote the recovery of Australia-not just to put on the brakes, but also to apply the motive power to this recovery. But regrettably this Budget will not promote the recovery. It is a stand-still Budget.

The Budget must be a great disappointment to the needy and the disadvantaged who were promised equity and fairness by this Government. Let us look at some of the people in those categories-the unemployed, the people who really did catch the brunt of Australia's national economic disaster.

The Government itself recognises that there will be a growth in unemployment in the current year. The average number of unemployment benefit recipients in 1982- 83 was 540,000. This number will climb to 680,000 in the current year judging from the Government's projections. One of the problems that many of us have with those figures is that last year's projection was proven to be 145,000 short of the real figure. We will just have to wait to see whether this prediction will be equally light on because there is a contracting job market. Last year we suffered a 1.4 per cent reduction in civilian employment-the largest fall for 30 years. All that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) can offer us is the following statement:
. . . employment growth will not be as strong as we might wish-but as I have attempted to illustrate, that is unavoidable.
Why is it unavoidable? It is unavoidable because of the self-imposed constraints that this Government has put upon this Budget.

Why did the Government swallow Treasury's philosophies when it had such exciting philosophies of its own? Does it lack the courage to roll Treasury and act on its own beliefs? This Government should be acting right now to create lasting employment growth, and not just be satisfied with a moderate increase in employment. Employment recovery needs both spending and ideas. It is not just a matter of dollars. Previous governments thought that dollars might solve the problem. This problem needs the sort of creativity that Minister Barry Jones tried to force through the Cabinet. But, of course, his initiatives were dumped, delayed or whatever. We have not seen them and they have not seen the light of day. So new technologies, sunrise industries and tomorrow's enterprises are still waiting, holding their breath. Having held it from the mini-Budget until the maxi-Budget they now have to hold it until God knows when. But certainly nothing has been done yet. The Government has not recognised its responsibility to plan for the future, to plan for tomorrow's enterprises.

In contrast to that I draw the Senate's attention to the Australian Democrats alternative Budget. We would introduce innovative ideas-the community mature persons support scheme, the conservation corps and the youth education work guarantee system. There are many innovative ideas in the Democrats alternative Budget that was presented before the Government's Budget was brought down. We would have been happy for the Government to steal those ideas as it has borrowed a number of other Democrat initiatives.

How sad for this country that in looking at the tax regime this Government hit on probably one of the most sensitive areas, not just in terms of potential for increasing inflation but in its overall impact on regions and on individuals who could not take any more tax increases. Of course, I am referring to the increased excise on petrol which hits everybody-the high socio-economic group, the low socio-economic group, the unemployed and the employed. Everybody is hit by the increase-the unnecessary increase, I might add, if one believes the Government's own rhetoric when it was in Opposition on the excise on petrol.

The Government has betrayed Australia and members of its own party and abandoned its own promises in increasing this excise. It has done so at the expense of rural areas and the northern regions in particular. Of course, the flow-on costs will be felt through the increased prices of food and, of course, the increased rate of inflation. Let me just illustrate for a moment how such an increase flows on through all sections of the community. That 1.5 cents per litre increase in excise has quite a dramatic effect on local government. It is estimated that there will be an increase of approximately 4 per cent for fuel in council budgets. The impact of that will flow on through local governments having to increase their rates. Rate increases will flow on through the whole economy and the consumer price index will be increased. So everybody will get hit. Of course, in addition to the straight out fuel impact, there are other flow-ons such as increases in bitumen costs, road construction costs and transport costs on all items which are carried to their destination for ultimate use by consumers. We can see already the impact of this Government's Budget strategy on all sectors.

The unions have responded to the previous Government's wages freeze quite responsibly overall. There have been deviations, but overall I think it is fair to suggest that the unions have carried their share of the burden. Most sectors of industry have carried their share of the burden. There have been drastic drops in profit and as a result industry has undergone rationalisation. But we do not see that inhibition in government at any level. We do not see it at Federal, State or local government levels. Government rates and taxes continue to skyrocket. Of course, this leads to higher and higher inflation. The Democrats suggested that it was time that the Federal Government recognised its responsibility to local government and, as a direct product of that, reduced the rate of inflation by granting higher subsidies to local government. Local government at least provides jobs at a much higher rate than other levels of government. Regional employment increases when money is made available at the local government level.

What a sad day it was for low income groups in Australia when this Government broke its promise to the needy and the disadvantaged and, I might add, to the swinging voters. Although certainly the Government appealed to the swinging voters before the election it very hastily abandoned them immediately post- election. What a sad day it was when the tax cuts were abandoned because here was the opportunity for this Government to stimulate the economy and get it going again. We suggested in the Australian Democrats alternative Budget that there was a scope to help the disadvantaged, the low income earners, and, as a direct result, to stimulate this economy through increased consumer spending which has a particularly direct and immediate impact on small businesses. If this Government wants some lead in where to direct its efforts from here on, let me suggest to it that it should be in the small business region. The simplest way of getting small business up and going again is to increase consumer demand, to get the dollars into the market-place and not into the savings bank where we consistently see an increase in savings because of the lack of confidence in the Government's economic strategy. Of course, as a direct result we would get a flow on not just to small business but to the whole economy.

Alternatives are available to this Government. It did not have to break its promises to the low income earners. It could have given tax alleviation to people who desperately need a few extra dollars just to survive. It could have stimulated the economy by injecting money at that level and, through that level, to small businesses. As an alternative it could have introduced, for instance, a capital gains tax. If it had the courage of its convictions it could have introduced a wealth tax. In the process of introducing those two taxes it could, almost overnight, have eliminated the tax evasion and tax avoidance industry. It probably could have saved itself from the further pain and anguish of chasing those who avoided and evaded their taxes in the 1970s. Instead it could have caught up with people in the 1980s who are still avoiding and evading their tax obligations to this society. This Government could have introduced a value added tax, if it had had the courage to do so. It could have done something innovative and lifted its sights above the old worn out tax methods in this country. It could have gone for a full scale tax reform. Whilst the Government preaches such reform, again it lacks the courage, the initiative and the innovation to go for it. It settles for just patching up a few of the older methods.

I heard an interjection earlier that the Government also could have done something about the housing industry. Of course it could have. It has done a little for the housing industry, but far too little. It has probably compensated for the little that it has done by removing the relief that was avilable to other people buying their homes. The Australian Democrats believe that there should be a housing interest rebate for all needy families buying their homes, not just for first home buyers. Sure, first home buyers do stimulate the housing industry directly and have an immediate impact but people who are already buying their homes, who cannot keep up with the interest rates and cannot cope with the dramatic increase in interest rates that they have suffered in recent years are in need of assistance.

In passing, while talking about housing assistance, I am disappointed that there was not an extension of the rental supplementary assistance to all recipients of the unemployment benefit after, say, eight weeks of unemployment. I think that that is a measure that this Government could still consider because there is anguish and tragedy when very low income earners find their wages supplanted by the unemployment benefit. Families finish up out in the streets.

This Government's great betrayal has been to the youth of this country. The under 18-year-olds are already seriously disadvantaged. They are forced to bear the brunt of unemployment and spiralling costs. They are given no encouragement and no incentive-not even the incentive to continue or to get back into the education system. The great hope of this country will be its educated young people in the next decade. But we are still not recognising the importance of encouraging young people to move into or to stay in the education system, to provide this country with that resource in the future. I also suggest that the Government could have won a lot of friends-the Democrats made this suggestion earlier-by extending fringe benefits to all age pensioners, irrespective of income. It would have been only a little gesture but I think it would have taken a tremendous amount of steam out of some of the antagonism that has built up recently in the pensioner groups. A lot of people rely on and particularly want those fringe benefits. The Government could have made that offer to pensioners.

I move now to the betrayal of Australian business-in particular, small business -by this Government. The Budget has had the effect of increasing costs to small businesses. The flow on effect of some of the measures adopted by the Government will have that impact on businesses which are already on their knees. Government charges have increased, as I indicated earlier, right across the board, at all levels of government. This Government could have given small business the injection it needed. With increased deficit spending the Government could have helped small business to lead the recovery of this nation. But there are no initiatives in this Budget for small business. The Government did not even introduce the small enterprise legislation which has been talked about recently. Apparently it did not contemplate the proposal for quarterly provisional tax payments to help ease the burden of small businesses which are battling to survive. It did not contemplate the Division 7 tax removal as proposed by the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System. That Committee recommended that a private company should be given the option to be treated as a partnership for tax purposes, with the shareholders being taxed accordingly. What a relief that could have been for a lot of small businesses. But no, they are ignored because this Government does not seem to have a recognition of the desperate plight of small businesses in this country. The Democrats proposed-I would have thought that if the Government were to pick up any measures it would have adopted this one-the abolition of payroll tax, the phasing out of payroll tax. The Government could have assisted the States-the States impose the tax-to phase out payroll tax over a period of two or three years, particularly over the next two or three years, as the economy improves.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would that have cost?

—If the Government took the whole brunt over a full year it would cost $2,000m. If the payroll tax were phased out that sort of cost would not have been reflected in this Budget. The Government could have indicated to State governments and to employers that it wanted to remove the disincentive to employ people. But there is no such gesture in the Budget. There is no such indication that such a policy will be implemented. If it is introduced in the Budget next year as an electoral plum then why not introduce it now when small businesses need it to survive? Now is the time that small businesses could be given the incentive to get more employees on their payrolls.

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is an economic betrayal of businesses because it has landed in no man's land between the Treasury's restrictionist approach and the stimulatory approach which the Government talked about before the election. This Budget will not stimulate the economy. It is just a 'hold the fort' strategy. It is expansionary without being stimulatory. The Government must have worked pretty damned hard to achieve that, to introduce a Budget which expands the economy without stimulating it. But that is the achievement of this Government because it lacked the courage to allow that deficit to swing out by another billion dollars. The deficit will probably swing out by one billion dollars in any case. Last year it swung out by much more than one billion dollars. The Government should have been prepared to say: 'Right, instead of concentrating on and worrying about the deficit we will concentrate on and worry about stimulating the economy again. We will get this nation going again'. As a direct result we would have had higher employment, higher economic activity and greater use of the resources of this country. As a direct result again the Government's coffers would have been filled and the deficit would have been reduced by the end of this year.

With the Budget that has been presented to us we will probably have the opposition situation. We will suffer a repetition of what we suffered last year, that is of a government trying to pull its horns in and in the end the deficit blowing out. If we had had a government which was game enough to say 'Yes, we are brave, we are willing to take a bit of a risk, we are willing to go for an extra $1 billion because we recognise that that will show the whole of Australia that we want to stimulate the economy' the country would have got up off its knees. There would have been a chance for this nation to recover this year and not wait for next year, the election year.

It was possible for the Government to produce a responsible expansive Budget. I am not the only person to suggest that. It has been suggested by responsible, highly respected economists around Australia. It has been suggested by a Minister of this Government. Mr Willis suggested that $9.6 billion was quite a responsible deficit. I suspect that Mr Willis had a lot of support in the Australian Labor Party, and I suspect that if this Government had had the courage to expand the deficit to around $9.6 billion Australia would have rejoiced and the Labor Party would have rejoiced. The only people who would have been saddened by that would have been a few financiers, a few members of the Opposition and the Treasury. The rest of Australia would have lifted off and would not have had to look back for the next decade as a result of that stimulation. Frankly, I believe that the financial markets would not have lost confidence in this Government if it had sold that strategy to them. Regrettably the Government painted itself into a corner by accepting the Treasury philosophy .

It is very interesting to note that the economy of the United States is experiencing sizeable growth with a deficit officially expected to reach 7 per cent of gross domestic product in 1983, thus proving that bigger deficits in times of recession are not ipso facto incompatible with growth and job creation. Australia's deficit as a proportion of GDP in 1983-84 is estimated to be 4.7 per cent of GDP. I repeat that the United States figure is 7 per cent of GDP and that country is getting the runs on the board. Australia's deficit, as a proportion of GDP, is only 4.7 per cent. That extra $1 billion could have made the difference. It could have achieved all that this Government preached before the election. It could have thrown out the window the tired and worn out economic strategies of the past eight years and proven that Her Majesty's Opposition circa 1976-83 was right. All that this Government seems to want to do is to prove that it can be as wrong as was Her Majesty's Government of that era.

This country needs long term planning. It needs long term vision. We have a chance this year, because we are coming out of the drought, to get Australia on its economic feet, but we need a long term growth strategy and not just be dependent on world recovery, waiting for the invisible hand. Does this Government not realise that it is the invisible hand and the hand at the moment is immobile? I wish that we had an alternative in the Liberal Party of Australia , but unfortunately its record is as bad. It too was snowed by Treasury.

In conclusion, I believe that Australians will be disappointed that this Government lacks the courage of its convictions. If that were not so it would have introduced a stimulatory Budget. This Budget is neither a social nor an economic plan on which Australians can build with confidence. Perhaps it is a political plan. Perhaps it is an election document. Nevertheless, I believe that we have a responsibility to try to make this Budget work despite its faults. Therefore the Australian Democrats will support the passing of this Budget. We will endeavour to improve it during its passage through this House, through amendments and in negotiations with the Government and the Opposition. Because the future of all Australians depends on the success of this Budget, we sincerely hope that it does achieve the Treasurer's promises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Budget which was brought down a fortnight ago. We have just heard from the senator whom I understand to be the economic spokesman of the Australian Democrats a speech in relation to the Budget which certainly was fascinating to me. I saw Senator Chipp on television last night. He said that the Democrats were the real Opposition in the Australian Parliament. Having had a look at the performance of the official Opposition in the past week or two, I thought that was a pretty intelligent comment, but having heard Senator Jack Evans's speech tonight I shudder at the prospect of the Democrats being the alternative Opposition in this country, if that is the shape of things to come and if that self-described alternative Opposition would introduce a Budget of the kind which Senator Jack Evans foreshadowed.
—And Mr Willis.

—No, not Mr Willis. I will come to that. I am no mathematician, but during the honourable senator's speech I made some rough calculations on the back of an envelope, as it were. If the Goverment were to do all the things that the honourable senator invited it to do and not to do all things he invited it not to do the cost to the Government would be of the order of $5 billion. But Senator Jack Evans kept talking all evening about one billion magic dollars which, he said, would change the face of this country and would do marvellous things in terms of an expansionary Budget and in terms of hope and optimism-all the things which were not characterised by his speech, which is perhaps best described as 'Abandon hope all ye who enter here'.
—Look on the other side of the envelope and you will see some revenue items.

—I saw some of the honourable senator's revenue items. I wanted to mention some of those because he chastised the Government first of all for not introducing a capital gains tax. Do I take that to be a statement of Australian Democrats philosophy?
—Yes.
—If we had introduced a capital gains tax in this Budget would the Democrats have supported it?
—Yes, it is in our policy.
—Is that the position now?
—Yes, it is. It always has been.

—Perhaps the honourable senator ought to consult other members of his party before making confident predictions like that. Senator Jack Evans told the Government that it could have given tax alleviation to lower income earners. That is true. We could have done many of those things, not all within Senator Jack Evans's $1 billion extra but one of the reasons why we could not do a number of those things is that when we introduced tax recoupment legislation in the last session of parliament, which would have brought in $500m in revenue- half of the Democrats $1 billion-the honourable senator's party voted against it .
—Not so. I did not.
—Nor did I. Do us credit. Be more accurate in what you say.

—I am used enough to dealing with split personalities but not split parties. The fact of the matter is that that legislation was rejected by the Senate. I understand that if it is introduced again it may well be rejected by the Senate again if sober consideration is not given to the matter by Senator Evans's colleagues.
—It will be again.
—It will be rejected again?
—It will be considered soberly again.
—It will be considered soberly, and I hope Senator Evans is very sober when he tries to persuade-
—Senator Jack Evans.

—I am sorry, Senator Gareth Evans, I am addressing Senator Jack Evans. I hope Senator Jack Evans is very sober when he tries to persuade his party to support the Government's legislation because then we will be three- tenths of the way towards his magical billion dollars.
—Will you then give that tax relief to low income earners?

—I cannot make a promise on behalf of the Government but of course we could do some of the things that the honourable senator has suggested we might do. Senator Jack Evans's speech reminds me of that famous exchange between Glendower and Hotspur. 'I can summon spirits from the vasty deep', says Glendower. 'Yes', says Hotspur, 'but will they come?'. That is the precise political position of the Australian Democrats in regard to this Budget because Senator Evans in his speech summoned all sorts of spirits from the vasty deep. The question to which a government has to address itself is not the sort of question to which a party like the Democrats has to address itself. A government has to address itself to the question: 'Can you make those spirits come?'. Senator Evans chastised us about many things which he is now pleased to say were Australian Labor Party promises-like a capital gains tax, a wealth tax and things of that kind. He had better have a look at the Labor Party platform before he tells us what we have failed to do in terms of promises.
—The Labor Party is still split on capital gains taxes.

—Yes, but we will not vote in different ways when it comes to the question. I want to set this Budget debate in a serious context because it is a serious matter and Senator Jack Evans's speech has really led us into a strange world of fantasy which is not relevant to the problems of the majority of the Australian people. I want only to re-remind Senator Jack Evans and the people of Australia of the inheritance which the Government got.
—Let us talk about the future. Why talk about the past all the time?

—The past is vitally relevant to the present and to the future. Senator Watson, Liberal, Tasmania, groans in pain when I say that I might mention the inheritance which this Government received. Well he might groan in pain. It is good practice for the next seven years, because that is the time he spent blaming the Whitlam Government for its alleged sins. So he can groan away, because I want to tell the Senate something about the inheritance received by this Government. First of all, in the words not of me but of Potter Partners, the sharebrokers, the Hawke Government took over from the Fraser Government the worst economy in the last 50 years. We had the highest unemployment since the Depression, interest rates were at a very high level and the projected deficit of the Fraser Government was very high, swollen by pork-barrel handouts dictated by the National Country Party. Inflation was at a continuing high level. The consumer price index averaged 10.4 per cent over the last four years of the Fraser Government.
—There was negative growth.

—There was negative growth. Compare those figures with the figures from Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries where Senator Jack Evans, Australian Democrat, Western Australia, would happily go in order to enjoy the benign life under the governments of Scandinavia and Europe. Compare those figures that we inherited with the figures for those countries. The balance of payments was highly dependent upon capital inflow because of the lack of competitive resilience in Australian industry. The taxation system was out of control, with low and middle income earners paying while high income earners were avoiding taxation-a process which is still continuing because of the actions of the Opposition and splinters of the Democrats in this chamber.
—Rubbish!

—'Rubbish!', says Senator Lewis. He is committed to voting against tax avoidance legislation again. He has been defending tax avoiders in here for years and he should not pretend otherwise. We also saw declining business investment, down nearly $2.7 billion in real terms in 1982-83 and in that year, for the first time in over three decades, the gross domestic product showed its first real annual decline. That is the situation which the Hawke Government inherited.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Evans can come in here tonight and say that we did not do this for that group and we did not do that for another group or for somebody else, but the giveaway, from a politician, was that he said 'and you did not do this for the swinging voters'. My word, what is he suggesting? Is he suggesting some sort of swinging voters' tax concession or something like that? I do not know. That was the last punch line of that series of betrayals of the Hawke Government as Senator Evans put it. The honourable senator talks about betrayals. I have been out meeting with a lot of community groups since this Budget. They do not feel as betrayed as the honourable senator would like to think they feel or as much as he hopes they do. That is the sad fact which the Democrats have to face up to . What we inherited in March of this year was a country on the skids and the concern of this Government has been to get it out of that situation. So we had an appalling economic legacy, an appalling political legacy, and a period of declining government by the former Government marked by ad hockery and policy making, and a cynical election Budget in 1982 which provided large tax cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —And it is fixing the economy at the present moment, isn't it?

—I thank the honourable senator; we are grateful to him. If he got on a platform in public life and said that something the Fraser Government did was fixing the country, he would get a job as a clown. Of course the worst and most cynical political thing about the Fraser Government inheritance was that there was no attempt at long term policy making, no ways suggested to pull this country out of recession, desperate bids to stay in power. That is what it was about-dismal exercises in pork barrelling. Right to the last the former Treasurer, Mr Howard, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition in Australia today-the discredited former Treasurer, if I might quote one of my colleagues-concealed the size of the deficit from the Australian people. This Government, by contrast , is committed to new policies to stimulate investment.
—Do you reckon your deficit figure will hold?

—Yes. I am asked-I should deal with this matter because it was raised before-whether our deficit will hold. If there is a hole made in it it will be because of the Opposition defending tax avoiders and voting against tax avoidance legislation. If the Liberal Opposition in the Senate gets into action, that will have an effect on the deficit. That will make a difference of some $ 300m which might be given to the unemployed or used to provide tax relief for low income earners. Sure, the Liberal Opposition in the Senate will affect the size of the deficit if it goes under its present leadership hell-bent the way it is at the moment towards lemming-like destruction. It is the invisible Opposition, as the Sydney Morning Herald described it this morning. The honourable senator asks me if our deficit will blow out in the way the previous Government's deficit blew out. We came to government committed to halting the rise in unemployment. I suggest that Senator Watson have a look at the figures. They are not marvellous, but they are improving. That could not have been said at any stage in the last three years of the Fraser Government.
—What figures?

—I ask the honourable senator to look at the number of unemployment beneficiaries in the last three years. As I said, this Government is committed to new policies, to stimulating investment, to alleviating the decline in employment and to achieving consensus on the way ahead for Australia. It is a government committed to fighting inflation and unemployment together. We have, we believe, the backing of the Australian people and the support of both business and trade unions in seeking that objective.
—You have our support too.
—That is new. I am glad to hear the official Liberal Party spokesman from Warrnambool on these matters. He has told us that we have its support on this important issue also.
—Will they back the retrospective tax though?

—The answer is no. They want to increase the size of the deficit: that is the argument. This Government wants to try to achieve consensus on the way ahead for this country by the methods about which I have just spoken. Senator Lewis might note my words now because it will give him an opportunity to ask a question at Question Time in the autumn session next year. Perhaps he will be able to ask me: 'Did you not say in your speech on the Budget that the Government would reduce inflation and unemployment?' In March of next year he will come in here, he hopes, and be able to state: 'Look, it has all gone wrong. What you said in your speech on the Budget did not happen'. I am prepared to take a bet with Senator Lewis on that matter.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government had embarked prior to the Budget presentation on the road leading the country out of this chaotic mess. It is wrong for Senator Lewis to say on air to the people of Australia that because the Government did not do something in the Budget it will not be done, or talk as if the Budget was the only instrument of government policy making. Since this Government was elected we have had the National Economic Summit Conference. That was a success in the eyes of all independent critics. Out of the mouths of Liberal Party spokesmen, it was a success for its political honesty, if nothing else. Then we had the May economic statement, which has caused some pain on the Opposition benches but nowhere else. Then we had the Premiers Conference, at which the States were treated better than they had been treated for years. They recognised that. Not only did they recognise that fact in terms of the size of the deficit in the Federal Budget but also the Premiers of all States supported the target which the Federal Government had set for the deficit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even Queensland?

—There was a unanimous communique, supported by Joh Bjelke- Petersen and-what is the name of the fellow in Tasmania?-Robin Gray. All supported the size of the deficit projected by the Federal Government. Next we had the Budget. As a result of all those activities optimism has already been engendered in the Australian community, and the Budget will engender it further. I inform Senator Jack Evans that I am talking about optimism; I do not mean false promises. This Government has never said-
—You do not appreciate the difference.

—Senator, I do not have time to interrupt my speech to talk about your performance over the last few years. Anything that I have to say about that would be colourful but scarcely interesting to people listening. The fact of the matter is that over many years, election after election, the Fraser Government promised that interest rates would fall, that unemployment would disappear, that inflation would be halved and so on. In this Budget context we have not said that. We have tried to encourage genuine optimism. We believe we have succeeded. We have not encouraged false expectations about unemployment or anything else.
—Have a look at your popularity rating.

—Senator, I would not get excited about that if I were you. What I have been trying to say, subject to the interruptions, is that the Government has accepted the need for a more substantial role for the public sector in order to get the economy moving. Let me talk a little about the Budget strategy. This has perhaps been talked about enough, but I say that the purpose of the Budget was to try to provide the maximum stimulus, consistent with reducing inflation, that we felt we could provide at this time. One might say that our judgment was in error. Senator Jack Evans, the Liberal from Western Australia-
—Mr President, I raise a point of order!

—Senator Jack Evans, who is a self-described member of the real Opposition in Australia-a Western Australian Democrat-says that we were out in all our calculations by $1 billion and that if only we had spent $1 billion more the whole thing would have changed. He went on to tell us what we ought to have spent the money on. That added up to about $5 billion, but that is really a mathematical error and something which can be allowed for-according to Senator Evans! All he was saying was that we were $1 billion out. Of course, there can be errors of judgment in these areas. I am arguing that there were no errors of judgment of a fundamental kind in this Budget, having regard to the constraints which were imposed on us by the idiotic and disastrous policies of the previous Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The Budget also addresses major questions of fairness and equity and establishes a new order of priorities towards the unemployed and the socially disadvantaged. What we need in this country more than anything else in relation to those matters and those sections of the community, equally with the business sector and the trade union movement, is a stable, predictable environment in which policies are directed to the long term as well as the immediate term and not just, as they have been in the past, to the next by-election. They should be directed to the medium and long terms. That is what we have said and argued about in this chamber on many occasions; it is what the prices and incomes policy is all about.
