In terms of stimulating the economy as part of the Budget strategy, expenditure increased in this Budget by 7.2 per cent in real terms. Receipts increased by less than one per cent in real terms, which represents in money terms a lower growth than in 1982-83, but a much higher growth, of course, in real terms. We need real growth in the Australian economy to provide jobs and to help offset the inflationary pressures which we inherited. I mentioned the size of the deficit. The lower deficit achieved in this Budget will, we hope, stimulate the economy much more than last year's Budget even attempted to do. I mentioned- Senator Jack Evans would be interested in this-some of the major areas in which stimulatory activity has been embarked on and where help is needed by sections of the Australian community. There was an increase of 23 per cent in expenditure on housing, of 25 per cent on health, and of 19 per cent on social security and welfare. In respect of aged persons alone, an additional amount of $457m is to be expended. In regard to expenditure in relation to unemployment, there has been an increase of a substantial order which, in terms of benefits paid to individuals, represents significant growth. All these increases represent substantial real growth.

Senator Jack Evans and others have chided us about the effects of the Budget on business. The important thing for the business community in Australia, whether large business or small, is to have an environment of continuity and support. This Government has continued the investment allowance. It has introduced the five year or three year depreciation regime, which was undertaken by the former Government but not introduced. It has done a number of things which specifically relate to small business. I mentioned some of those things at Question Time this morning. Of course, the greatest thing which can be done for small business is to reduce inflation. I think that is the most important thing we can do for small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —And interest rates.

—And interest rates, and the Budget is directed to both those matters. The Australian Democrats alternative Budget would produce nothing but ruin. In the business area, the Government has taken action in relation to the Australian Industry Development Corporation and the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia, and it has increased funds for research and development. There has been an enormous increase in those areas, which have been recognised as important by previous speakers. It has increased to $333m the funds available for employment and training programs, which are also essential to the future welfare of Australian business and industry.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention all these things in the context of a debate which has been characterised on the Opposition side by words such as 'betrayal' and 'failure'. Senator Chaney, who speaks on behalf of a political party which created the highest level of unemployment in Australia since the Great Depression, used those words. He speaks as leader of the Liberal Party in the Senate, and he chastised this Government about unemployment when this Government has been in office for only 5 1/2 months. He chastised this Government at a time when there is every sign that the alarming decline in employment has been halted. The Democrats have said that we have not done things for this group or that group. I agree that all of those matters have to be addressed by the Government but not addressed necessarily in the context of this first Budget. We believe that it is part of the continuous progress which has characterised the activities, plans and announcements of this Government since it was elected to office. It has characterised steps which we are taking, over time, with the aim of creating jobs, reducing inflation and achieving a monetary balance in the budgetary context.

Nearly all commentators have acclaimed this Budget as responsible and offering some hope for the future. It does not for a moment offer all the hope that we would like, but it offers some hope, some optimism, some reason for belief that this country has turned the corner and now is able to go forward towards the great destiny which we all hope it has. Many advisers to the former Government have grudgingly approved of the Budget. It has achieved a rare degree of accord within the community. As I said, I believe it gives hope. This Government, in its deliberations, has considered all sections of the Australian community as part of that task of restoring some of the confidence, equity and fairness which the people of Australia deserve.
Debate (on motion by Senator Martin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.
Clause 20 (Dissolution of marriage).

TALK.START.PARA: —When consideration was interrupted I was appealing to the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, to take some action to try to make people realise that when they take marriage vows they accept other responsibilities. They must realise that it will not be easy for them to get out of those marriage vows; it will not just be a case of being separated for 12 months. Things may take a little longer. I believe that unless we as a parliament take some action to strengthen the ties of marriage then we will do a great disservice to the stability of the family in this country. I indicated when I first rose to speak to this amendment that even though our marriage rates are still high, our divorce rates are now also high. Every year there is one divorce for every 2 1/2 marriages. That, I imagine, would worry every Australian . Those are horrendous figures. Unless this Government attempts to do something to stabilise the situation coming generations will bear the burden of our mistakes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coleman Sen R.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a couple of points in relation to the speech made by Senator Durack. I was a little disturbed at some of the things he said. His implication was that people go into marriage knowing that if it does not work out they can simply get a divorce. I do not believe that that is what happens in our society. Perhaps I am still a bit of a romantic in that I believe that when people get married they firmly believe, at that time , that they will spend the rest of their lives with that partner. As I said to Senator Harradine during the suspension of the sitting for dinner, we really do not know a person until we live with him. If it does not work out, then the point I made on the previous amendment is still a valid one. The big problem I see in any consideration of an extension of time is that the marriage has broken down anyway before the separation actually takes place. So really when we talk about a 12 months separation we are not talking about a 12 months breakdown of the marriage; we are talking about a marriage that has broken down some considerable time before that separation comes into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Durack made some comments about counsellors. Perhaps something that should be looked at is how their role can be better developed at a time when it is needed most. How does one suggest to people, when a marriage is running smoothly, that they require counselling in order to stay that way? The counsellor has no role whatsoever to play until the marriage has broken down. If it has broken down to the extent that people have separated, then a counsellor will not assist, in the main, in getting the couple back together again. I only reiterate what I said on the previous amendment. The Committee would do irreparable harm to a lot of people, including children, if it were to consider seriously extending the time of separation to two years, as proposed by Senator Durack's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also oppose the amendment. Senator Walters, and probably Senator Harradine too, want action taken to make people realise that when they enter into marriage vows it will not be easy for them to get out of that marriage, that it may take longer than 12 months. This amendment represents an intimidation. If we took those two speakers seriously, and they are both very sincere in their views, we would have no divorce in this country. They are opposed altogether to divorce. They would have no divorce rules in this country at all. I am afraid we would then have stability of marriage and stability of misery for many people for the remainder of their lives. The fact is that we have long since gone beyond that situation. We realise that not only are people entitled to be divorced and should be divorced in situations when lives become a misery, but also it is in the interests of children that this be done. We have moderated this law over a number of years. It is no use trying to pretend that we can return to a previous situation.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular amendment has a long history. Senator Durack and I have been battling this question for some nine years. When the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs had before it the Family Law Bill in 1974, Senator Durack and Senator Chaney were then the minority of two in a committee of six who favoured a two-year term of separation. They sincerely believed that that was a better period. The majority favoured a one-year period of separation. I think Senator Button and I are the only two senators in the chamber these days who supported that majority opinion. Since then that has become the law; that period was adopted by this Parliament in 1974.

We had a very long investigation of family law in 1979-80. When we examined these things we came to a conclusion that there were no grounds for changing that period. I will not go over the arguments put by the Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans-I also put them last night-why a long period of separation is not a good idea. Figures that were before the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act show that there was very little opportunity or likelihood of reconciliation occurring over a period of six months or a year. Certainly there was no likelihood of reconciliation after two years or longer periods. This would not aid reconciliation at all.

It is worth reminding the Committee of the Joint Committee's conclusions on this matter. I also remind Senator Walters that she was a party to the conclusions contained in paragraph 3.47 of the Joint Committee's report which states:

If the period of separation were to be extended as proposed to a blanket period of 24 or 36 months it would be impossible in our view not to make special provision for immediate divorce in certain cases. This would inevitably re- introduce some element of fault. The combination of an immediate fault ground and a longer separation period could easily result in many parties colluding to obtain a fault divorce. This has been the experience as was noted earlier. If this were the result it would seen to defeat the purpose of extending the separation period to facilitate reconciliation as parties who were agreed on divorce would be able to obtain their dissolution even sooner than it is possible for them to do now. This is particularly the case if adultery is accepted as one of the grounds.

We already rejected the amendment which included adultery or continuous adultery as one of the grounds. It is clear that the Committee, after hearing all the evidence, was strongly of the opinion that to extend the period was undesirable. As the Attorney-General has pointed out, if we extend the period it would make it even more difficult to get settlement of property matters and the complete settlement of a family situation at a reasonably early date. If any part of this legislation is not upheld and it is challenged in the High Court of Australia we may well find we are in a very awkward situation if we extend the period of separation to two years. People, in a period of limbo, may not be able to settle property or other matters after the marriage has broken down. For these reasons there are potent grounds for rejecting amendments like this.

There is no demand for this sort of thing except from a small section of the community that has been consistent in this over the years. But an overwhelming number of people have always accepted that non-fault grounds should be accepted. I think one-year separation has been accepted readily by the community as being sound. One does not restore marriages by forcing people to stick together and by saying that they cannot get a divorce. This has been tried in the past. It is tried in countries where there is no divorce at all and it does not succeed in making happy marriages. I believe, sir, that absolutely no ground has been established for a change in the grounds of divorce. I trust that as in 1974, as in the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act and as in the public view, this amendment will be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment that has been moved by Senator Durack, which seeks to extend to two years the 12-month period of separation as the ground for the irretrievable breakdown of a marriage . Despite what the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and Senator Missen have said, 12 months separation seems to me to be very short time in which to prove irretrievable breakdown. It seems to me to create expectations of easy divorce, and that would be borne out by figures cited in the Senate on the increase in divorces since the Family Law Act came into being-there is one divorce in every 2.5 marriages. I think a period of separation as short as 12 months takes away the incentive to work at reconciliation and a restoration of a real relationship. I was pleased to hear the Attorney-General tell us that there is to be compulsory counselling for people married for less than two years who are seeking a divorce. I think that compulsory counselling for all couples seeking divorce is something we should aim at.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, the marriage vow 'till death do us part' seems to be taken quite lightly in many circumstances. Everything possible should be done to strengthen the marriage bond and not to make dissolution easier. Marriage and family relationships are something to be worked at and there is certainly no easy Utopia situation. Twelve months would not give people much time to work at a reconciliation, whereas if the period were extended to two years, as proposed in the amendment that Senator Durack has brought forward, more reconciliations might be possible. Both parties to a divorce should remember the needs of their children, who are the victims of broken marriages, and they should work very hard indeed to effect a reconciliation. The establishment of a happy family unit must be seen as the major objective of men and women and, indeed, the Senate. I certainly support Senator Durack's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really take exception to Senator Missen's misquoting and twisting my words. At no time have I indicated that I do not believe in divorce under any circumstance and that I would not have causes for divorce allowed in this country. It would be like my saying that Senator Missen says people should be able to obtain their divorces if they just say the right words three times. To misconstrue my words the way he has is untruthful and it does not do him credit. I am merely saying that if divorce is made too easy it will undermine marriage, which we, in this country, believe creates stability in the very precious family situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find myself to be a reluctant supporter of the proposition that has been advanced by Senator Durack. I believe it is less desirable than the amendment which I moved and which the Senate has not seen fit to accept. However, it is at least a step in the right direction. One matter of real concern within the community, of course, the fact that in its operation, the Family Law Act has enabled a growing number of dissolutions of marriage in Australia. It has been repeated here quite often that the number of marriages being dissolved in Australia is increasing each year. It has also been repeated quite often that the number of young people-that is children under the age of 18 years-affected by these dissolutions is increasing each year.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that prior to 1975 something like six per 1000 of the population under the age of 18 was affected by divorce. That figure has now grown to something like 11.8 per 1000 of people under the age of 18. I cite those figures from memory. The actual number of children affected last year alone under the age of 18 was over 53,000. That is because the law which defines the meaning of marriage-as I explained before the suspension of the sitting for dinner-is made a mockery of by this section of the Family Law Act. As I pointed out, it is the requirement of the marriage celebrant under section 46 of the Marriage Act to state to the parties in the presence of witnesses that marriage according to law in Australia is 'the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life'. Of course, the marriage celebrant must remind the parties that they are entering into a solemn and binding relationship .

I agree with what Senator Coleman said. When persons get married by and large they consider that situation. They desire it to take place. Many of them, particularly women, are absolutely staggered when the man-very often in this case-simply shoots through and leaves them with the children. After 12 months separation he may lodge an application for the dissolution of that marriage without the consent of the other partner to the marriage and very often, with her positive dissent. It is a fact that-I challenge the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans) to deny this-the majority of persons seeking the assistance of marriage counsellors and marriage counselling organisations in Australia are women. Of course, many of those women are quite alarmed at the fact that they have been left; that their husbands have shot through. There is no requirement for the husband to sit down with the wife and a marriage counsellor and for them to consider the social, economic and legal consequences and the consequences to the children of that action. To show that what I have been saying is understood by some members of the court, I quote from the judgment in the Court of Appeal case, Seidler v. Schallhofer. The Court of Appeal comprised Justices Hope, Reynolds and Hutley and the judgment was given on 23 August 1982. I read from a statement by Mr Justice Hutley. It is a pretty frank statement on what we are talking about here. I quote from page 100 of New South Wales Law Reports 1982, which states:

. . . The monogamous marriage for life runs counter to such powerful passions in men and women that only strong legal and social sanctions could maintain it, particularly in a society where the pursuit of pleasure is regarded as its own justification. These sanctions have been abandoned, or repealed for example, damages can no longer be recovered from a seducer.
The next sentence is irrelevant, but in the next paragraph His Honour says:

The marriage which the law now provides is of an entirely different kind. It is an arrangement terminable by either party on one year's separation, really one year's notice, as the separation may be fictitious. Though the Family Law Act 1975 provides in section 43:

The Family Court shall, in the exercise of its jurisdiction under this Act or any other Act, and any other court exercising jurisdiction under this Act shall, in the exercise of that jurisdiction, have regard to-
(a) the need to preserve and protect the institution of marriage as the union of a man and a woman to the exclusion of all others voluntarily entered into for life;

(b) the need to give the widest possible protection and assistance to the family as the natural and fundamental group unit of society, particularly while it is responsible for the care and education of dependent children . . .

this can only be regarded as propaganda contradicted by the substantial provisions of the Act which, except for the creation of counselling facilities, are directed to the speedy termination of the married state . . .

That is the opinion of one judge. I do not agree that that ought to be the case but what he is saying there is that if section 43 means anything and if the definition of marriage means anything, then section 48 simply contradicts and overturns that section. All that is being attempted by Senator Durack at this late stage of the debate is at least to extend that period of 12 months to two years. I feel that that is not a sufficient period but I will support it. The onus of proof is on those who supported and continue to support the 12 months separation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh no.

—The onus is on them. Senator Missen says 'Oh no'. The onus is on them because of the result, and the result is quite clear. The result is a continuing escalation of the divorce rate in Australia with the consequential social damaging effects to those people directly affected and to society as a whole.
—The Joint Committee answers it.

—The Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act does not answer it at all. It has been said previously that the Joint Committee did not receive evidence on this point but in fact it did receive evidence suggesting that there ought to be an extension of the period. Of course, the Joint Committee rejected that evidence because people such as Senator Missen served on it. As we are talking about the Joint Committee, when did the Joint Committee report?
—Three years ago.

—It was longer than three years ago. A lot of water has flown under the bridge since three years ago. You will notice, Mr Chairman, that the figures since three years ago, of course, have created more concern. So the onus of proof is on those who are maintaining the arbitrary period of 12 months. Those who oppose the extension must address themselves to what needs to be inserted in the legislation to stop the drift and the damaging effect that that drift and the increasing number of divorces are having on society today. The onus is on those people to ensure that something is inserted in this legislation which will create a legislative, even educative, atmosphere.
—Intimidation.

—What a lot of rot. Senator Missen would not understand. But a woman with five or six kids may have a husband who has shot through and is mucking around all over the town, leaving her with the five kids. Does Senator Missen not believe that this law intimidates many people who are left stranded in that situation? It does. That roue can shack up all over the place, stay away for 12 months and then file an application for divorce. However, if the period of separation were longer and there were associated provisions in the Act for reconciliation counselling, that at least would ensure that the couple would have to face facts. I repeat to those honourable senators who vote against these measures that are trying to tighten up the legislation that the onus is on them to do something about it.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that Senator Harradine did not have an opportunity of finishing the remarks he was making because he was drawing them to a close, but his conclusion was not reached. I do not rise solely for the purpose of giving him an opportunity to speak again. I want to add one or two matters to the debate in support of the amendment I have moved. I listened with interest to the reasons given by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) for not supporting it. His remarks were relevant only to my argument that a separation of one year was not adequate proof of irretrievable breakdown. I do not think his arguments really dealt with my other, and much more important, argument-that is, that we must establish a new attitude, a new approach, by many people to the institution of marraige and to the responsibilities they have in marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: The idea that one can get out of a marriage by separating for 12 months does not induce an adequate sense of responsibility. I will refer to arguments that Senator Coleman and Senator Missen advanced because I feel there is a fundamental disagreement between their approach and mine on this issue. I was familiar with the legislation in force before the Family Law Act. At that time I had more practical experience in the area of matrimonial law at the work face so to speak. There was a growing view that the basic and only reason for divorce should be irretrievable breakdown of marriage. I agree with that proposition. There was also the rather simplistic idea that once a marriage had broken down it ought to be put to an end as swiftly as possible to give people the opportunity of building a new life or a new marriage, given that the children would be better off under those circumstances rather than suffering under a marriage which had broken down. That argument seems to be the foundation of the views that have been expressed in this debate, particularly by Senators Coleman and Missen. As I have said, this is a simplistic view because the fundamental question is one of how, when and why a marriage has irretrievably broken down. It is not simply a question of people separating and after a period of six months, 12 months or even two years-whatever period is adopted as law-saying that that means the marriage has broken down.

The point is that marriages have their ups and downs. When problems arise in a marriage, even when separation occurs, it does not mean by any stretch of the imagination that the marriage has broken down. Our social buttressing of marriage, our law, needs to offer various inducements to encourage people to think again, to work together, to get help, to try to work out a more satisfactory relationship and thereby prevent the marriage breaking down. Many things need to be done. I do not by any means see this as the only solution. I agree with Senator Harradine. During this debate I have already mentioned the provision for compulsory counselling before people can get a divorce. The provision that they establish that they have tried such counselling is a very worthwhile one. I hope we will debate that matter further. I know there are resource problems associated with such a provision, but I think it is very worthwhile.

Another amendment that I have moved seeks to tighten up that law by which people can easily overcome their financial problems when they divorce by resorting to various social welfare benefits. That makes things much easier for people. Obviously one of the problems in the past has been the financial problems that people face when they separate and divorce. We have made it far too easy for them by enabling the problem to be very largely solved by the taxpayer. There are a number of matters on which new policies need to be adopted in order to buttress marriage, to induce people to try to co-operate to solve their problems and to reconcile. One thing I was very concerned about when I was responsible for administering this Act was the attitude of the court counsellors who seemed to see their role as being concerned not with attempting reconciliation but simply with helping people over the stile towards divorce. I know that they do a very worthwhile job; I am not criticising their work. But I am very concerned, and I criticise that attitude, because I think much more attention must be given to counselling for reconciliation.

I come back to the basic attitude which I think has been developing for many years, since long before the Family Law Act was brought into effect, namely, when people run into trouble with their marriages and are a bit unhappy and meet somebody else, they put an end to that marriage and marry again because it is better for the parties and for the children and because everyone will then live happily ever after. The fact is that that is not proving to be the case. It might be a wonderful humanistic notion and at one stage it might have been a very attractive proposition, but the statistics now show that second mariages have about a 50 per cent failure rate. What is the point of all this great humanism if in fact it is not working and people have only a 50 per cent chance of being happier as a result of divorce and remarriage? I believe all those considerations are most important in support of this amendment. I think this amendment is not itself by any means an answer. It has to be coupled with other propositions which have been before the chamber in this debate and which have also yet to be considered in this debate, but I think it goes to the central feature of the Family Law Act. If it were passed by the Parliament, which I hope it will be, it would have a very significant effect in buttressing the institution of marriage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman-
—Oh, give it a rest, Noel.

—I will be brief for the convenience of everybody but the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). I think the amendment has been canvassed fully and effectively, but it has always struck me that almost all amendments to this Act since 1975 have been designed primarily to make divorce less painful and more convenient and comfortable for the partners. Of course, there are those who will always argue that that is desirable while there are those who take the contrary view. There seems to be little in the Act which really directly seeks to strengthen the bonds of marriage. Is there anything unattractive or unreasonable about maintaining the strength of the bonds of marriage and the implications of marriage? Most of the amendments have dealt with overcoming the problem of a pending divorce rather than looking at the contract at the outset. I have always taken the view that the greater the consequences of the contract, the greater the care a prudent person will take before entering into the contract, whether it be a marriage or any other contract. I have heard no argument so far which in any way convinces me that a 12-month period of separation is far superior for the maintenance of the institution of marriage than a 24-month period of separation. I believe there ought to be a responsibility upon the lawmakers to place greater social awareness and greater social conscience upon the implications of marriage and what it represents.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Durack's amendment) be added.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 21 agreed to.
Clause 22 (Guardianship and Custody).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Page 14, lines 33 to 41, leave out proposed sub-sections 60A (1) and (2), the following sub-sections:

'' '60A. (1) A person who is the guardian of a child under this Act has responsibility for the long-term welfare of the child and has, in relation to that child, all the powers, rights and duties that are, apart from this Act, vested by law or custom in the guardian of a child, other than-
(a) the right to have the daily care and control of the child; and
(b) the right and responsibility to make decisions concerning the daily care and control of the child.
'(2) A person who has or is granted custody of a child under this Act has-
(a) the right to have the daily care and control of the child; and
(b) the right and responsibility to make decisions concerning the daily care and control of the child.''.

This is an amendment to proposed sub-sections 60A (1) and (2) of the Bill, which describe the right to custody of a child. The language in the original draft of the amendment was in terms of the right to the possession of a child as being the appropriate definition of the right to custody. Since the amendments were first formulated the Watson Committee Report of November 1982 has come down, dealing with the subject of wardship, guardianship and custody, among other things. A subsequent rethinking of that report so far as this recommendation is concerned has made it clear that the appropriate language in which to describe custody and guardianship is not 'the possession of the child' but rather 'the right to have the daily care and control of the child' and 'the right and responsibility to make decisions concerning the daily care and control of the child'. All that we propose in this further amendment is to employ language which is rather more satisfactory in describing the nature of that relationship. I believe that the amendment is uncontroversial and I commend it to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment and announce that I propose not to withdraw my amendments which on the consolidated list are Nos (28 ), (29) and (30). They were originally part of the alternative proposal which the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act put up in respect of the definition of these matters. The Committee had in mind also that a wardship provision might be included. The Watson Committee has not favoured the resurrection of the rather ancient language of wardship and I think that the amendment that the Attorney-General has now moved is in accord with the fairly sound report of the Watson Committee, which was headed by a judge with a fair amount of experience in this matter. There is, I think, some criticism. Some judges and others do not hold the view that the Watson proposals are necessarily the best. I think that on the whole, the Watson proposals overcome and widen the definition of what is involved in custody. They do not bring antique language back into the Act which otherwise might be included. Consequently, I do not propose to move amendments Nos (28), (29) and (30) in my name.

—When I went through the original amending Bill I questioned that part which dealt with the possession of the child. I am glad that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has remedied that situation. I wonder whether the Attorney will give me a brief explanation of a matter I wish to raise. Even in the amendment to clause 22 there appears to be a distinction between the guardian and the person who has custody. The amendment seems to say that the guardian spouse will have the power and the custodial spouse will have the responsibility. I should like an explanation of that because, if that is the case, it could engender an enormous amount of unnecessary anger and enmity between the parents, the parties, to the detriment of the child. Can the Attorney explain that to the Committee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The essential distinction is that the long term welfare decisions are the responsibility of the guardian. The day to day care and responsibility in the short term sense is inherent in the conception of custody. Very often the two concepts will, of course, overlap but in some circumstances it is appropriate to draw a distinction. To the extent that one can draw a distinction on the particular facts of the situation, that is the essence of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 23 and 24-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Australian Democrats ( Senator Chipp) will not be moving his proposed amendment to clause 24 as a result of discussions that have been held today. Arrangements will be made to incorporate part of the intention of that proposed amendment elsewhere in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clause 25 (Powers of court in custodial proceedings).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —My amendment is to section 64 of the principal Act. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Page 16, before paragraph (a), insert the following new paragraph:
''(a) by omitting from sub-section (1) 'In proceedings with respect to', and substituting 'When considering'.''.

I have moved this amendment because I believe that the judge should have regard to the welfare of the children not just in custody proceedings but when considering any custody-related matters. This applies to undefended cases, to divorce by post, or whatever. Whenever the judge is considering the welfare of the children the following guidelines that have been set out by both the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) and by some of my amendments should be taken into consideration. I believe that that small amendment is not controversial. I am quite sure the Attorney will agree to that little request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am always very sad to disappoint Senator Walters but I must do so on this occasion because lurking beneath that small and, on the face of it, semantic point she seeks to make is in fact a change of some considerable magnitude, as I rather suspect the honourable senator is not entirely unaware. The effect of the amendment can be described as follows: At present when granting a divorce the court has to be satisfied that proper arrangements are made for the children, otherwise the decree nisi cannot become absolute. Senator Walters's amendment would require the court, when it is so satisfying itself, to look at the matters contained in section 64 (1) of the parent Act. These matters include children's wishes and, indeed, the whole range of custody criteria. This obligation being imposed upon the court would result in an impossible burden being placed on the court when granting divorces. So much evidence would be needed to satisfy the section 64 (1 ) tests that the court would have to apply that the divorce granting process would simply break down.
—You mean they would have to work a bit harder at it?

—Let me describe why. Of the 44,000 divorces that were granted in 1982, we calculate that 27,158 involved children. So we are talking about something like 27,000 divorces last year and, presumably, this year the same order of magnitude of cases will involve children. However, in that same year-1982-only about 1,000 custody applications were fully heard by the Family Court of Australia and by the Family Court of Western Australia in Western Australia. About 10 per cent of the custody cases filed as disputed actually went to hearing. It was in these 1,000 cases that the court had to apply the criteria set out in section 64 (1) and Senator Walters would now have the court have regard to such criteria in every divorce case involving the presence of children. So what is now occupying the time of the court in but 1,000 cases a year would, if Senator Walters's amendment succeeds, would occupy the court in something like 27,000 cases. If the court were to discharge its legal duty under the terms of the Act as it would be rewritten with Senator Walters's minor semantic amendment the court would, in fact, have that obligation.

SPEECH.PARA: There are further considerations about the burden this would impose upon the parties, particularly those who act for themselves in dissolution cases. The complexity of the application of those custody criteria and the complexity involved in their application in a particular case would, on the whole, require a higher level of legal skills than the most unrepresented parties would obviously be able to bring to bear in these cases. It is simply unrealistic in all the circumstances to impose that burden upon the courts and the parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I really was not prepared for the Attorney- General (Senator Gareth Evans) to tell us tonight that it is too great a burden for the judges of the Family Court to have to be fully satisfied that the rights and the best interests of the children are protected. I am well aware that section 63 states that the judge must be satisfied that 'proper arrangements in all the circumstances have been made for the welfare' of the children. But if that is to be done correctly the judges must take note of the guidelines that have been set down for any reasonable consideration of custody. It was one of the recommendations of the report of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act from which Senator Missen is so very keen to quote and which he seems to consider as his bible. Let us look at what the Committee said. There has been considerable criticism of various judges, and their determinations and prejudices when considering custody arrangements. The Committee said:

SPEECH.PARA: Criticism is sometimes levelled at the subjectivity of judges who are accused of allowing personal prejudices to determine their decisions. It has even been said that it is the list clerks of the courts who determine the outcome of custody cases. The presence of such uncertainty and the opportunities for appeal that this gives rise to under the present Act is considered one of the reasons for the proliferation of applications for custory.

If an uncontested case comes before the court, people may make it convenient for themselves and not act in the best interests of the children. If the judge is not enforced to look at the guidelines set down by legislation, and he is able to allow and, indeed, allows his personal prejudices to determine his decisions, we are not responding to our responsibilities in this place. The evidence received by the Committee showed that judges' decisions vary considerably and that they respond to their own prejudices. It is imperative that guidelines be set down in the legislation which say to the judge: 'This, this and this must be taken into consideration if the best interests of the child are to be maintained '. If the Government says that in a contested case the judge must take more trouble to determine the rights and the well being of the children than in an uncontested case, it is discriminating against the children of the non-contested custody cases by saying that the judge really does not have to show much concern for their well being; it is left entirely to him, without any guidelines. If the case is contested the judge has to take considerable trouble and must abide by the guidelines set down by legislation. There is no justification in that situation whatsoever.

Senator Gareth Evans has said that 27,000 marriages involving children were dissolved. As I have said, the Family Law Act is a very convenient divorce law for parents. It is horrendous for the children. I do not care one jot if it takes a little more time in the courts as long as justice for the children is maintained. I was completely unprepared for the very cynical reply of the Attorney-General when he said that the courts have neither the time nor the money to go into the detail of determining whether children will be looked after in the best possible way. I am rather appalled by the Attorney-General's attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is most curious that Senator Walters appears somewhat to regret that I am taking an interest in the provisions of the report which is the basis of this legislation, and for which she and I are, in nearly all of its recommendations, jointly responsible, having voted for and signed the report. Senator Walters quoted the first half of paragraph 4.49 and left out the rest of it. Of course, what happens then is that that paragraph leads to a recommendation by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. The Committee recommendation is that there should be-and this is all that could be done-some guidelines set out as to matters to be considered by the courts in determining questions of custody. We set out a number of those. What the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has done in his Bill is to set out in somewhat different form-but there is not basically much difference-certain matters which are to be taken into account. That is what that clause is related to.
—Of course it is.

—All right. Well, why is Senator Walters using it on a different matter altogether? In fact, it is relevant to the next part of this clause in the Bill; the Attorney-General has put it there. All the Committee suggested could be done was that guidelines be put in that might qualify the custody situations; and they are in the Bill as recommended.
—That is right.

—I do not know why Senator Walters was using that criticism. She quoted from that report a few introductory remarks of criticisms that were made about judges, and so forth. We did not say that they were justified, or anything of that sort. Some criticisms of judges are, at times, probably justified; others are misunderstandings; others are the words of disappointed parties. We went on to reach a conclusion and make a recommendation, which has been substantially and, I think, fairly faithfully reported, and is in the Bill. It does not justify Senator Walters's arguments for this amendment, and I support the Attorney-General's rejection of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I entirely agree with Senator Walters's amendment. I think that it is entirely consistent with the provisions of section 43 of the legislation, which requires the Family Court to have regard to the need to protect the rights of children and to promote their welfare. It is consistent with that, and I support it.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Page 16, paragraph (b), after proposed new paragraph 64 (1) (b), insert the following new paragraph:

'(baa) subject to paragraphs (a) and (b), the court shall, unless in the opinion of the court it is not practicable, make the order that, in the opinion of the court, is least likely to lead to the institution of further proceedings with respect to the custody or guardianship of the child;'.
(24) Page 17, paragraph (c), lines 6 and 7, leave out ''and substituting ', (b) and (ba)' '', insert ''and substituting ', (b), (baa) and (ba)' ''.

The first part of amendment No. (23) and the latter part of amendment No. (24) are purely procedural, but the basis of the amendments is to put into section 64 of the Act another requirement for the court to consider in determining its decision. The new paragraph would insert:

subject to paragraphs (a) and (b), the court shall, unless in the opinion of the court it is not practicable, make the order that, in the opinion of the court, is least likely to lead to the institution of further proceedings with respect to the custody or guardianship of the child.
This is a unanimous recommendation of the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. In paragraph 4.48 of the Joint Committee's report the following is said :
In order to reduce as far as possible the unnecessary bitter and prolonged custody and access proceedings, a new section 70A-
That is a different number now-

should be inserted in the Act providing that in proceedings with respect to the custody and guardianship of a child of a marriage, the court shall, as far as practicable make such orders as will avoid further proceedings.
It goes on to say:

The Committee does not believe it can go beyond this provision, nor be more specific than this if only for the reason that, in the case of access, it will always need changing much more than custody, and once a custody order is made proceedings can be brought, under recent authorities, by persons other than the parties to the marriage.

I do not suggest that the change that is proposed is a world shattering change. Unfortunately, I understand that the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) is opposed to this proposal but I am really not able to understand why.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep talking, you never know your luck in a big city.

—I can assure the Attorney that, as a member of the Joint Select Committee, I will press this matter to a division if necessary because I believe it is a desirable provision. The nature of the amendments we are making in the Bill, to section 64 do a number of things. They relate among other things, to the welfare and the wishes of the child. There is a very sensible amendment in regard to that. As I have already said, certain other considerations also must be taken into account. This provision is one whereby if it is possible, if it is practicable, the Court should endeavour to stop the continuance of custody proceedings and should try to settle the children in as fixed a position as possible. Undoubtedly, on the evidence the Committee received, there is a great deal to be said for children being in a fixed situation and, for example, for children being together with their siblings-that is, their brothers and sisters. Changing the situation of children from time to time or having a series of custody proceedings-we know such things have occurred over the years in the courts; they promote a great deal of bitterness between the parents and are very damaging to the psyche of the children-is to be avoided if possible and if practicable. This is merely a guideline to the Court suggesting that wherever it can make an order which, other things being equal, and taking into account the other matters in this section, will cut down on the litigation involving parents and the children, then this will be a desirable course. I urge the Committee to support this recommendation of Joint Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not often that I am intimidated by Senator Missen but I am afraid he does have me against the ropes with his threat to press this matter to a division. The basis of my objection was not particularly substantive, but simply that it was an unnecessary and merely cosmetic piece of frippery from the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act and Senator Missen which did not add anything substantial to the sorts of criteria to be applied by the courts and the duties imposed upon them. But since I have no objection, after further consultation with representatives of the judiciary on this, and as I believe that it may in fact have some useful effect in helping to bring matters to finality in guardianship and custody proceedings, I indicate acceptance of Senator Missen's amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Page 16, paragraph (b), before proposed new sub-paragraph 64 (1) (ba) (i), insert the following new sub-paragraphs:
''(iaa) the relevant conduct, as parents, of the parents of the child;
(iaab) the relevant conduct of any step-parents or persons sharing the care, control and guardianship of the child with the custodian;
(iaac) the wishes of the child's parent or parents as to his custody;''.
(26) Page 16, paragraph (b), after proposed new sub-paragraph 64 (1) (ba) (ii), insert the following new sub-paragraphs:
''(iia) if there is more than one child under consideration the effect of the separation on the children;
(iib) the education and up-bringing of the child;''.

As the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) has already entered into consideration of a list of guidelines for judges to abide by in contested custody proceedings, I would also like to add a few. They are some of the guidelines put forward by the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. The things to be taken into account are the relevant conduct of the parents; the relevant conduct of any step-parents or persons sharing care, control or guardianship of the child with the custodian; the wishes of the child's parent or parents as to custody; if more than one child is under consideration, the effect of the separation of the children; and the education and upbringing of the child. My consequential amendment follows on from that.

As I said before, I believe that guidelines for judges to follow are necessary. The Joint Select Committee received considerable evidence that judges do allow personal prejudices to determine their decisions. I quote again from that Committee report:

Criticism is sometimes levelled at the subjectivity of judges who are accused of allowing personal prejudices to determine their decisions. It has even been said that it is the list clerks of the courts who determine the outcome of custody cases. The presence of such uncertainty and the opportunities for appeal that this gives rise to under the present Act is considered one of the reasons for the proliferation of applications for custody. If the outcome of custody cases was more readily predictable by the parties their legal advisers and court counsellors, an inducement to settlement of disputes by negotiations between the parties would be provided.

So the report goes on. I believe that if the people working in this area-the counsellors and the legal profession-and the parents of the child knew the exact situation and the guidelines that the judges must take into consideration there would be fewer applications for custody, fewer appeals, less bitterness and, I believe, the settlement of disputes would be more easily achieved. It amounts to the fact that, as I said a little earlier, the Family Court of Australia is for the convenience of parents. The no fault system is wonderful for the parents- absolutely ideal-but it does nothing for the children. It is because about 400, 000 children have been affected since this Act came in that I believe we must make it possible for judgments to be more uniform than at present. These guidelines, I am sure, will be instrumental in obtaining continuity in that area .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am attracted to this amendment. I think that it would, as Senator Walters said, establish criteria which would minimise, to the extent that it is possible, the somewhat inconsistent views taken by judges of the Family Court of Australia in custody cases. I feel that, besides the matters contained in the proposed amendment moved by the Attorney-General ( Senator Gareth Evans), these guidelines proposed by Senator Walters would greatly assist judges in that respect. Let me retail them. The first, 'the relevant conduct, as parents of the parents of the child', surely is important when considering custody cases. The next two are 'the relevant conduct of any step-parents or persons sharing the care, control and guardianship of the child with the custodian' and 'the wishes of the child's parent or parents as to custody'. These seem to be self-evident, but it is clear from some decisions of the Family Court judges that they are not all guided by these sorts of guidelines. They may wish to be guided by them, but there may be pressure which may not always contribute to a clear and just decision in custody cases. I do not want to reflect on the integrity of the judges; it has been said quite clearly that they are under pressure. The next provides that if there is more than one child under consideration the judge must consider the effect of the separation on the children. That seems to me to be a self-evident guideline which ought to be applied in relation to the education and upbringing of the children.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe the major point that Senator Walters made was that if these guidelines were stipulated in the legislation it is more likely that agreement would be reached between the parties as to custody. If the guidelines are there those advising the parties have a reference against which they can provide the advice to the parties. If the parties have advice and are conducting their own applications and so forth, they too have a reference against which they can make considerations of themselves and jointly in regard to the custody of their children. For those reasons I believe the amendments moved by Senator Walters should be welcomed and accepted by the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments proposed by Senator Walters and supported by Senator Harradine do have merit to the extent that they seek to introduce criteria for the Court to apply in making a custody decision where hitherto no detailed criteria had existed. Up until now the test has simply seen that in the language of section 64 (1) of the Act the Court shall regard the welfare of the child as the paramount consideration. Undoubtedly the Court has taken into account, in determining the welfare of the child, the conduct of the parents as parents and some of the other factors that have been mentioned, but it certaintly does no harm to spell out in some detail the kinds of considerations that really do make up that total concept of what is in the best interests of the welfare of the child. Indeed, that was the very motivation which led me, in picking up the recommendation of the Joint Select Committee, to seek to write into clause 25 some detailed criteria.

SPEECH.PARA: The only question before us is not the desirability of these sorts of criteria, because these criteria are now proposed to be put in there by the main substantive amendment which is before us, but whether it adds anything useful or intelligible to those criteria to go down the track that has been plotted for us by Senator Walters. I put it to the Committee that it is not useful to add the kind of criteria, the further criteria, that Senator Walters would have us add. Either they are quite unecessary or they are unintelligible or both. Let me document that particular contention. So far as Senator Walters' amendment No. ( 25) is concerned, she would have us have regard, in the first instance, to the relevant conduct as parents of the parents of the child. One possible ground of objection to that is that it does rather seem to be trying to sneak in through the back door elements of fault which arguably have no place in the Family Law Act at all. I would acknowledge-

TALK.START.PARA: —As parents.

—Yes. I ask that Senator Harradine allow me to finish my sentence. I do acknowledge that when one is focusing on the custody situation and the considerations going directly to the welfare of the child, the performance, the behaviour-if you like, the conduct-of the parents as parents in a parent-child relationship is relevant. I simply make the point that it is unnecessary to use that further language that Senator Walters proposes given, in particular, paragraph (iv) of sub-clause (ba) in new section 64 which we are proposing. Without confusing matters too much with that set of numerals, the phrase I have in mind is this:

SPEECH.PARA: the capacity of each parent, or of any other person, to care adequately for the child;

That concept of capacity of the parent does, I suggest, steer the Court directly in the direction of looking at and evaluating the behaviour and the capacity of the parent as a parent to do the job that a parent should, bearing in mind that this is not just a criterion expressed in the abstract but a criterion which sits there under the umbrella of an obligation on the Court to have paramount regard to the welfare of the child.

Were that all that were in issue with Senator Walters's proposition in that respect maybe we could live with it. It is when we move down to her next criterion, that is, 'the relevant conduct of any step-parents or persons sharing care, control and guardianship of the child with the custodian' that we start to run into difficulties. I suggest the basic difficulty about this proposed sub- paragraph is that it is quite unintelligible. Who is the custodian for the purposes of the operation of this clause? Is Senator Walters referring to a person who had custody prior to or at the time of the proceedings in which this criterion is being applied or is she referring to an applicant for custody? The language in which this sub-paragraph has been drafted is quite obscure. Proposed new sub-paragraph (iaac) refers to the wishes of the child's parent or parents as to his custody. It is quite absurd to suggest the inclusion of a criterion of this kind to which the court should have regard because it is the very conflict of those wishes that causes the case to be before the court. It is only in the context of a contested custody matter in which the wishes of the respective parents are being fought over in the court that these matters will even arise. I suggest that at the very least it is quite redundant to have a criterion of the kind proposed in Senator Walters's amendment No.(25).

We then get to her further amendment-amendment No. (26)-in which she suggests that a further criterion is separation from other children. I draw the attention of the Committee to the fact that that is already squarely covered by criterion (ii) in the Bill in which the court is obliged to take into account the effect on the child of any separation from either parent of the child or any child or other person with whom the child has been living. The separation from other children is squarely covered by the existing proposal in the Bill. The question of education which Senator Walters also wants us to have regard to is covered, albeit not specifically but certainly by the general language of criterion in (v ), namely any other fact or circumstance that, in the opinion of the court, the welfare of the child requires to be taken into account.

I make it clear that I again understand the reasoning behind Senator Walters' amendment. I share her concern that there be detailed critera spelt out but I suggest, with every respect, that the drafting of the proposition she puts before us is a muddle. It would create more confusion than it would resolve. It is simply unnecessary, given the array of detailed criteria to which the court is obliged to have regard by virtue of the passage of the parent amendment that is now before the Committee. I suggest that her amendment be rejected accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am rather amazed by the reaction of the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) to this amendment, particularly his reaction to the amendment moved previously by Senator Missen. To my mind, Senator Missen's amendment is of no significance whatsoever. I did not speak to it because I did not think it was worth any attention. If the Attorney wants to clutter up his Act with such a meaningless and pointless addition that is his business, but I did not think that we needed to worry about it. He saw fit to do so because he said it was something from the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act. We know that the Committee's report which is the result of very careful consideration is a matter which certainly needs to be taken into account . Senator Walters brought forward some further amendments which I understand are also based on recommendations from the Committee.
—That is correct.
—I expect Senator Missen to support these matters.
—I am supporting them; I am not speaking on everything.

—I am pleased to hear that he does. I believe that the Attorney has got himself into a difficult position because he has decided to accept the Committee's recommendation to spell out criteria, but this whole exercise is showing how difficult it is to do so. I believe it would be better not to have embarked on this exercise at all but rather to have relied on the law as it has been developed and is developing in relation to the criteria. As the decision has been made to spell them out I think that a further attempt should be made to meet the points which the Committee has recommended and which Senator Walters has spelt out in her amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I concede that there seems to be some duplication in the amendments of Senator Walters and the criteria set out in the Bill. Nevertheless I feel that some quite relevant additions to those criteria arise from Senator Walters's amendments. As the Senate must shortly adjourn, I ask the Attorney-General to give further consideration to these amendments, to see whether additional criteria might not be usefully incorporated in the Bill. For instance, I do not think it is good enough, in spelling out criteria in a Bill, to say that a specific criterion-to take into account the education and upbringing of a child- is covered by Government amendment No. (21). Clearly, amendment No. (21) will cover almost all the other criteria anyway. But if the Attorney-General is to embark upon the exercise of spelling out criteria I think it ought to be done properly. I suggest that he give this matter more consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no wish to cut the debate short at this crucial stage. I undertake to give it more consideration in the light of the comments made by Senator Durack.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.
