DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION (UNPAID COMPANY TAX) ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1983

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

Some three months ago I introduced into the Senate a Bill by this title. The major purpose of that Bill was to give effect to this Government's election undertaking to recover personal tax avoided by former owners of companies that were the subject of 'bottom-of-the-harbour' schemes. In addition, the Bill was designed to strengthen and improve in several identified areas the legislation passed by the Parliament last year to recoup the company tax that was evaded by the use of these schemes. Honourable senators will recall that the Bill was defeated on a tied vote in this House.

As foreshadowed by the Treasurer in his Budget Speech the Government is now submitting to the Parliament, as an important part of the Budget, a Bill that covers essentially the same ground as the earlier one but which has been changed in significant respects. The principal change concerns the measure of personal tax to be recovered. Under the earlier Bill, former owners of a stripped company were to be made liable for personal tax on the total after-tax accumulated profits effectively received by them as part of the price received for the sale of their shares. The Government has now decided that the recovery of personal tax should be confined to such tax avoided in respect of the liberated after-tax profits of those years of income where evasion of primary company tax was involved. In short, the personal tax measures will apply to 'current-year' profits. This limitation will mean that personal tax avoided in respect of profits of earlier years that had borne primary company tax will not be within the scope of the legislation as now proposed. Similarly personal tax is not to be recouped in respect of any capital profits of the stripped company, regardless of the year of income in which such profits were derived.

Another significant aspect of the proposed limitation is that a liability for avoided personal tax will not arise in respect of any year of income where the only company tax evaded for that year was undistributed profits tax under Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I mention also that the time-to-pay , free of interest, facility included in the earlier Bill has been retained in the present Bill. The Government believes that, with the changed basis of measuring the liability for personal tax together with retention of the time-to- pay facility, the legislation is now in a form which responds adequately to the points made by honourable senators in the debate on the earlier Bill.

Mr President, subject to one exception, the present Bill proposes to strengthen and improve the company tax recoupment measures in the same areas as were proposed in the earlier Bill. The exception concerns the proposal under the earlier Bill to simplify the procedures that require copies of notices of company assessments be served on a range of former owners. The passage of time has reduced the administrative advantages which that proposal was designed to provide and has obviated the need for the amendments. The Government has therefore decided not to proceed with these. For the reasons connected with the grounds of a recent constitutional challenge in the High Court to the validity of the recoupment tax legislation, and about which I will have something to say later, this Bill now proposes a variation to earlier amendments to an evidentiary provision of the recoupment tax legislation. I turn now to the details of the Bill.
Measures to Recover Personal tax

By far the greater part of this Bill is related to amendments to give effect to our decision that the restitution expected of those persons who benefited from the sale of shares in companies that were stripped of pre-tax profits should not be limited to the tax that ought to have been paid by the companies concerned. Rather, those persons should also pay the tax that, as shareholders or other former owners, they escaped through receipt in a non-taxable capital form of after-tax profits that, if the companies had continued to operate as going concerns, would have been taxable as dividends in their hands. As I mentioned earlier, the recovery of personal tax will, however, be confined to the tax related to after-tax revenue profits of the stripped company for those years of income in respect of which primary company tax was evaded. In our view it is quite beyond argument that the revenue is just as entitled to have these tax losses made good as it is to have the lost company tax made good. This Bill will accordingly insert in the recoupment tax law rules to be applied to fix the liability of former owners of a stripped company for personal income tax on those profits on which primary company tax was evaded. Broadly, these rules will require a former owner of a stripped company to pay income tax on the basis that the company has paid a dividend to the former owner at the time of sale of the shares. The amount of this imputed dividend will be the same proportion of the company's after-tax taxable income for the year of income in respect of which primary company tax was evaded as the proportion of the sale consideration recieved by that owner. The amount of after-tax taxable income will be determined after allowance has been made for the unpaid ordinary company tax that is to be recouped under the existing legislation, as proposed to be amended .

The Bill provides that a dividend will be deemed to have been paid in circumstaces where the former owner of a company is liable to make good unpaid company tax on the company's taxable income, that is, where there is a liability for vendors recoupment tax in relation to ordinary company tax or there would have been such a liability if any payments of such tax made after 25 July 1982 were disregared. That date is, of course, the date on which the former Government announced its intention to legislate to recover unpaid company tax escaped through 'Bottom-of-the-harbour' schemes. This qualifications is necessary to ensure that the liability for escaped personal income tax will not be avoided by simply making a payment of the company tax in pursuance of the former Government's announcement or of the legislation enacted last year. The requirement that there exists or, but for payments of company tax, would exist a liability for vendors recoupment tax means, that where the liability for that tax is or would be less than $100 and the Commissioner of Taxation exercise his power under the existing law not to pursue the liability, there will be no liability for the relatively small amounts of personal income tax that would otherwise be liable to be recouped. Where the former owner concerned is a natural person the imputed dividend is to be included in his or her assessable income. In the case of any entity not itself subject to income tax on the dividend by reason of its tax exempt status or, in certain cases, the inter- company dividend rebate, the imputed amount will of course be treated as tax- free income in the hands of that entity. Where a company, or a person as trustee of a trust, is allocated a divident that is deemed to have been paid by a stripped company and the owners of that company, or the beneficiaries of that trust, are the same persons as the former owners of the stripped company at the date of its sale, the company or trustee will, in the first instance, be liable to pay dividend recoupment tax on the dividend at the maximum personal rate applicable to the year of income in which the sale of shares occurred. However, there is to be a right for former owners in this situation to elect to be taxed on amounts equal in total to the amount of the dividend deemed to have been received by the company or trust concerned. If this election is made, and the Commissioner is satisfied that the allocation of the deemed dividend among former owners is reasonable and that personal tax, if any, payable by the former owners will, subject to the hardship relief provisions of the income tax law, be paid by them, the interposed company or trust will be freed from its liability for dividend recoupment tax. In a similar fashion a stripped company will, where a liability for personal tax or dividend recoupment tax exists, be freed from its liability for the income year concerned for undistributed profits tax payable under Division 7, and the former owners will accordingly no longer be liable for vendors recoupment tax on an unpaid Division 7 liability for that year.

As already mentioned a liability for personal tax or dividend recoupment tax will not exist in relation to the profits of a particular year of income where the only unpaid company tax for that year giving rise to a liability for vendors recoupment tax is a liability for undistributed profits tax under Division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. As with the existing recoupment tax law it will be possible under the provisions being inserted by this Bill to trace from the primary level to the next level and, as necessary, successively to further levels where a company or trust has ceased to exist, has different shareholders or beneficiaries as a result of shares or beneficial interests having been sold, or is unlikely to be able to meet a liability for dividend recoupment tax on the dividend which is deemed to have been paid to it. The automatic tracing process applicable in this case will continue until a dividend is deemed to have been paid to a natural person-for tax-free entity referred to earlier-or to a company or trust that still exists if, in the latter situations, the company or trust is one the ownership of which has not changed since the stripped company was sold and has the capacity to met the dividend recoupment tax payable.

A significant feature of the Bill is the provision of a time-to-pay facility in relation to the personal income tax and dividend recoupment tax liabilities which are to be imposed by this and an associated Bill. This provision is modelled on an existing facility-which is to be retained in a modified form- which permits former owners of companies who are liable to pay a share of unpaid company tax to meet that liability by instalments, typically over 12 months without late payment penalty being charged. Initially, the Government proposed that the existing facility be abolished from a date to be proclaimed. On review, we accepted and still accept that the particular facility for time-to-pay should be retained and indeed extended so that a liablity for dividend recoupment tax and related personal tax may also be paid over 12 months without attracting additional tax for late payment. The modification of the existing facility I referred to a moment ago is to impose a strict limitation to 12 months as the period for which an arrangment to pay unpaid company tax may be made. Similarly, the proposed facility in relation to personal tax and dividend recoupment tax will require full payment to be made within a period of 12 months if the penalty -free concession is to be attracted. An application for time to pay personal income tax or dividend recoupment tax in respect of a share of a stripped company's profits will need to be made within 30 days after service of the notice of assessment relating to that liability.
Post-sale Avoidance Schemes

The recoupment tax legislation contains a let-out provision that operates where the stripped company was the subject of an unsuccessful post-sale scheme to avoid tax. Under this escape clause there is no liability to recoupment tax liability on the people who benefited by non-payment of the company tax. This provision was inserted by the former Government for reasons which are best known to it. In our view it defies logic and it is our announced policy to abolish it. This is to be done by the Bill.
Pre-sale Avoidance Schemes

Consistently with the removal of the post-sale avoidance scheme provision, this Bill will also ensure that, in ascertaining the potential tax liability of a company for the purpose of determining whether the recoupment tax legislation applies in relation to it, any pre-sale scheme which is ultimately established to be ineffective of its tax avoidance purpose is to disregarded. There are several further amendments contained in the Bill designed to improve the administration of the legislation or to correct technical deficiencies. The Bill proposes to remove one of the pre-conditions to liability for recoupment tax-the requirement that the company was by a stripping scheme rendered unable to pay its tax-which was inserted by the previous Government, it seems for presentational purposes. The element that the requirement expresses is, in substance, present in all cases of pre-tax profit stripping to which the legislation applies and a specific reference to it is quite unnecessary. The ' stripping scheme test', and an associated provision requiring full disclosure by the Commissioner of known details of it, is being exploited by some taxpayers as a means of delaying issue of recoupment tax assessments. Because of their availability as a pure delaying tactic, the provisions are having and will, unless removed, continue to have an adverse effect on revenue.

It is also proposed by this Bill to re-insert in the recoupment tax legislation a provision removed by the previous Government which authorised the Commissioner of Taxation to report to this Parliament the names of persons who fail to meet their liability for vendors or promoters recoupment tax. The Commissioner is already required to provide in his annual report to Parliament details of breaches or evasions of the taxation laws and it is consistent with that duty that he be authorised, where he considers it appropriate, to report details of failure to pay recoupment tax.

Finally, I explain an amendment I touched on earlier. An existing provision of the recoupment tax legislation that reflects the settled policy of the tax law in these matters seeks to ensure that persons liable for recoupment tax can only contest the correctness of the underlying company assessment through the established objection and appeal procedures against the company assessment itself. For this purpose it provides that a certificate specifying the amount of a company's liability to company tax is to be conclusive evidence except in an appeal concerning the assessment of the company. Some technical deficiencies in the provision were to be corrected by the Bill that was defeated earlier in the year and the Government has, with an eye to a particular constitutional question , now decided to make some other amendments as well. Honourable senators will know that the recoupment tax legislation has been under constitutional challenge , on a number of grounds. One of them concerns the evidentiary provision and reflects a legal argument that the Commonwealth cannot validly levy a tax that is uncontestable. It is said that there are circumstances where a certificate that is conclusive evidence would render the tax uncontestable. Obviously it cannot be predicted what decision the High Court will reach on the particular point but the Government has concluded that it should solve the difficulty by legislating so that the certificate represents only prima facie evidence, with the result that the matters that are the subject of it will therefore clearly not be uncontestable. In providing to that effect the Bill also proposes that such a certificate would in appropriate circumstances represent conclusive evidence if a provision in the Bill that re-instates its conclusive nature were to be proclaimed. A decision on whether to make the proclamation, and thus have the provision revert to the conclusive evidence form that is reflective of settled policy, will be made in the light of any High Court decision on the underlying constitutional point.

Mr President, the revenue implications of these amendments in the context of the Budget are significant. The measures contained in the Bill are estimated to yield $270m in total and $60m in 1983-84, and they should be given the approval of the Parliament. As usual with amendments of the taxation laws, an explanatory memorandum giving details of the amendments contained in the Bill is being circulated to honourable senators. It will be clear that while the Government stands by the principles of the earlier Bill, it has nevertheless been prepared to modify its stance to meet all reasonable criticisms of the original measures. In that light, I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Mr David Combe-Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority-Telegram Expenses of Member for Kingston-Excise on Grape Spirit

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr David Combe-Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority-Telegram Expenses of Member for Kingston-Excise on Grape Spirit

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 11 p.m., under sessional order I put the question :

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 2 of the Australian of today's date there is an article headlined 'Combe denies Communist tag'. This article deals with responses given by Mr David Combe to cross-examination in the hearings of the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies of 6 September. Mr Combe told the Commission that he had indicated to the Northern Territory Government that it would be accepted as a client in his lobbying business only with the approval of the Australian Labor Party Opposition in the Territory. In reporting the relationship of members of the ALP in the Northern Territory the Australian stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Though Mr Combe did not claim Mr Collins-
he is the Leader of the Opposition of the Northern Territory-
gave his blessing to this business deal he had the approval of current Northern Territory members of the House of Representatives and the Senate who are in the ALP.

I cannot speak for Mr Collins, MHA, or Mr Reeves, MHR, but I would like to place on record the fact that I was not contacted by Mr Combe prior to his acceptance of the Northern Territory Government as a client. Reports in the media would suggest that my colleague Mr Reeves opposed the utilisation by the Northern Territory Government of Mr Combe's services as a lobbyist. I make this comment because Mr Reeves is at present overseas on parliamentary business and unable to respond personally at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a matter I wish to raise with the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) concerning an answer to a question she gave on 25 August last. In relation to the Australian Capital Territory school system, the Minister pointed out that there was an additional sum in the Budget this year, a real increase of $300,000 . I quote from Hansard of 25 August what she went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I have already had discussions with the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority as to how that money can best be spent to overcome defects in Australian Capital Territory Schools. The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is an independent body which conducts its business under an ordinance of the Austalian Capital Territory and it is in the best position to make decisions as to the allocation of that money.

The Minister in that statement was clearly conveying to the Senate that the Schools Authority was in the best position and had the right to determine how that money was to be spent. It is a fact that pursuant to the Schools Authority Ordinance, section 6, sub-paragraph (iii), the Authority must 'perform its functions in accordance with any directions given by the Minister'. From the Press release of the Schools Authority of 26 August, it is in fact apparent that the Minister did direct the Authority as to how to spend the $300,000, but for some reason she was not prepared to tell the Senate that she had done so. The Schools Authority in its deliberations had clearly determined that the top priority for any additional funding available in the Australian Capital Territory was to be for the improvement of the resourcing formula for schools. The Press statement that I have referred to says:

In making this recommendation, the Authority took into consideration the Government's decision that funds should not be applied to improving the resourcing formula for schools. The Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, Dr Richard Campbell said: 'This means that the Authority cannot begin reducing class sizes in Kindergarten and Years 1 and 2 despite its being the Authority's top priority.'

The Authority was disappointed at the amount allocated for initiatives. The priorities it proposed involved a 2 per cent real increase in resources covered; reduction of class sizes in kindergarten; 'cushioning' the effects of declining enrolments in small schools; further implementation of the resource teacher scheme; computer education for high schools; full provision of English-as-a- Second-Language services; integration of early childhood services and restructuring of secondary school curricula.

At its special Budget meeting yesterday the Authority expressed regret that the National Government had become involved in deciding matters of local detail. The Authority believes that within broad policy guidelines, local educational priority setting should be left to the statutory authority whose members have direct knowledge of, and are responsible for meeting, the educational needs of Canberra.

As a result of the Minister's directive to the Authority, it has now recommended to the Minister what apparently she wanted it to recommend to her-that the $300, 000 be spent as follows: Computer education $172,000; resource teachers $92,000; curricula for youth $20,000; and early childhood $16,000, a total amount of $300 ,000. It is very clear to me, from the correspondence I have been getting recently in my office, that many parents regard the resourcing formula-that is, class sizes, especially in the early years of schooling-as having a very high priority. They seek to have changes made so that there is a reduction in kindergarten and primary school sizes. It is very clear from the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority's own Press statement that it regards as its top priority the reduction of class sizes in kindergarten and years 1 and 2.

I think the electorate is entitled to know why the Minister rejects class sizes as an important issue and has directed the Authority to ignore its own selected top priority. I think this chamber is entitled to know why the Minister misled the Senate by not disclosing that she had directed the Authority as to how the additional money should be spent, in spite of her assertion that the Authority was best equipped to determine how the money should be spent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon during Question Time in the Senate I raised the matter of the new Australian Labor Party member for Kingston (Mr Bilney) running up a $10,000 telegram bill in one day, all at the taxpayer's expense. I told Mr Bilney that I would be speaking on this matter in the Senate tonight and I see that he is present in the gallery. In order to save time and to set out a brief account of this extraordinary incident, I ask leave of the Senate to incorporate in Hansard an article dated 7 August from the Adelaide Sunday Mail. I have shown it to the Minister for Resources and Energy ( Senator Walsh).

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The article read as follows-
The Kingston quickstep
One-time career diplomat and, latterly, Labor MP, Mr Gordon Bilney, is, on occasion, somewhat less than diplomatic.

The former High Commissioner to Kingston-Jamaica-turned Federal member for Kingston-south-western suburbs- recently made what would be politely referred to in the cercle diplomatique as a faux pas avec volte face rapide.
Or, in other words, the $8000 boo-boo and the $1200 quickstep.

Being a loyal friend, Mr Bilney was concerned at the ignominious fate which befell the former Special Minister of State, Mr Mick Young, and promptly sent off telegram to the other 104 Labor MPs saying so.
Actually, the words he used were: ''Increasingly dismayed.''

Among the other 480 words in the 104 telegrams flying about the country were: ' 'At the least, some key decisions which have been taken seem to have involved a considerable degree of over-reaction . . . I include the decision to accept Mick Young's resignation.''
Other words included ''air of total unreality,'' ''whole fantasy'' and '' incumbent on people of common sense to stand up.''
None of those, of course, are exactly tactful things to say about your boss- especially not when he's going to read them in one of the 104, 480-word telegrams you've been sending all round the place.
Which, perhaps, is why a second telegram was sent a short time later- only 55 words this time-which started out: ''Dear Colleague, on reflection, I think I have been somewhat hasty . . . ''
According to Telecom, the cost of a 480-word telegram is $79.80-multiplied by 104, equals $8299.20.
Admitting to being ''somewhat hasty'' is cheaper-$11.80 a time, of a mere $1227 if you want to tell 104 people about it.
Asked yesterday who would be picking up the bill, Mr Bilney said: ''Well, one is entitled to an allowance for telegrams and that sort of thing.''
But not from Mr Hawke.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Not only members of this Parliament but also the electors of Kingston are concerned about this matter. The answer given by the Government to the question I asked this afternoon is not satisfactory. Certainly it does not satisfy me, nor, I suggest, does it satisfy most members of this Senate. My question was directed to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), representing the Special Minister of State, as this Minister is responsible for the office and other facilities, such as telegrams, provided to members of parliament. However, in an unusual step, the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) intervened instead because it was regarded by the Government as a matter to be taken very seriously at a wider level.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate the genuine and serious answer that the Leader of the Government in the Senate gave to me and to the Senate. The Minister acknowledged that it was a gross abuse of the taxpayers' money. Nevertheless, I was not satisfied with this serious answer. Meanwhile the Government back bench senators were all deathly quiet. They had all received the offending telegrams at a cost of about $100 each and they recognised that a lot was wrong. The Leader of the Government said that his response was immediate. He had put Mr Bilney on the mat and reprimanded him for such an expensive abuse of the facilities paid for by the taxpayers. Senator Button said that he had demanded an explanation. This is where all credibility has to be suspended for it is lacking in this part of the answer, on the part of both the Government and Mr Bilney. The excuse given, and weakly given-I suspect that it is not really believed by Government members-is that Mr Bilney said that he thought the 208 messages he was sending were going by telex and not, as it turned out, by telegram. There are four reasons why this excuse cannot be believed. Whilst this directly reflects on Mr Bilney's lack of credibility, it also reflects on the credibility of the Government. Why did the Leader of the Government in the Senate put this up as an excuse which it appears the Government accepted? The Leader of the Government in the Senate put it up today in the Senate as an attempt at an explanation of what happened.
The first reason for rejecting this explanation is that it was not Mr Bilney's first excuse. When asked by the Press about this at the time Mr Bilney said:
Well, one is entitled to an allowance for telegrams and that sort of thing.

There was no mention of telexes in that explanation. Moreover, this first excuse is misleading because it refers to an allowance. There is no such allowance. There is no concept of a limited grant allowing expenses on telegrams to be used according to the priorities of members of parliament. In fact there is no limit, there is no need for priorities for budgeting out an allowance, so-called, over the year.

The second reason for rejecting the explanation-that is the second attempted explanation referring to telexes-is that all of us know that only very few senators and members actually have telex facilities. In answer to my question here today Senator Button said he did not know, but there might be only eight members who have telexes. But 104 members received $100 telegrams.

The third reason for rejecting the explanation is that it is not possible to send telex messages to a list of addresses. They can be sent only to a list of telex numbers. It is true that the $100 telegrams could have been instead $13 telexes. That would still amount to well over $1,000 in the all up cost for the day's messages-that is, about one-seventh of the cost of the telegrams. But to achieve that there would have had to have been a long list of telex numbers, and these plainly just do not exist.

The fourth reason for rejecting the explanation is that in any event why was it that when $8,000 had already been expended on the first bunch of telegrams the whole process was repeated on the same day? Surely his telexes which were mistaken for telegrams would have come to light by then. At the same time, can we believe that when there was so clear a risk of abusing $10,000 of the taxpayers' money, Mr Bilney did not take very cautious steps to ensure that extraordinary expense was not incurred?

Probably what happened was this: Some of Mr Bilney's Australian Labor Party colleagues, offended by his telegrams attacking his own Prime Minister, rang up and said: 'I have your telegram and disagree with you. Why be so hasty?' Surely Mr Bilney knew that the first set were in fact telegrams. He then straightaway sent off the second set. The explanation is not an explanation. The new honourable member for Kingston could have avoided it all by plainly owning up to what he has done. Why the evasion? Why the unconvincing excuses? Why even try? At the same time, how is it that the Government seems to have accepted this explanation, which is no explanation at all? There is an entire lack of credibility on the part of Mr Bilney and on the part of the Government.

Mr President, the lack of credibility shown by Mr Bilney in this matter of the $10,000 telegram bill is compounded by the same dearth of credibility in his response to the newly imposed tax on fortified wine, imposed a fortnight ago in the Budget introduced by his own Labor Government. The electors of Kingston have once again been misled by their new Labor member of parliament, Mr Bilney. He even refuses to admit that the new $15m per annum wine tax breaks his own and his Party's undertaking given before the election. He does not recognise that a substantial proportion of this tax will have to be paid by the wine industry in his electorate, in the McLaren Vale area, the Southern Vales, that produce some of South Australia's best fortified wines. Unrepentant, Bilney's assertion in Parliament, even after the bad news of the Budget was announced, was that the ALP promise of no wine tax had been 'completely honoured'. That is recorded on pages 272 and 273 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 25 August. Where is the credibility in this? Bilney, in trying to hide--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable member use the prefix 'Mr'.

—Mr Bilney, in trying to hide from and confuse his electorate, is putting his own head in a barrel. But evading the facts is no escape for a politician. What will be the impact of the new tax on South Australia? The grape growers of South Australia will have to pay about $10m per annum in the new tax because two-thirds of Australia's grape spirit is produced in my State of South Australia. This directly undermines their livelihood. It directly undermines the well-being of their families and it directly undermines the viability of the whole industry. In addition, the new wine tax will be payable at the point of blending the fortified wines; that is, unless the Government relents and backtracks on its decision given the Opposition's pressure on it to do so. The tax is payable at the point of blending the fortified wines; that is, before the many years of wine maturation are completed; rather than at the point of sale. Consequently, an enormous additional burden for the wine industry will be the loss incurred in raising bridging finance to pay the tax some years before recovering some of it from the consumer. How will it raise the millions of dollars of bridging finance involved?

SPEECH.PARA: What was the Australian Labor Party's promise that was made to help win Kingston at the last election? Let us remember that even with this promise, Kingston was won by the ALP by a voting margin of only 2 1/2 per cent. During the 1983 election campaign the Labor Party chose McLaren Vale, the southern part of the Kingston electorate in South Australia, as the place to announce the Labor policy for the wine industry. It was there, on 14 February, that the now Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, said:
I pledge that Labor will not contemplate a wine tax.

Beside him sat the candidate for Kingston, Mr Bilney, happy that that assurance could well win the support of the grape growers of the southern vales. This promise, to which Mr Bilney was party, has now been broken. The promise not to contemplate a wine tax now joins the long list of very clear and specific promises which the Labor Government has blatantly broken since coming to office six months ago.

What is the nature of the new tax? The Budget last week imposed an excise tax on fortified wine. The new tax based on alcohol produced from grape spirit at the rate of $2.50 per litre of alcohol is a very severe blow to the many grape growers and wine producers of South Australia, not least those of McLaren Vale in the Kingston electorate. The new tax applies to ports, muscats, sherries, madeiras, vermouths, frontignacs, tokays and all other fortified wines. Not only has a promise been broken; in addition, Mr Bilney has not attempted to come clean with his electorate. Rather than admitting the truth-

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Tonight we are seeing nothing less than a scurrilous attack on the honourable member for Kingston. I put it to you that this well rehearsed written speech by the honourable senator, which I contend is in contravention of the Standing Orders, also offends Standing Orders in that it is offensive to a member of either the Senate or the House of Representatives, in this instance, the House of Representatives. I put it to you that this sort of scurrilous attack within the Parliament should not be allowed to continue. It reflects on the honourable member for Kingston.

—In response to the point of order taken by Senator Bolkus, I draw Senator Teague's attention to the fact that there is a standing order which says that no senator shall read his speech. In response to the second part of the honourable senator's point of order I will listen carefully to Senator Teague's remarks. As far as I can see, he is still within the ambit of standing order 418 . I do not uphold that portion of the point of order.

—I am using careful notes. I acknowledge that this Parliament is a robust place in which its members ought to expect robust debate. If there is an offence to Government members opposite, they need to face up to their own statements and promises during the last election campaign and see whether their members are maintaining credibility. Mr Bilney, rather than admitting the truth that the promise not to introduce a wine tax was a trick to win, at any price, the vote of the wine and grape producers in the southern half of his electorate, told Parliament this week that the promise has, in fact, been kept. He claimed that the promise not to introduce a tax on wine has been 'completely honoured'. One can only ask now: Where is the credibility of the new Labor member for Kingston? Lest honourable senators disbelieve that the honourable member for Kingston could not be so ostrich-like, so adament in denying the facts of this new tax on fortified wines, I quote from his statements in the House of Representatives on the last sitting Thursday, that is the Thursday two days after the Budget. He made a personal explanation in response to remarks made by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the member who represents South Australia's Barossa Valley, the Riverland and the Clare Valley. In a personal explanation aimed directly at this wine tax issue, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) in his remarks referred to the fact that I appeared on a platform with the then shadow Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Kerin, in McLaren Vale during the election campaign. It is quite true that on that occasion I appeared on that platform. The promise was given to the wine industry that there would be no sales or excise taxes on wines. I regard that promise as being completely honoured as a result of this Budget.
On the next page of Hansard, this statement appears:

My point is simply that the honourable member for Wakefield seemed to imply that somehow I had misled the electorate of Kingston. I do not believe that the electorate was misled. I believe that the promise that I associated myself with has been completely honoured. I reject any implication that the Government has not honoured its obligations to the wine industry.

I conclude by repeating this question: In light of this new $15m per year tax on fortified wine, where is the credibility of the new Labor member for Kingston, Mr Bilney? There is no credibility at all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the matters raised by Senator Reid, I am advised that the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority is a statutory authority with powers as set out in its ordinance. The Authority is fully independent in the general conduct and management of schools, for example, the school curricula and general policy. Nevertheless, the Schools Authority Ordinance gives the Minister powers of approval and direction over the Authority in a number of areas, in particular in the area of finance. It is necessary for the Authority to follow the general policy parameters set by the Government in its overall Budget strategy. The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, has received the Authority's recommendations for the expenditure of the additional $300,000 that the Authority was given in the Budget. Senator Ryan is in the process of consulting with the Authority about those recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to matters raised by Senator Teague, who had incorporated into Hansard some beat-up from the Adelaide Sunday Mail, which is another one of the Murdoch Sunday papers. I do not think I need really say any more about the calibre or credibility of Murdoch's Sunday papers. Senator Teague then supplemented the article with some of his own casuistry which was very tedious and boring at this time of night. I do not intend to delay the Senate much longer, but in view of Senator Teague's strong interest in the question of expenses incurred by members of Parliament I will endeavour to obtain information regarding expenditure on the particular facility to which he referred and other services such as car and air transport and charters and the use of parliamentary warrants to travel to country towns to provide professional services for personal gain. Where these expenses are clearly well above normal levels, I will seek to provide that information to the Senate at an appropriate time. I expect that some familiar names, well known perennial plunderers of the public purse, will crop up again when that information is presented to the Senate, and it might well be that the undertaker will be buried.

In regard to the latter part of his speech and his allegations that Labor Party pre-election commitments were broken, the simple fact is that there is no tax on wine. An excise has been applied on spirit which is used for boosting the alcohol content of some wines.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 2 June 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many research projects in the last three years by Australian scientists in the Antarctic have involved killing, wounding, capturing or molesting of any native mammal or native bird.
(2) How many permits have been issued under the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act for killing, wounding, capturing or molesting of any native mammal or native bird.
(3) For what purpose and to whom was each permit issued.

(4) Will any persons who have killed, wounded, captured or molested any native mammal or native bird since the coming into force of the Antartic Treaty ( Environment Protection) Act be prosecuted under that Act if their activities were conducted without a permit.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1 to 3) Since the coming into operation of the Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act in December 1980, a total of 17 permits have been issued in connection with research on the productivity and dynamic functioning of the Antarctic marine ecosystem. The information requested by Senator Mason concerning the names of permit holders, their affiliations, and the projects for which permits were granted is quite extensive and, hence, the Minister for Science and Technology has chosen to pass this information by letter to the honourable Senator. To the maximum extent possible, research on Antarctic wildlife utilises passive sampling techniques which do not place wildlife at risk.

(4) The Antarctic Treaty (Environment Protection) Act 1980 provides strict legal controls for the protection of wildlife in Antarctica. Persons who unlawfully kill, take, injure or otherwise interfere with wildlife in contravention of the provisions of the Act will be prosecuted accordingly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 24 August 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: Are oil tankers permitted to use the Prince of Wales Channel in the Great Barrier Reef; if so, do any restrictions or regulations apply to such use.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Prince of Wales Channel is the only suitable channel for large ships through Torres Strait and is used by oil tankers.
Tankers generally are required to conform to a number of international conventions on the prevention of pollution and on ship safety. There are no special regulations for the Prince of Wales Channel.

The Commonwealth Department of Transport's Marine Information Manual recommends that masters who are not familiar with Torres Strait waters and in particular masters of vessels with limited under keel clearance, embark a pilot of the Queensland Coast and Torres Strait Pilot Service for passage through these waters.

Most oil tankers use the services of a pilot. Pilots require a minimum permissible under keel clearance for vessels up to 11.89 metres draught of 1 metre. For draughts of 11.89 metres to 12.2 metres the permissible under keel clearance is 10 per cent of the draught.
